All Reviews

  1. Nice quality razor. Gives me a good shave with Astra blades. I recommend this razor
  2. There is nothing better than getting a close shave with a single blade instead of getting hair stuck in the triple blade and more razors. This is small enough and easy with a protective shield to lessen the ability to accidentally cut yourself. Make sure to go for the full effect with a brush and shaving cream.<br />The investment is good because razors are not as pricey as Gilette and other competing brands.
  3. Great product. I'm new to DE shaving and I have no complaints. It's very easy to use and I'm now getting the best shave I've ever had. I highly recommend this product.
  4. This razor is well crafted and a joy to use.
  5. My razor completely fell apart after one month of moderate use. And of course it happened a week after the exchange window ran out. Very disappointing as I really enjoyed the razor while it was still functional. Would recommend going with another brand.
  6. Lil heavy and sturdy. Good one.
  7. Good weight, I should have got the longer handle model.
  8. I was brand new to DE shaving when I got this razor and it has worked perfectly. I started out very timid since I really wanted to avoid cutting myself. I've used this razor exclusively for the last 4 months and I've never had a major cut. There have been a few nicks here and there, but nothing too bad. I highly recommend the switch from cartridges.
  9. Just started shaving with a double edge, and this was my first razor. Less expensive than the same exact thing from The Art of Shaving. This razor is weighted so nicely, which is why I picked it over the many other options out there. I wasn't a fan of the Merkur blade that came with it - it cut me up a lot (though I was new to this, so maybe it was my fault). I got a sample pack of replacement blades and was much happier with some others. Highly recommended.
  10. Good razor. A hair below in smoothness as the edwin jagger kelvin. Quality is less than par of the jagger. Two piece but there is a lot of play and hard to line up the razor blade. I prefer the kelvin. This one has a smaller blade gap but more aggressive angle than the kelvin. Doesn't do it for my face.
  11. I love this razor. Has a quality feel to it. Holds blade very securely. Easy to clean. The handle is easy to manipulate around my face.
  12. This razor has given me a closer shave than anything I imagined from your standard Gillette or other &#34;commercial&#34; razors. I can honestly say I will never go back to those razors again. As someone who is prone to razor burns, I am yet to get ONE with this razor and it has been 4+ weeks. I would reccommend this razor to anybody!
  13. Merkur has a well-deserved reputation as producing one of the best shavers in the business. I transitioned to wet shaving with this product after using Mach 3 for many years. It takes a little adjustment to use shorter strokes, but that was the toughest part for me. (In other words, shaving with the Merkur 34C is very easy.) Another tip: Using a stroke of NO MORE THAN AN INCH AT A TIME, rinse the blade after each stroke, and alternate blades each time. Works like a dream.<br /><br />You'll also want to use some good pre-shave oil before you lather, so that the blade glides across your face. I've found that straight castor oil works best for me, which is cheaper than buying the packaged pre-shave oil. Olive oil also works well if you want something lighter. I add some essential oil (sage oil, for instance) for fragrance, but it's not necessary.<br /><br />I also highly recommend using an alum bar after you shave. Many sites on safety-razor shaving rightly point out that alcohol-based aftershaves are bad for your skin (the Art of Shaving site has a lot to say about this). The alum bar is far superior to alcohol-based aftershaves, so you should really consider upgrading to an alum bar. You'll thank me.
  14. Well balanced, nice knurled stock. The blade is half way decent to get you through a day or two. Worth the price, even if it holds together a couple of years.
  15. Luv it!!!!! Shaves great, feels great in my hand and is easy to control due the nice hefty weight. I use Feather blades, insanely sharp, in mine and keep it in an almond oil bath between shavings. I must admit that I don't use it as often as I use to because I'm a recent convert to cut-throat shaving. Nothing shaves closer then a straight razor, period!!!!! However, before treading into cut-throat territory I would strongly advise that you research, research, research and understand straight razor mechanics, angles, movements, maintenance and cost!!!! Practice on something that doesn't bleed, like a melon, prior to face. Definitely watch those great Youtube shaving videos. Will you cut yourself???? In one word......YES.........it's going to happen regardless of how careful you are.......so don't sweat it. The more knowledge you have prior to face shaving the less likely you are sustain serious injury.
  16. I really, really like this razor! Super solid, heavier than I expected, and easy to grip with that gnarled handle. The handle (just above the twist piece at the bottom) actually has the Merkur logo etched into it. A great attention to detail with this razor. Overall, this razor is more than worth the money. As long as you treat this razor like gold, it'll treat you even better!
  17. I plan on buying this same razor for by boys when they turn 18. Love it.
  18. Excellent razor. Saves so you so much money.
  19. Great beginners razor as this was my first safety razor purchase. I'm much happier with the quality if shaves I'm getting now than I have ever been. I'd recommend using this with the Feather brand of blades, especially if you suffer from ingrown hairs like me. This combo buy comes with said razors.
  20. The product arrived quickly and shaves well. It arrived with a chip in the handle and one on the handle cap. I've only owned this product for a week and it's already rusting where the plating chipped off. Very disappointed that a $40 razor is rusting in a week.

  29. Nice razor, I like to use feather blades with mine. I just recently switched from a Mach 5 to this Merkur and a shavette. It is nice to be able to use the same type of blade for both razors.<br /><br />When buying this razor my main concern was which style should I get? The longer handle, the adjustable one or this shorter heavier razor. Well after a bit of research I chose this shorter heavy duty razor. Some people were saying that the longer handle Merkur was hard to maneuver while shaving the face and that it was intended more for shaving legs etcetera. After shaving with this shorter one I would have to agree that some areas on the face would be harder to shave with a longer handle. Such as from the jaw to the neck. This is because of the shaving angle you have to use with this type of razor. The adjustable Merkur razor isn't recommended for anyone new to double edge shaving since it is easier to cut yourself. I would have to agree with this too. I haven't cut myself with this heavy duty one yet, but since the adjustable cuts closer I can see that as being an issue for someone new to this type of shaving. I may eventually upgrade to the adjustable since you can get a closer shave, but for now I am pretty happy with this razor.<br /><br />If you are going to buy feather blades be sure you are buying the Japanese brand and not the knockoff Thailand blades. With the feather blades you just let the razor weight apply the pressure. Some say you shouldn't buy feather blades if you are new to double edge shaving, but I used them as my first blades and haven't cut myself.<br /><br />Not sure if this will work or not but here is the link to the blades I buy for my Merkur and shavette.<br /><br />http://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B004RWTQTS
  30. Very well made, fit & finish flawless, nice weight, very natural feel in the hand. Could not be happier.
  31. Razor works as advertised. No problems.
  32. Awsome. Quality, nuff. Said
  33. Why would anyone buy anything else. Blades are cheap and it gives a great shave
  34. I must start out by saying I am one of those men with a beard that seems to be made of wire and skin that is incredibly sensitive - shaving has never been fun, easy or without issues since I was a teenager. The majority of my life has been spent shaving with those lovely cartridge razors that burn your skin and your wallet leaving you unhappy and with a dread of shaving; something that in today's world is nearly a must in all professional circles.<br /><br />I decided to purchase this razor after 3 weeks of research into wet shaving and in all honesty with much reluctance to try something that held a razor capable of leaving you in need of stitches. In essence this was a \\"last resort\\" in an attempt to get that close shave that lasted more than half a day and didn't leave me feeling uncomfortable.<br /><br />When my razor arrived, I inserted the Merkur blade that comes with the razor, lathered up and began to shave after taking a deep breath and resigning myself to potential nicks and scrapes...I was so wrong in thinking this way. The 34c provided a smooth, comfortable shave with no pulling of my beard, no unpleasant burn after each stroke and surprisingly it was even fun.<br /><br />The 34c is brilliantly designed and the chrome finish and heft make it a pleasure to own and to use. The knurled handle offers plenty of grip, loading the razor is incredibly easy and it feels sturdy and stable in your hand.<br /><br />My very first shave was closer than any I've ever had before and so much more pleasant. My wife is amazed and incredibly happy with my shaves now.<br /><br />If this is your first DE razor you are on the right track. I must offer a bit of advice though: Do not think that the short handle is going to be a burden, this design actually makes it easier to use and to apply the proper technique. Let me repeat that last part, TECHNIQUE, is essential in wet shaving. There is no pivot-head which means you must be aware of and account for the organic curvature of your face and neck. A longer handled razor will only impede your learning, your technique and ultimately affect your shave!<br /><br />Also, if you purchase this razor, start off with the Merkur blade but don't be afraid to try other blades. A multi-pack with an assortment of blades would be a good purchase as well so that you can try out other manufacturers and find the best fit for your skin and beard type. So far, for me, the Merkur blade is wonderful! Don't forget to get a good soap (I use Art of Shaving cream for ease of use) and a good badger brush to lather with. These are essentials to a good wet-shave! You won't be disappointed!<br /><br />There is something to be said for shaving with a DE razor. Most of us today shave without a thought to how much of shaving is tradition as well as necessity. Our fathers and grandfathers and further back passed tradition on as well and many of them shaved with a DE or a straight edge but with the advent of the cartridge razor the tradition has nearly died out. Cartidges take out the need for learning, technique and patience. Shaving with a DE brings back this tradition among men and puts this time-honored right of passage back in our hands. Try a DE, you will get a wonderful shave and possible develop nostalgia for those simpler times when men were proud to be men and life involved reminders of what is meant to be a man in daily life.<br /><br />Pros:<br />Excellent, sturdy design<br />Heft and weight offer a effortless shave<br />DE technique is easy to learn due to the design<br />Blades are cheap! What you pay for replacement cartridges would buy you almost a year supply of DE blades<br />Cleaning is incredibly easy<br />Razor won't clog with hair like cartridges do<br /><br />Cons:<br />Shave time increased for me but only by 5 minutes<br />Shave prep is more extensive but worth it<br />Smaller handle does take time to get used to but as I mentioned it has a purposezor will only impede your learning, your technique and ultimately affect your shave! Also, if you purchase this razor, start off with the Merkur blade but don't be afraid to try other blades. A multi-pack with an assortment of blades would be a good purchase as well so that you can try out other manufacturers and find the best fit for your skin and beard type. So far, for me, the Merkur blade is wonderful! Don't forget to get a good soap (I use Art of Shaving cream for ease of use) and a good badger brush to lather with. These are essentials to a good wet-shave! You won't be disappointed! There is something to be said for shaving with a DE razor. Most of us today shave without a thought to how much of shaving is tradition as well as necessity. Our fathers and grandfathers and further back passed tradition on as well and many of them shaved with a DE or a straight edge but with the advent of the cartridge razor the tradition has nearly died out. Cartidges take out the need for learning, technique and patience. Shaving with a DE brings back this tradition among men and puts this time-honored right of passage back in our hands. Try a DE, you will get a wonderful shave and possible develop nostalgia for those simpler times when men were proud to be men and life involved reminders of what is meant to be a man in daily life. Pros: Excellent, sturdy design Heft and weight offer a effortless shave DE technique is easy to learn due to the design Blades are cheap! What you pay for replacement cartridges would buy you almost a year supply of DE blades Cleaning is incredibly easy Razor won't clog with hair like cartridges do Cons: Shave time increased for me but only by 5 minutes Shave prep is more extensive but worth it Smaller handle does take time to get used to but as I mentioned it has a purpose
  35. I cannot find any flaw with this razor! I really enjoy it and I find the short handle very comfortable maneuver around your face and jawline. I actually enjoy waking up and whipping up my lather and shaving; I can't find a better way to wake up! The product's fit and finish is perfect, not a single flaw that I can find.   36. I got a amazon gift card during a Christmas work party so I bought this razor and which came with a merkur blade. I also got a 30 count of astra blades. And this razor beat the mirco touch one by a landslide. I will post more as I use it
  37. I was very excited to go from the typical double/triple blade razors sold at CVS etc to this Merkur. Spent $80.00 on a quality shave brush and another $50.00 on Proraso products. Sadly, I'm returning everything. This Merkur is not as sharp as the typical Schick razors sold in department stores. I even purchased the blades by Feather which are suppose to be one of the sharpest. I used this razor for 2 weeks shaving in every angle/direction until one day I shaved half of my face with this Merkur and the other half with a Schick Xtreme 3 razor. I noticed that Schick gave me a closer and less irritating shave (using the same number of passes and angles). The Merkur razor looks very nice and shiny but just like my 2 year old BMW - what's the point of having a nice luxury car with a variety of electrical problems. And Proraso products are overrated. Stick menthol into anything and put it on your face and you'll get that same \\"tingling\\" sensation. Point being, I'll stick with what has and still works best for me...Edge can gel and department store razors.
  38. Background I have used everything from the twin blades, 4 blades, disposables, and electrics. I have used foam, gels, and on some occasions just water. Benefits * quick changeover - it takes about 15 seconds to change blades * double sided - that means two shaving passes before hitting the bowl of water * steel - well constructed and feels heavy * cost - upfront cost but the blades are sharp and cheap Should I get the short or long handle? I can tell you that the short feels better in my hand as I have more control and I hold it in the middle. However this is personal preference. If you currently use a quattro, fusion, or disposable, try to remember where the end of the shaft is. If you only hold the razor with 3 fingers (picture chop stix) then you should be fine. If the end of the razor is somehow in you palm when shaving then you may notice the difference. Is it more difficult to use? Just different. Forget about your old style of shaving. Simply let the weight of the razor do the trick. As far as what angle to use, simply start at a 90 degree angle and work your way down (30-45 works for me). It does sideburns with ease and the hair right under your nose is easy to get as well. Rinse after every pass and shave with the grain. What blade do I use? Experiment. Don't just buy the 200 pack and call it a day. Buy a 10 pack for a few bucks and see if it works for you. Do I buy shaving soap and a badger brush? I use the proraso green shaving soap and a badger brush and i haven't even put a dent in it. You should buy both though. The first time you use that soap with your new razor you will think you came out of a barber shop with that smell and close shave How long does it take? Shaving is really a skill and it will take you about 20 minutes the first time and you should be close to your current shave in no time. I'm still undecided, is there even a difference? All I can tell is that I have a much, MUCH closer shave and I smell likea barber shop (although not overpowering at all, my wife can't tell) and shaving old school like my grandpa is just a bonus ;) -Rene N.
  39. 21 year old that has been using disposable razors from Costco since I started shaving. It was always frustrating getting the hair on my chin and under my nose. I saw this as the #1 choice on Lifehacker and ordered it. I just used thee old shaving foam and once I glided this down my cheek, it feel awesome. NO TRACE OF BREAD AT ALL TO THE NAKED EYE!

  41. Good fit and finish for the price. Very much liked the 2-piece construction. Personally, the short handle was not comfortable or convenient for me, but that doesn't mean there is anything intrinsically wrong with the product.

  43. Well, I shave my whole head and have been using cartridge razors for years, they keep making them more expensive to use. At almost $4 per cartridge, it was costing me about a dollar everytime I shaved my head. Someone told me about safety razors, so figured I'd try them. So my first experience with a safety razor was with a Parker 22r that was faulty, it would not secure fully, and chewed my head up. It really made me almost regret jumping on the safety razor train. I returned it and purchased the Merkur 34c, glad I gave safety razors a second chance. This razor although kind've short has a really nice weight and feel. I've only used it with the merkur platnium razor blade that came with it so far. But I didn't even nick my head once, although I did get my neck once or twice. What a great razor (maybe it has something to do with the blade) it doesn't pull when used against the grain. Even when shaving my moustache I got very little irritation, which usually is very sensitive. Now I do have 13 more different types of blades to try out, and find what works best for me, but as of right now I am very happy with my purchase. I would recommend anyone to purchase this razor, if the size is too small for you (probably around 3 1/2\\" tall) they do make a longer handled version. On another note they listed it with 5 free blades, mine came with 1 merkur blade and 10 extra korean made blades.
  44. i usually dont write reviews but i had to for this razor. i have been using the usual mach 3 type razors but wanted something a little different this time. i found great reviews for this razor and decided to buy not knowing anything about straight razors. the trick is to just not put any pressure like we are all used to but to use the weight of the razor to shave. its the closest shave i have ever gotten. i used the provoso soap. the blades it came with did the job, but i will experiment with others as soon as i need them, and replacement blades are CHEAP compared to cartridges. do your self a favor and get this razor and make shaving enjoyable rather than a task of the day.

My primary shaving method before the switch as an electric razor, and while there may be a debate about which is \\"greener\\" there can be no debate about which one performs better and gives you a better shave. This razor wins hands down. It may take a little more time, not much, but it's time well spent.
  49. I am new to DE shaving, but this razor is solid and comes highly recommended by others. Seems solid so far.<br /><br />An important note though: while the listing only promises 5 free DE razor blades, many people in the reviews seem to have gotten feather blades with their product. Feathers might be a bit risky for newbies, but are probably the most popular and perhaps sharpest blade available from what I gather. Unfortunately, my order came with 10 Dorco blades. While I can't fault the seller (no promises having been made), the Dorco blades have been highly unsatisfactory. It has been impossible to get a really close shave with them. I'd rather have gotten no blades for free; I could have ordered some along with my initial order for a couple dollars.<br /><br />So buy this product, but just assume the free blades are a total loss and buy one of the more well regarded blade brands.

They go great with the Merkur! I tried the Micro Touch One with the included Dorco blades before I got this one, and soon realized that although I could tell Double Edge shaving was the way to go- after blowing too much money on Fusion blades- the MicroTouch wasn't a long term keeper.   52. We have been so brainwashed into buying cartridges for razors. At four to five dollars a pop, this was getting out of hand. After researching the web for hours, I decided on this model due to the positive reviews. I'm new to DE shaving and was a little concerned about cutting myself.<br /><br />When the razor arrived, I inserted a blade and proceeded to try it out. I used the canned shaving gel I had and found the shaving experience very nice. I quickly realized that I couldn't drag the razor like I had before with the Gillette fusion. I have to be very light with the pressure. I did cut myself once on the chin when I pressed too hard.<br /><br />Now after using it for a month, I found the shaving experience much better than the Gillette fusion. I can shave up and down, accross, and even against the grain without razor burn. The shave is much closer than the disposable cartridge razor. My face is not dry and flaking in the morning anymore.   53. I have this razor and like it. But since it s the first safety razor I ve used in 25 years, i can t tell you how it compares to others. Since I was hesitant about buying a safety razor after years of using modern razors with multi blade disposables, I am commenting on that aspect. I was driven by the need to spend less on blades, and contribute less into the waste stream, but I didn t know if I d find shaving with it equivalent to my Mach 3. My attitude on shaving is that you need to shave both with and against the grain in a hot, steamy environment, because the goal is a shave so close that you have completely smooth skin. A safety razor will do that, and with much less expense in blades. But since it is somewhat larger and clumsier than a disposable, I still keep my disposable at hand to clean up in and around my lips, nose, ears, and adam s apple. used this way, the Mach 3 s blade will last a very long time, since they are only doing final touch up. I see it in the same way that a groundskeeper might handle a big area: you use the tractor mower to do the large acreages, the little riding mower to do the intermediate work, and the hand-held weed whip to do the detail work: no one machine is perfect for the entire job, but in combination you get the job done quickly and cheaply. I found Wilkinson blades to be sharper than the Merkur blades offered with this razor, and I d like a way to have a friction lock on the knurled know so that I could OPEN up the blade angle slightly without the loosened knob then moving to a completely loose position. Otherwise, the razor seems to work fine.

This razor is heavy enough to do the work for you. Excellent product. I will enjoy this for years to come.
  68. Well constructed and heavy. I wished it had a longer handle however. Overall however it works well.
  69. feels great , solid, smooth well engineered, can't believe it took me so long to stop the insanity of overpriced disposables and ineffective electrics
  70. A great alternative to the modern multi-blade methodology of shaving. This old fashion shaving is getting new life for me. The newer 'Mach 3' style has gotten so expensive in blade replacement and this solves that problem.
  71. Fits the plastic Merkur travel case and gives a great shave with Astra blades. Great shaves.
  72. I've been using a safety razor for a couple of years now. I've tried lots of different ones -- including adjustable and fixed head. This is a fixed head razor and I'd recommend it to anyone, including those new to wet shaving. Though perhaps not as cool as using an adjustable razor, or one with a butterfly opening to load blades, this razor does everything you could ask. I have a lot of other razors that I use from time to time -- including super speeds, adjustables, fat boys and tiny Gillette travel razors -- some more than 50 years old. In my opinion, the older razors work fine but need a really sharp blade to totally get the job done. Despite having all those other razors, more often than not, I use this one. The reason? It's simple and works great. I also know that this razor will work flawlessly for years to come just as it does today. (In fact, I have no doubt that it'll work far longer than just my lifetime.) The Merkur is a more aggressive razor then the old Gillette razors you might purchase on eBay or elsewhere -- but not one that needs to scare someone just starting out. Take your time, get a good badger brush, some high quality shaving soap or shaving cream, and do something you may not have done in years -- enjoy shaving again! Finally, any razor is only as good as it's blade. The Merkur is a very good razor at an extremely reasonable price. When you combine it with good blades -- you have a winning combination. Blades I've used and like include Crystals, Derby Extras, and the pretty much universally recognized sharpest blades made: Feathers. (Fair Warning: unless you're a regular wet shaver, don't start out with Feather blades -- work up to them.) For those accustomed to a long handle, you may want to consider the Merkur long handle razor. For those needing a more aggressive shave, think Merkur slant. Regardless of which razor you choose, once you've purchased it, you'll be ready to start saving money on shaving for the rest of your life. Blades cost just pennies each and within a short time you'll make up the purchase price of your Merkur razor in savings from buying disposable razors or expensive blades. So ditch those disposables and look forward once again to that morning ritual of a close shave. You'll never go back.
  73. This is my first DE safety razor. I really like the chrome finish and weight of the razor. Changing the blades is very easy. At first I was a little concerned about the short handle but I actually really like it. I have smaller hands but can still grip it securely using two or three fingers.
  74. After about a year and a half with wet shaving, I finally moved up to the much praised Merkur 34C. Although happy with Feather, Parker 22, and Utopia, I now have fallen in love with my Merkur!! The three inch short handle really enhances my shaving experience tremendously. I can certainly see why it is the favorite of so many. I would challenge beginners not to be scared of it as I was by the reviews of more senior shavers! Why not begin with this one? You will not be disappointed!
  75. This may be the best double-edge razor I've used in more than five decades of DE shaving. Smooth and efficient, and has excellent in-hand feel. The 34C is an exceptional performer. It delivers a smooth, comfortable, irritation-free shave. Paired mine with an Astra SP blade for an exceptional razor-to-blade pairing.<br /><br />The bulldog handle makes the razor very easy to maneuver; and the razor's head allows for close shaving in under one's nose. I've used many Merkur razors, including the 37C (Slant), Progress, and Futur (extremely aggressive); and the 34C outperforms these razors at delivering a comfortably close shave. One pass and pickups and I'm ready for the day.
  76. One of the most popular razors in the world. Gives a mild but close shave. Well designed and well made. You can purchase this for less than the price of the newest cartridge gadget and five cartridge blades. How about paying 5 cents a week for razors and getting a better shave. You will be handing this to your grandchildren while that cartridge thing will be a shaming a local landfill. Great product.
  77. There's not much to say about this razor that hasn't already been said - it's a great introduction to the world of double-edge shaving, and DE shaving in general is a vastly more pleasant (and cost effective) alternative to cartridge razors. One note on this particular vendor: the razor came with 10 free blades (not 5), Dorco ST-301's. I've been pleased with them; prices for DE blades can vary widely, and the Dorco's are on the cheaper end. I probably would not have tried them if they weren't included with the razor. I can offer a few suggestions to those considering taking the leap: 1) Watch mantic59's videos on youtube. 2) If you're considering a longer razor - the Merkur 180 or barber pole, for example - remember that you shouldn't treat the handle as a \\"handle\\". After receiving the razor (and ignoring mantic's video advice), I grabbed the razor in my fist and promptly removed half of my jaw. You'll be MUCH happier if you force yourself to use fingertips only; the shorter handle encourages this. 3) Slow down. Slow down. Slow down. Short, slow, light strokes cause much less irritation. 4) Never shave any part of your face that hasn't been lathered. This seems obvious, but coming from a Mach 3, I was used to haphazardly touching up stubble without applying additional shaving cream. This isn't a hot idea with a DE razor. Take the extra 10 seconds to re-lather. 5) Consider purchasing an alum block to use after shaving. I'm not sold on the stinging sensation, but it's been a great help in determining which parts of my face I'm using too much pressure on. The Bloc Osma alum block seemed like a good value, and it really does tighten up your skin nicely. Have fun! My complete shaving set consisting of this razor, [[ASIN:B002JW8S6K Bloc Osma Natural Alum Block]], [[ASIN:B000RI8BZQ Proraso Shaving Cream 5.2 oz (147 g)]], and [[ASIN:B002QI45Z0 Edwin Jagger 1ej947sds Traditional English Best Badger Hair Shaving Brush Faux Ivory Medium With Drip Stand, Ivory, Medium]] was right around $100. This is similar to the price of two bulk-packs of Mach 3 refills from Costco, so don't agonize too much. DE is the way to go, and the 34C is a great razor.
  78. I am 35 years old and I used to \\"shave\\" using a electric trimmer because my skin is so sensitive that I couldn't use any blades. When I used a disposable super expensive razor like the Gillette Fusion Proglide, I would get razors burn and as a results many bumps on my neck.Therefore I settled for a electric trimmer because it was the only thing safe for me to use. A couple of weeks ago, I got tired of the way my face look and I dare to try the Merkur Heavy Duty Double Edge Razor #34C after watching a video on youtube about \\"the art of shaving\\". It is truly an art. At first I thought the handle was too small for me but once you try it, your will love it. I was afraid to cut my face but once I tried it, all fears vanished. It is super easy to use. I use it at about 30 degree angle, and I let the weight of the razor to its job. I do three pass on my face (with the grain, against the grain, and side ways) Pay extra attention to how your hairs grow on your neck area, where it matters the most how you cut it.) The upper part of my neck - I shave it down with the grain, but the lower part of my neck - I have to shave it up with the grain. Therefore, if you have the same condition I have and you shave down your neck all the way down - it is wrong and it might get irritated. **Now, I shave every two days, I get no irritation, no razor burns, no bumps on my neck. **Now, I understand, that all you need is this safety razor, the right technique and a good blade. **Products I use: * Shaving oil - Pacific Shaving Company All Natural Shaving Oil: I love this product, I don't know if there are better ones out there, but this product is great, and made in the great U.S.A. Get the 2 oz bottle. * Brush - Escali Badger shaving brush: I like it, it is a good brush for the price. * Shaving Soap - WSP Rustic Shaving Soap 4.2 oz and I also use Stirling Sharp Dressed Man scent - I started with Proraso, but these two brands are amazing. These are made in the U.S.A. The lather builds up quickly, has great cushioning and glide, and the smell is amazing on both soaps. * After Shave - Proraso liquid after shave cream: and this one I do like. It comes with green tea and oatmeal, and I love how it smells and how my face feels after I apply this. I am going to be trying next the Stirling Sharp Dressed Man Aftershave. I really like this company. * Double Edge Safety Razor Blades: (you need to experiment with different blades until you find what works for you) - I used the Astra Platinum Double Edge Safety Razor Blades from Russia- it is a good blade and inexpensive. - I used the Kai Stainless Steel Double Edge Razor Blades from Japan- it is a great blade but expensive. - I used the Personna - Red from Israel - these are better than the Astra blades and double the price. - I am planning to use the Feather Razor Blades Hi-Stainless Double Edge from Japan next and hopefully they will be as good as the reviews claim it to be in order for me to justify its price. I will choose one blade once I try these, regardless of its price. * Stand - I use the Burleigh Chrome Razor and Brush Stand: it cost me $20, and I am supper impressed with this product quality and presentation (the packaging is fantastic) I hope this review helps someone out there that thinks that his skin is super sensitive, because it is probably not.
  79. After reading multiple reviews on the 34C and the long handled version I chose the 34C.<br /><br />This was my first Double Edge Razor (safety razor). I have been shaving with disposable razor heads for over twenty years and they are closer in length to the long handle version. So first couple shaves with this I was very skeptical that I really liked this shorter handle. I watched a couple videos on how to shave with one of these razors and now I am hooked on the shorter/heavy 34C and using double edge blades over disposable head Gillette/Schick ones.<br /><br />The quality is outstanding. If this is your first double edge razor it might take you 3-4 shaves before you get use to the smaller/heavy razor compared to your old one, but i now love it.<br /><br />I bought 100 Astra razors and also a blade sampler. Like everyone mentions the Feather blade is amazing, but if you are new to this type of shaving I would not start off with that one. IT IS SHARP. I started off using the Merkur blade that came with the razor, used some Astra's then tried out the Feather blade once I knew what I was doing.
  80. I'm a relatively new convert to shaving with a double-edge razor, having been brought up on disposable cartridges. My new razor of choice? The Merkur Heavy Duty #34C. This is going to be the last razor I own, and I'll be passing it along to my younger generations. The quality is that good. Not so much a disposable personal care item, as I've always viewed razors before, this is more of a premium quality tool. The details based on my experience:<br /><br />Size: The dimensions of this razor are altogether different from your typical Mach X: The handle is short, the working end (you know, the sharp part) is large in proportion to the handle, and it weighs about as much as a decent size wrench. The dimensions and weight of it complement proper double-edge razor shaving technique as, unlike a Mach X which you rather drag across your face, the weight of the razor provides the oomph behind the actual blade, rather than the force of your stroke. I prefer the shorter handle of this one to longer ones because it allows me to concentrate on proper technique and helps to removes the urge to use a longer handle to lever my way through the shave.<br /><br />Quality: All parts are heavy, all metal, and finely machined. The top of the shaving head that comes off to accommodate the razor blade fits perfectly in its receiver so that the blade maintains the desired profile each and every time you change blades. There is nothing to go wrong here, nothing to break, nothing to fail, unless you really whack it with a hammer or drop it repeatedly from a height onto a hard surface. I can reasonably expect my razor to outlast me...<br /><br />Design: I like that the design is simple and straightforward, and I appreciate its perfect balance. It may not be as cool to load as a 'butterfly' DE razor, and it is not adjustable as some DE razors are. Fewer moving parts should add to durability.<br /><br />Price: For something that may well shave multiple generations of faces, I'd say this is a fair ripper of a value. It's also a nice bonus that, in addition to coming with a Merkur blade, it's also packed with a box of Dorco blades to try. Yours may or may not have this specific brand of blade packed with it, but it is nice to start off with a couple different brands of blades for you to try on your skin; blades do matter, and I would recommend trying several.<br /><br />Lasting Impression: Is this the razor for you? I can say with confidence that this razor is perfect for me, but shaving is such an individual thing: There are so, so many types of skin and beards and preferences. I've heard from many that this is an excellent 'starter' razor for those who make the jump from cartridges and I'd have to agree with that. However, while I think it is a good idea to try various products (and certainly with various brands of replacement blades) I don't feel that this razor is necessarily one you leave behind simply because you started with it. The shave it provides strikes me as middle-of-the-road with regard to aggressiveness, with some being more and some less. It gives me a perfect shave and actually makes me enjoy the task - a first since I began shaving decades ago. No other razor I have found works better for me. Easy, then, to recommend this.a value. It's also a nice bonus that, in addition to coming with a Merkur blade, it's also packed with a box of Dorco blades to try. Yours may or may not have this specific brand of blade packed with it, but it is nice to start off with a couple different brands of blades for you to try on your skin; blades do matter, and I would recommend trying several. Lasting Impression: Is this the razor for you? I can say with confidence that this razor is perfect for me, but shaving is such an individual thing: There are so, so many types of skin and beards and preferences. I've heard from many that this is an excellent 'starter' razor for those who make the jump from cartridges and I'd have to agree with that. However, while I think it is a good idea to try various products (and certainly with various brands of replacement blades) I don't feel that this razor is necessarily one you leave behind simply because you started with it. The shave it provides strikes me as middle-of-the-road with regard to aggressiveness, with some being more and some less. It gives me a perfect shave and actually makes me enjoy the task - a first since I began shaving decades ago. No other razor I have found works better for me. Easy, then, to recommend this.

  84. This is my first double-edge blade razor. I've been using it for a few months now, and love it. I switched from a Gillette Fusion because I got tired of buying the refill cartridges and how much they costed. I've found that I have to shave more frequently, but it doesn't feel like the shaver is tearing off a layer of skin. I also find that I will nick myself more if I'm going too fast. A little dab of a styptic pen and no more blood. I'm glad I made the switch and feel that this razor does a great job. Would recommend it to somebody else.
  85. I purchased this because I have suffered a long time with ingrown hairs and irritation after shaving. I have curly hair that is somewhat coarse, so I am predisposed to having difficulty at times with shaving. I got a job where I needed to shave everyday or every other day for work and since I have to shave more often I wanted to invest in something that would not give me irritation. There are some things that everyone should know about shaving with a safety razor: 1) You can cut yourself easier with this than a disposable razor. However, if you properly learn proper shaving habits, you will greatly reduce the odds of this. Mantic59 on Youtube has excellent videos on how to shave properly. 2) It takes slightly longer to shave. For me this is usually around 10 minutes or so instead of 5 minutes with the Gilette fusion that I used to use. 3) You should invest in a shaving brush (preferably badger hair), a good non alcohol based shaving soap/cream, a styptic pen (if you cut yourself this will effectively sanitize the area and stop the bleeding you can get these really cheap at any drugstore for a couple of dollars). 4) I'd also recommend purchasing a sample pack of double edged blades. After sampling a few of the brands I found that Derby suits me well and is a perfect combination of not being too dull where you will get resistance shaving and not being too sharp where you will cut yourself easily. I found Feather was way too sharp and Merkur was a little dull. Everyone has a different opinion on which to use. When I bought this, I also purchased The Art of Shaving set that included aftershave moisturizer, preshave oil, a badger brush, and shaving cream and it was an excellent shaving set. I have since moved on to using Proraso shaving soap because it is substantially cheaper and has similar results. I still use the moisturizer and preshave oil though, they are both excellent products. I have found that my irritation is substantially reduced and I actually enjoy shaving now and the blades are so cheap that you will quickly recoup your initial investment in cost savings compared to using a Gilette. Good luck!
  86. At 51 yrs old I discovered the wonder of the old classic double-edged (DE) razor. Why did we ever go away from these?? I've always hated shaving. It was always a drudgery and only when absolutely necessary. Ingrown hairs, red rash on my neck, etc from these modern multi-blade razors made it miserable. I tried electric razors for years and that helped quite a bit ref rash and ingrown hairs, I still did get some ingrowns now and then. Plus the electric left rough stubble nearly as bad as a five o'clock shadow.<br /> A few months ago I heard a commercial ref these DE razors and was intrigued. I looked here on Amazon and read hundreds of reviews on these razors. The Merkur 34c really stood out with it's high marks and praise from users. I thought about it awhile and finally decided to try it. I also ordered a $10 boar brush and some shaving soap...<br /> It's been about a month now and let me tell you I honestly now ENJOY shaving each day - I look forward to it! This is something I'd never would have thought could be possible, but it is. The shave is smooth as any cartridge razor and I no longer have issues with rash. Ingrown hairs are fading away also (remnants of my previous shaving method - an electric I'd used the last several years).<br /> Another thing I love about DE shaving is the cost of blades. If bought in bulk packs of 100, they're around 10 cents each!! Yes that's right - 10 cents. Compared to what? $3-$5 each for the 16-blade wonders of today? Forget it. You'll never see me touch another multi-blade disposable or cartridge razor again.<br /> The Merkur 34c is very well made. The fit and finish are excellent. It's hefty and exudes quality when you feel it in hand. It's a &#34;mild&#34; shave as far as razors of this sort go, so you need not worry about bad cuts. A nick or two you may experience the first couple of shaves, but once you get the simple technique down you'll have no issues with cuts at all. I can count on one hand how many nicks I've gotten in the past month if that gives you an idea. They were all minor.<br /> Shaving with a retro DE razor like the 34c is a thrill. It takes you back several decades to a simpler time. When men were men and did manly things! Shaving was one of those things and they had the best tool for the job, a simple and efficient razor that got the job done and did it well. The ritual of whipping up a lather with your shaving brush and applying it to your face. The deliberate strokes of the razor. The splash of cold water to rinse. Then the splash of aftershave... Ahhh yes! It's a pleasant and refreshing experience.in the past month if that gives you an idea. They were all minor.<br /> Shaving with a retro DE razor like the 34c is a thrill. It takes you back several decades to a simpler time. When men were men and did manly things! Shaving was one of those things and they had the best tool for the job, a simple and efficient razor that got the job done and did it well. The ritual of whipping up a lather with your shaving brush and applying it to your face. The deliberate strokes of the razor. The splash of cold water to rinse. Then the splash of aftershave... Ahhh yes! It's a pleasant and refreshing experience.

  110. Just over a decade ago, when an elderly friend passed away, his wife tried to give me his Gillette safety razor body. Being younger and dumber I passed on it but took the mug and brush. Since mug soap seems to last forever, I saved a fortune on shaving, or so I thought. Today I received my first safety razor, the Merkur HD 34C, put the Merkur blade in, cranked it down, and rushed off to shave like I was a kid on Christmas day that had just received a new remote control car. I'd been intentionally neglecting shaving since Amazon emailed me that it had shipped, so I had quite clear cut forest look going on. I was so impatient I didn't even want to wait to lather up the soap, I just put a hot towel on my face for a few seconds and then off and shaving I went. I'd read all the reviews, and knew to just let the weight of this razor do the work. After the first pass I actually checked the mirror to make sure it'd actually shaved me. I can really only describe it as effortless. Within a minute I'd cleaned up my neckline. How could I have been so dumb as to be using disposables and cartridge razors all these years? The cons. If you've never used a safety razor, the weight of this razor is really the only thing I think will take a little adjustment time. I'd compare the weight to about three or four Sacagawea dollar coins. Compared to a disposable it's a rock compared to a feather. The length of the handle, compared to several different disposables I have, is 1.5\\" shorter on average. So if you absolutely need a long handled razor, there are other safety razors you should look at. The pros. Solid construction, feels like I could fight my way out of a corner with it and not only still have a clean shave afterward, but I could pass this down to someone 40 years from now so they could barfight/shave with it as well. The included Merkur blade fits so snug that it took a little maneuvering just to get the blade past the threads (which is a good thing considering the reviews I've seen for other safety razors). It locks down nice and tight. The Merkur blade made shaving effortless. This one comes with 5 extra blades (made by Derby), but I currently have no experience with Derby blades so I can't really review them. Looking around on Amazon, blades cost ~15 cents (if bought by the 100 pack) compared to a cartridge which comes in around $2 a cartridge. So it's also a frugal shave, if that's your thing. Plus it's shiny, and people like shiny objects.
  111. I used this razor yesterday for the first time right after getting it. I was hesitant because of worrying about cutting myself. Well it was very easy to use and gave me the closest most comfortable shave ever-even closer and more comfortable than my Gillette Fusion Power. Also, for the first time I didn't bleed at all after shaving against the grain. I just took my time and it was actually enjoyable. I warn people just to be VERY careful while changing the blade. I didn't cut myself, but I could tell I could dice up my digits pretty good if I got in a hurry.
  112. I had been looking for a classic razor set for a long time, but was not impressed with the Gillette razor sets, with the expensive replacement blades. This was a great razor to start my set, and was easy to learn with. Provides a heavy feel, is easy to clean and replace blades.<br /><br />With a little practice the razor provides the closest, most comfortable shave you will find.
  113. My wife has always had a not-so-subtle dislike of my facial hair, and shortly before Christmas picked up a groupon for an Art of Shaving starter kit (oil, brush, cream, balm). The one thing missing was a higher-end razor to go with it, which her godmother corrected by purchasing me this Merkur razor for Christmas. Since Christmas I have used it about a half-dozen times, shaving about twice a week. I have oily skin on and around my nose, combined with dry, easy-to-cut skin on my throat and chin. I have always had problems with ingrown hairs and in-shave bleeding, as well as bad razor burn thereafter. This razor, using one double-edged blade, has greatly reduced my ingrown hairs, which I understand can happen more frequently with modern cartridge or disposable razors. CONSTRUCTION: solid steel construction. It feels nice in the hand, and blades are easy to change out. It feels like a unit that I could someday give to my son if he wished to have it. SHAVING: when I get done, my face and throat are completely smooth and stay that way for 2-3 days, which even considering my slow beard growth is a good shave. Bear in mind, however, that I go through a 20-30 minute process every time, and it involves in-shower facial exfoliation, hot towels, glycerine shaving soap, brush, pre-shave oil, three razor passes and balm (I normally do this with a little Miles Davis or Coltrane). Also, DO NOT PRESS WITH THIS RAZOR. you have to be patient for at least two passes, and attempting to hurry by pressing down will shred your face. It takes practice and patience, since you have to lather up for each pass. Finally, the razor head can't fit into the spot right under my nostrils- I have to use a thin Gillette blade for that. VALUE: safety razor blades cost much less than any cartridge razors- a pack of 10 ran me $7 at CVS, while a box of fusion proglides can run $30-40. If you are interested in a closer shave, for yourself or the man in your life, I recommend this as a great gift idea.
  114. I am a beginner with a DE razor. I did a little research and found out this is the one, especially for beginners. All I know is it's great for me. Very maneuverable, and leaves my face feeling great. I'm now saying goodbye to razor bumps.
  115. very happy that i ordered this razor. it is very sturdy with a nice finish, something that looks like it will last a lifetime. what i really like about this razor is the knurled handle and the 2 piece design. just twist the nut on the bottom of the handle and the head releases. i like being able to install a blade while holding the handle and not having to hold the head between my fingers. the razor holds the blades straight with an even blade exposure on both sides. i ordered mine from SimplyBeautiful and i am very happy with my order. i also ordered a razor stand from them and couldn't be happier.
  116. I've noticed that most of the longer reviews are more about the experience of shaving than the product itself. That's probably because there really isn't that much you can say about something as simple and perfect as this. It feels just right in the hand, it is very well made, and it gets the job done well. As a first time buyer of a safety razor, I looked at a lot of options, and weighed whether to get the longer handled model or not -- for me, the short handle works perfectly. As many have noted, you shouldn't grip it, so I would imagine a longer handle might actually be detrimental.
  117. When I bought this razor a few months ago I was new to double edge shaving. In fact, I'd always thought my cartridge razor experience was pretty good. Now I know differently.<br /><br />This razor is very well made, and easy to load. I considered getting the long handled version because it was more like what I was used to, but this feels really solid in my hand and I din't want anything different. There definitely is a bit of a learning curve, but the whole process was surprisingly intuitive, especially if you read a blog or two about proper shaving technique.<br /><br />The first time I used the razor, I knew I'd never go back. The closeness of the shave is amazing, my irritation is virtually nil, it is cheaper than cartridges, and it makes you feel like a real man. I highly recommend this razor.
  118. Great shaver! It says it comes with 5 blades but mine came with 11! One sample and 10 treet blades.
  119. I love my DE razor a thousand times more than my old razor. Switching is one of the best decisions I've made recently.
  120. Excellent intro razor into the world of DE shaving. There's something about lathering up a nice bowl of soap and brushing it on the face, following by the smooth strokes that the Merkur provides. It has a very nice feel, not too hefty, not too light. I'm really enjoying how the razor gives such a smooth shave, however, I haven't settled on a razor brand yet (Feather's seem to be leading the pack for now). This product does what its supposed to - give a clean, smooth, old-fashioned shave every time. Highly recommend.
  121. Great razor! High quality steel and finish. Wish I bought a long time ago to save money on razor blades.
  122. After getting sick and tired of buying razors at the grocery store and paying $8 for 4 blades, I opted to go old school. I had done my research, which showed Merkur products were supposed to be great. So, I took the risk and purchased. This razor combined with Merkur's double edged platinum blades is an excellent shave that is far closer and superior to anything I have ever pulled off before. I have switched to the wet shave (shave soap, oil, and badger hair brush) and this blade really does let you get things done right. For new people who are wanting to try this: I shave once a day, every day. I have what I would consider above average facial hair thickness (in terms of actually hair thickness, density, and in growth speed). I, personally, have to use the lubricant oil or this gets to be a bit much for me. Things to remember: the first few shaves you will cut yourself. Get a styptic pencil (which stings like a son of a gun but stops the bleeding on contact) and build in some extra time in your routine until you get this down. It took me a full week to really figure out my face and neck shape/contours, as well as the best angle of attack of the blade itself, to get the best shave. I can get so close that at 4 in the afternoon (after having shaved at 7 in the morning) I still have a damn smooth face and neck. I NEVER had that from the old razors. If you are going back and forth, I would suggest you give this a try. I do not regret this purchase at all. Or the fact that I purchased 50 blades (which seem to last me a little over a week i.e. the same as any major brand blade) for all of $32.50 + S&H. For me, not only is this a financially awesome change up, but the quality is far superior as well. Excellent product.
  123. Exellent Safety Razor recommended
  124. This is my first safety razor and I couldn't be happier. In the long run it will save me money and in the short run it's very gentle on my skin. My skin always felt irritated after shaving with my Mach 3 Turbo, and has never felt like that with this. I looked up some how to videos on YouTube to get started. I shave after my shower and have tried olive oil, only water, and Aveeno lotion as shaving cream (I didn't want to dry my face with soap, or get sucked into buying expensive products for a cost efficient razor). For me, the aveeno lotion works the best, although the olive oil, and only water work real good as well. It will take a couple times to get used to, but is hard to cut yourself with (I haven't got cut yet). I looked into different razors, but wanted to get a quality one, many sites said this was the best. The short handle was easy to convert to.
  125. Nice construction. I would buy the long handled one if I bought again.<br />It does not give you a closer shave.<br />I have a very thick coarse beard and dull out the expensive 3 blade disposables after three shaves and often had cuts and nicks and a sensitive area on the neck would also bleed.<br />It is not as forgiving as a disposable and with this product I am bleeding and cutting myself at least twice as much.<br />I am saving money though.
  126. Since I hate wasting money and using plastic products, I had to find an alternative to the disposable razor or disposable razor head. My father had what I call an old fashion double-sided razor and I remember cutting myself with it as a curious kid so I was scared to try the double edge. After doing research, I decided on heavy double sided razor with the safety feature and a screw down top versus butterfly (read butterfly becomes loose and unsafe). It took a few practice runs on my legs before I hit the bikini zone and wow what a great shave. No cuts, smooth finish or extremely efficient and safe. If it your first time using the razor, I recommend watching a \\"how do use\\" video online. I first I thought I wouldn't like the short handle but it makes easy to maneuver in the groin area. I love my Merkur Heavy Duty Double Edge Razor.
  127. I will never shave with a cartridge ever again! Worth every penny and will last you a lifetime. I picked up some Personna blades to go along with this and it certainly is a great combination. Just buy it already!
  128. I kept wondering why people were singing the praises of the Merkur 34c. Being a Edwin Jagger DE89 kelvin user ithought i had found the perfect razor. I had no idea what the 34c was hiding. The blade gaps and exposure look identical to the DE 89 but in use the Merkur just feels more in control. In trouble areas like under the nose or the sensitive sides of the chin the angles just seem to lock in. It may be what people say, its slightly more aggressive. But with practice aggressive isnt a bad thing. I usually have to go against the grain on my chin and cheeks to get a good shave. To my surprise they were already smooth after a cross grain pass. With the Merkur a 3rd pass is just for clean up.<br />As for design I love the 2 piece approach. There is nothing wrong with the 3 piece razors but i always felt like i could use another finger or two when loading. The Merkur head just balances on a towel ya drop the blade bring over the handle and tighen the base and its done. With my Astra blades there was no need to center the blade it was already there. Will try with personnas in a day or two.<br />Thanks Merkur!<br /><br />Update: Merkur 34c plus personna blades makes against the grain passed unnecessary. One with and one across plus a small touch up on chin and sideburns and I'm on the road.<br /><br />Added thought. As one of those sensitive skin guys with random hair growth south of the Adams apple I finnaly figured out my mistake. Hopefully this will help a few others out there. I had always gotten a little irritation in the area mentioned. The answer was simple. More lather! I would load my brush and never thought of hitting the soap again in later passes resulting in weak watery lather in the touch up 3rd pass. Try relathering on the puck or bowl each pass and that last pass will be as gentle as the first.
  129. Great Razor! I would definitely recommend the purchase of the razor.
  130. I've owned the futur for a few years and although that is a great razor, I found it bulky and couldn't keep from cutting myself a few times every week. It's probably operator error, but it was getting old, man. I almost considered getting some cartridges so I could get a comfortable shave when I was in a rush. I'm glad I purchased the HD. It provides a very comfortable shave. Short length is not an issue for me. I feel very confident that I will not cut myself while using it. This is the perfect everyday razor. It looks great on its stand in my little man corner on the bathroom counter. It is definitely not as close of a shave for me as the futur, but still very good. Pair this with the 1904 open, which gives me a closer shave than the HD, and you have 2 similar razors that feel a bit different and will last a very long time.

  136. Excellent. I own one and bought this as a gift for someone new to shaving.
  137. Unfortunately, I've spent the last 17 years of my life shaving with whatever the local supermarket had to offer. After becoming increasingly frustrated with the cost of the name-brand \\"Super Ultra 16-Blade\\" razor cartridges, the speed with which said razors seem to dull, and the questionable shave quality that even those new razors provide, I decided to do some serious research into finding a \\"proper\\" shaving tool. Most educated opinions pointed to a Merkur safety razor as one of the finest razors money can buy, so I took a chance and ordered the 34C. I purposely didn't shave for a week and a half and sported the \\"bum\\" look while awaiting my new razor. When it finally arrived I promptly fired up a scalding hot shower while visions of the perfect shave danced in my head. The first thing I noticed about the Merkur is how solid it is. This is a professional instrument and makes my 16-blade plastic-clad supermarket razor look like a toy (although it most certainly is not a toy; kids, don't play with razors!). The Merkur's double-edged razors are extremely sharp and the 34C clamps them firmly in place. After shaving the 10-day old wild growth off of my face I can assuredly say that this is the razor I've been looking my entire life. Here's the great thing about this razor: When you you run it over your face (without much pressure applied due to the comfortable weight of the razor) the hair that was once on your face is no longer on your face(!). In addition, it doesn't leave your face a bloody, burned mess. What it does leave behind is ultra-smooth, unmolested skin. I think that is just about everything you could ever want from a razor. It didn't wash my car or make me a batch of Julienne fries, so I was sort-of disappointed about that, but what are you going to do. They really should issue a Merkur razor to young men as they enter puberty. This is an excellent product that is worth every penny. If your current shaving situation leaves you feeling less-than-satisfied as mine did, then you absolutely won't regret picking one of these up.
  138. It is exactly as described. Its a quality unit and has good weight and balance to it. The only drawback to this unit (and to this type of shaving) is that you need about a 30 degree angle on the blade and its impossible to get that under your nose. So I have to get another razor out to get that last little bit of whiskers under the nostrils. Other than that its a great buy!
  139. I have a bad combination as far as shaving is concerned. Which is really dense and thick facial hair with soft and sensitive skin. The first time I shaved with a cartridge razor I ended up with a huge cut on the side of my chin, and I still have the scar from it. Then when my neck line kept getting lower I realized that I was nicking myself in a line across my neck. I found out that my whiskers actually reverse direction half way down the shaving area of my neck. I tried compensating for it using the cartridge razor by flipping it along that line, and the mach 3 kept slicing me open. I experimented with other cartridge brands to no avail. So for a while I gave up on shaving and just trimmed my beard. Then I got back into it.<br /><br />First I tried an electric shaver. I found it irritating without getting close. Times it would yank my hairs out by the follicles and result in ingrowns. I started to lose hope on finding a good shaving method. Then I saw a video of DE shaving, and decided to order this Merkur razor. Since this was kind of a trial I decided not to order a traditional kit and opted to continue using canned cream with extra moisturizer. To my surprise it wasn't nearly as bad as I expected.<br /><br />I loaded this thing up with a Personna (blue box) and got going. Finding the correct angle was a little tricky, but once I got it, it worked awesome. It cut those whiskers off like butter without irritating my face like the cartridge or the electric razor. I barely nicked myself in a few different spots but since it only happened on the across and against passes, I figured I'd just have to change up my routine. The second time using this, I went with two with the grain passes (even on the second it was still cutting some whiskers), and then one across the grain on only my face. The result: nearly BBS shave with no blood or no irritation.<br /><br />My only complaint is that it leaves my face feeling a little tight and dry until I apply my home made aftershave lotion. I'm going to switch to traditional shaving soap or cream with the brush and mug which will improve the experience a lot.<br /><br />A few notes: You can use this thing with pressurized can shaving cream, it works good except it clogs quickly. Instead of bearing down like you would with a cartridge, rinse this thing out. You have to go slower than a cartridge blade, and feel the blade. You want it to barely touch, if you feel too much pressure, pull off, rinse and start where you left off; if you feel it's not even, just turn the handle a little. Whatever you do don't push down on the blade.
  140. First time buying and using a DE Razor. Others have recommended this particular Merkur as one of the best. My experience with saftey razors is limited, but it is a great razor. I used to use Mach 3 (I shave both head and face) but they are getting to expensive. Long term, this is much, much cheaper. You can find razor blades for as little as 10 cents here or on ebay. This does a great job, but there is a learning curve. Go slow and let the weight of the razor do the job. Be patient and in no time you will have as close as a shave as a Mach 3 for less money. Also, use shaving oil - much better than shaving cream (which is bad for the skin).
  141. This is a non aggressive razor. Which is exactly what I was looking for when I started DE shaving 4 months ago. I pair it with a super sharp blade, (Feather) and I get close shaves without carving my face up. The razor is well made and has a simple 2 piece design. Changing a blade is a snap, This is just a great razor and I use it everyday with a 3 pass shave.

  144. Happy i gave up Mach 3s. I was like the many folks out there dulling up mach 3s and then dreading having to pay for new cartridges. It's not that I can't afford them but I just don't think a shave should cost what they want to charge.<br /><br />Not only is it a cheaper method, but the shaves come out a lot better and closer. The only downside is that it takes a little longer to shave and change blades versus mach3.<br /><br />Tips: use the weight of the the Merkur razor to cut your hair - don't apply much force, stretch your skin while shaving, shower or wash your face with warm water prior to shaving (open pores), don't use any chemicals after a shave, just cold water.<br /><br />Also, use feather razors, but they're super sharp, so be careful.
  145. I've been using multi-blade razors for years. Just recently I decided to try a safety razor to save money on blades. Just received my 34c about a week ago. WOW, what a difference! I couldn't be more pleased. Anyone who is thinking of making the switch, it is so worth it. Not just because it will save you money but you'll get a better shave. Be sure to try different blades.   146. I've noticed that this razor has been raved as the best go to razor by wet shavers all across the board. It's a solid simple razor, nicely weighted, grips beautifully, and almost as easy as using a disposable. It may look intimidating but you most likely will not get cut, at the very worst, you'll get razor burn. When you first use it, you'll get a great shave but not as close as you would with a straight razor; I honestly thought that my product was defective as I got closer shaves by slightly loosening the head *Bad Idea!!!* As it turns out, Shaving with a safety razor is all about beard reduction through succeeding passes, not removal. Choosing the right angles will make or break the shave, I go for a 30 degree angle, than I try to get as low of an angle as possible to perform baby face shaves. Be sure to try out various blades to see which one is right for you as they are not all created equal *I just went with Persona since they were pretty cheap but I wished that I did a variety sample blade pack but oh well, they perform nicely anyways.* As you shave more and more, you'll get better shaves as you'll start to have a feel of the right angles. Surly, the only thing that disposables razors like the Mach 3 and Schick Quattro have going for them is that they're able to automatically contour to every pivot of your face; the learning curve of shaving with the 34C or probably any other safety razor depends on the person but it may take you about 8 to 10 shaves to start getting baby faced smoothness. However, when you consider that it's all metal, the blades are easily changeable, easily recyclable, much cheaper, you'll be getting a straight razor close shave without the headache of stropping, servicing, oiling, and honing. Blades are usually dirt cheap even for high quality ones. As I shave about three days a week, changing the blade after three shaves, a set of 100 persona blades could easily last me two yeras!!! Sharpening is just as easy as unscrew, pop off, insert, and tighten. This is a very good buy!!! It'll save you time, hassle, and money. This is coming from a person who use to use a Dovo Best Quality Straight Razor; straight razors give fantastic shaves *quite possibly the best* but you'll need the time, patience, and skill for maintenance and upkeep; it's also more expensive up front as you'll have to buy a strop, stones, oil, etc. You'll also have to become an expert in knife sharpening, otherwise, you'll have to send your blade to get serviced. When my safety razor dulled up due to poor stropping technique, I used a Dovo Shavette with interchangeable straight razor blades, it gave baby face shaves but it was dangerous and made shaving feel like a deliberate chore; changing blades was also cumbersome. With the 34C however, I'm so eager to shave everyday!!! I'll still go back to Straight Razor shaving but I'm only doing it for novelty sake to be frankly honest. In my opinion, this should be the modern way to shave., and tighten. This is a very good buy!!! It'll save you time, hassle, and money. This is coming from a person who use to use a Dovo Best Quality Straight Razor; straight razors give fantastic shaves *quite possibly the best* but you'll need the time, patience, and skill for maintenance and upkeep; it's also more expensive up front as you'll have to buy a strop, stones, oil, etc. You'll also have to become an expert in knife sharpening, otherwise, you'll have to send your blade to get serviced. When my safety razor dulled up due to poor stropping technique, I used a Dovo Shavette with interchangeable straight razor blades, it gave baby face shaves but it was dangerous and made shaving feel like a deliberate chore; changing blades was also cumbersome. With the 34C however, I'm so eager to shave everyday!!! I'll still go back to Straight Razor shaving but I'm only doing it for novelty sake to be frankly honest. In my opinion, this should be the modern way to shave.
