  148. excellent shave and easy to learn the correct form. I will never go back to using cartridges. my in grown hairs and bumps have all disappeared, and this shaves with no effort. (pushing is bad) just let the weight of this razor do its job.
  149. I get a real close shave with the Merkur Heavy Duty Double Edge Razor #34C. I first I cut myself, but after a few shaves I got the hang of it. Its comfortable and my skin & face look great. Its easy to clean and change blades. The ladies notice the difference about my face. Thank you Merkur!
  150. A little disappointed in that stem is not as long as I would prefer, but well built and has a little heft to it as I prefer this type of razor.
  151. This is NOT your grandpa's razor - but he wishes it was. Like many men, I get ingrown hairs on my face when shaving with the typical 2-10 blade trendy razors you see on commercials. Sure, you get a close shave with those expensive cartridge-based deals, but you're scraping a couple layers of skin off and getting bumps the next day, which when you shave them, bleed. Maybe not everyone has this problem, but I sure hate it. Enter safety razors, stage right. Ever since switching a few years ago, I cringe at the thought of going back. In general, these will give a close shave, at an incredible price (pennies for a blade replacement if you buy the \\"Sharp\\" brand - my favorite), and precision typically found in the straight razor. For the genre, you can't go wrong with Merkur - solid construction, exact-fitting parts that keep a tight fit throughout its life. Some people go with the \\"butterfly\\" opening, but I find the mechanics of that style get gummed up with soap and hard-water sediments. This razor does not have that problem, as it comes apart into two pieces - the handle, with a non-removable threaded nut at the bottom, and the highly-polished top part which secures and angles the blade, attached to a long bolt that fits down into the handle to be screwed down. That nut at the bottom is what makes this one stand out among some of the others - it allows for easy disassembly, safe removal/replacement of the blade and maintains a solid feel to the whole razor. The short overall length is something you might have to get used to, but is perfectly balanced to allow you to shave with minimal pressure. I love the portability this size provides. Overall, one of the best purchases I've ever made.
  152. Like you could go wrong with the benchmark of DE razors (in my book at least). Superior build quality (actually I feel a little better than my Futur at twice the price). Excellent razor for beginners and pros alike. Close shave, and über forgiving (even with a Feather in it) in case you get a like sloppy, or rushed! My go-to razor when I'm trying anything new (blades, creams, soaps, etc....) because it's that consistent. Never a variable. Killer price for a razor that should be in any wet shavers arsenal.
  153. The classic. I can't recommend this highly enough. I would give it a couple more stars if I were able.<br /><br />Mild shave with a great two piece design. Very heavy but well balanced.
  154. If you're using a Mach 3, Quattro, Fusion, you're probably a sucker. You bought into the advertisements and price war just like they wanted you to. Are you upset? I would be. It's ok, I was a sucker too. There's an old expression: if it ain't broke, don't fix it. That goes for razors. Too many blades does nothing more than drive up your monthly expenses.<br /><br />So I ponied up and invested in this Merkur. Freakin' old school. This is not a shaver, this is a tool, to be respected and cared for. Honestly, the transition to Shaving The Right Way with this Merkur was easy. No nicks or cuts, just take your time and apply less pound-force (Telling people to apply less 'pressure' is a misnomer: the pressure is the same, but we are working with less blade area, so it is the force that matters as Pressure=Force/Area) - the weight of the razor will do the work. The shave is better and the blades last longer and are dirt cheap to replace.<br /><br />I will note, however, that TSA isn't quite as fond of the device as myself. They will make you dispose of the safety blades before entering an airport terminal.<br /><br />Cheers,
  155. An awesome razor, exceeded my expectations!
  156. Only giving this one star for visibility, because I want others like me to know what they're buying when they get a safety razor, especially those with thick coarse facial hair. After getting tired of spending a fortune on cartridge razors which give sub-par shaves I decided to get a safety razor, and this decision was based on numerous reviews that these things will give you the best shave of your life with little risk of cutting yourself.<br /><br />So I loaded it up, got nice and lathered and began shaving. I made one pass and some hairs were shaved off, but a lot remained. So I made a second pass, more hairs removed but many still remained. I'm thinking at this point that something is wrong with the razor, my technique, the blade itself. I made several passes over the same area to remove all the hairs. After all was said and done there remained random hairs sticking out where I had just shaved with this thing, so I googled tutorials on how you're supposed to shave with this thing. Turns out making numerous passes is normal with these types of razors, and that re-lathering & re-shaving is something you're supposed to do. It's also recommended to go against the grain, which I never do as in-grown hairs are a nightmare.<br /><br />A safety razor is the same as a cartridge razor but with only one blade.Then I realized there's a reason the multi-blade cartridge razors were invented, because men got tired of having to make several passes to shave their faces clean.<br /><br />If you want my advice on how to get the absolute best shave? Get a straight razor and learn to use it. You'll never look back, I know I haven't.<br /><br />I should note that this razor I'm reviewing was in great condition, beautiful finish, and nice and weighty. Overall a fantastic razor, if you like using safety razors.
  157. I like the smooth clean shave this provides. The handle is shorter than i expected. It is easy to clean and i really like it.
  158. Nice to get back to the older style!👍🏾
  159. The best razer ive ever used.no nicks!!!
  160. After shaving for years with a conventional \\"multi-blade\\" razor, I was becoming increasingly frustrated. Shaving has always been unpleasant and I avoided it when ever possible. Moving into a new job that required me to stay much more clean shaven meant having to having to suffer through it even more frequently, which was something I was not looking forward to. Enter the traditional wet shave. Proper technique with a good lather and safety razor has given me consistently smooth, clean shaves (my wife approves greatly of them) without the constant irritation and shaving bumps. The Merkur safety razor is an excellent razor for anyone wanting to get started with more traditional shaving. It has a very solid feel and good weight, and paired with a good razor blade (there are many to choose from, so find one that works for you) results in a very satisfying shaving experience.

  165. Find yourself good blades and never look back
  166. This is a great razor. Just a hunk of metal with three parts. Reliable, nicely weighted, does the job. Classic. The razor leaves a large space open between the blade and the guard bar so that this razor never gets clogged and is always easy to clean by just running water over it or shaking it under water.<br /><br />Why did I knock off a star? Workmanship. The design is flawless but the production is not. My razor was over machined, and the top part isn't square and curves toward the edge. It doesn't seems to be enough to affect the quality of the shave, but when paying this much for a razor, I think it should be built right.<br /><br />One thing to watch out for: when I last looked this up on Amazon, the folks who have this listed at the #34C charge $50 but the people listing this as the 178 charge around $32, shipping inclusive! They are the same thing; #34C is Merkur's designation, 178 is the designation by the American company that imports and distributes them. So, just pick the one with the cheaper price and buy from a reputable seller. Knock-offs abound these days and I would think a razor like this would be a ripe target.
  167. This is an amazing razor and my purchase of it completes a journey back to using a DE razor. I once had an old DE razor that belonged to my grandfather, but eventually followed the big razor companies as they added 2 and 3 blades. I have been frustrated with the 2 giant razor companies' prices for many years, and the continual addition of more blades seemed ridiculous to me, especially when the companies discontinued their old models, which worked as well or better than the new ones. When the price of new cartridges became almost equal to the price of this highly recommended razor, I bought one, about 6 months ago. It has been great, especially when using a brush, Proraso shaving cream, and Feather blades. The shave is as close as any shave I have ever had with only two tiny nicks in 6 months. Get rid of whatever 4 and 5 blade nonsense you have and buy this quality tool. There's no school like the old school

  190. You realize that when you first pick it up. It's heavy. It's machined to hold the blade square to the rest of the razor. It has no frills, just function. Having decided to go the double edge route I researched to find the best 'starter' razor that would last and perform without fail. I found it. This razor has a substantial presence in the hand. It's weight and balance make it ideal for gliding down my face with no pressure needed from me. It's simple construction makes it durable and reliable. Although it is not adjustable this 'feature' actually promotes good technique. Once you learn the correct angle it becomes intuitive. I have used disposable razors for 40 years and will not go back. I get a much better shave, less irritation, and I'm spending a lot less on blades compared to the other 'systems' out there. A slight learning curve and a little practice will free you from the outrageous expense of disposables, and with better results! The Merkur Heavy Duty (34C) is a great place to start your education and your liberation!

  196. I have been using #34C for almost two months, and I find it very easy to maneuver on my face. I can grow a full beard with sideburns, and the weight of the blade alone can shave off hairs with no tugging or any unpleasant feelings. As long as you are not applying extra force, it is unlikely that you will cut yourself.<br /><br />In terms of durability, I think I did an okay job. I always take the blade out after shave, and place both the blade and the razor handle on a folded paper towel, That way, you can keep your razor handle and blades dry, preventing razor from getting rusty.<br /><br />The razor is in two pieces. To put on the blade, you simply slide the blade under the outer cover of the razor, and then fasten the handle to its cover by twisting the bottom of the razor. The tighter you twist, the more likely you can break the handle (just like when you put too much force to tighten a screw, and it screws up the thread). Other than that, it is a perfect little handle that shall last you for ages.
  197. I ran out of my supply of Gilette Mach-3 cartridges and realized that their prices have jumped yet again. While the actual price is about the same as the price of a moderately expensive drink @ Starbucks I still do not think it is anywhere close to reasonable and decided to investigate other alternatives. This razor is very solidly made and a pleasure to use even though I personally prefer the handle to be a bit longer like [[ASIN:B000NL0T1G Merkur Model 180 Long Handled Safety Razor]]. I am using it with my regular shaving Gel after a hot shower and it works fine but you do need to be more careful compared to the normal cartridge razors to not nick yourself. If you are going to purchase this and stop giving in to the Gilette rip-off I highly recommend investing in a styptic pencil to take care of the inevitable nicks and small cuts (esp. if you are careless or try to shave in a hurry) [[ASIN:B00112WRB6 Pinaud Styptic Pencil 0.25 oz pencil]]. The package says it comes with 5 blades while in reality it has 6 blades (5 [[ASIN:B001G5FOLI 10 Feather Razor Blades NEW Hi-stainless Double Edge]]and 1 [[ASIN:B000NCMMBA Merkur Double Edge Safety Razor Blades- 3 Pack of 10 Blades]]). I have used both the blades so far. While the Feather blades are sharper (more nicks) but the Merkur blade is fantastic and lasted me about 10 days without any issues. Your mileage may vary based on personal preference and skin type. My cartridge cost has gone down from $4.00 a month to $1.50 a month and I am getting a smoother shave with a new blade every 10 day. Your savings might be higher or lower depending on how often you change your blades. I highly recommend this if you are tired of cartridge systems and are willing to spend 1 minute more every day shaving (due to the fact that you need to be more careful).

  199. I've used this razor for shaving in the \\"bikini line\\" so they call it.Being a teen(guy) with somewhat sensitive skin, this provided a very quick shave.Even though hair down there is much thicker than the beard or any other area of the body, this single blade trimmed it down quickly.Its highly recommended to use good shaving soap(Proraso sapone)and a prep before the shave to prevent ingrown hairs/razor burn.<br /><br />Regardless of people saying they got horrible nicks and cuts, I began shaving first try no cuts(small whiskers on beard), and really got the hang of it the second time in the \\"bikini area\\" without loosing a golf ball.One thing I will say, you need to constantly use soap/lather!Every time your cutting hair(if hair is about 1/2 inch), you WILL need to rinse your blade, which will lead to soap removal.{This is normal, but for the region we are working in this will be enforced a bit more}.Saying so, go to the shower and have about 2 hours extra of time before you do any activities.Start by trimming hair with scissors as short as possible.Apply some soap, let it sit for about a minute(if you got time, do 5) reapply soap and then begin shaving with a small stream of water turned on to remove hair from the razor.Afterwards,take a shower and pat dry, apply a thin layer of neosporin/triple antibiotic and let it adsorb meanwhile you dry everything else.After that, apply something like Aveeno or a natural cream that doesn't have a strong fragrance or alcohol(I just used Lubriderm daily moisture) and let that soak in(if you have a non-alcoholic after shave,its the time to use it).Finally,put something on that's loose(boxers,soft panties) and made of cotton to prevent irritation.<br /><br />Everybody is different, but give it a try if you have tried shaving and you always end up with razor burn or just started shaving.Who knows, this strategy just might work for you.Thanks for reading :)<br /><br />Blade type: Merkur sample blade

  203. This is my 1st DE razor so I have nothing to compare it to, but so far its been great. Bought a pack to 100 razors for about $10.
  204. Ultimate beginners razor and blade. If your new to wet shaving, this is the way to start of. Good quality and craftsmanship at an awesome deal! The art of shaving version cost $60-$80 without the blades. Def your money's worth. The perforated handle provides good grip even when your hands are wet and soapy from the shaving cream.<br /><br />As far as using the razor, there is a learning curve to it. Shave at 30 degree angle and remember you move your arm as your wrist is locked in place. Think of your face as different planes and shave them: .5 inch to an inch of each plane. Remember it is a double edge so use the other side of the blade as well. Also you can't shave a beard in one pass with this razor. Depending on your beard type it might take 3-4 passes. Don't be afraid to re lather. The merkur blades are good for about 3-4 shaves. I change my every 1 to 1/2 weeks, depending on how many times you shave in a week. TAKE YOUR TIME! In no time you will be enjoying and looking forward to your next wet shave.
  205. i bought this as a gift for my hubby. he has very thick facial hair and he absolutely loves it.
  206. I fully recommend this razor for either the beginner or experienced DE razor user. The razor is sturdy, beautifully chromed, and has a nice hefty weight. The short handle doesn't bother me at all. It feels secure and well anchored in my hand. As with any DE razor, preparation is key. Best to shave right after a shower, use some pre-shave lotion or oil--Proraso or Art of Shaving makes some great products. Even Noxema is a good option. Work up a lather using a bar or shave cream and apply with a boar bristle or silvertip badger brush. Learn how to shave with the grain of the hair on your face and then across the grain. Only on rare occasions will you need to go against the grain. Rinse off, use an alum bar or apply your favorite lotion or aftershave. Baby face smooth.
  207. Sturdy build,comfortable and non slip grip.perfect curves of razor plate for every corner of face. It's not the most beautiful thing on planet but it is definitely not ugly.
  208. The weight is substantial without being heavy. The handle is length provides balance and dexterity. The knurling on the handle provides excellent grip. The simplicity of the two piece design is unparalleled. This razor can give you a squeaky clean shave. Moist, squeaky clean skin can become tacky. The combed edge will not adhere to squeaky clean skin. The smooth edge can, and will cause the razor jump or skid, resulting in a knick. To avoid this: 1...angle the razor accordingly. 2...use shaving oil, 2 fl oz will last 3-6 months (3-5 drops per application is enough). I use tea tree oil, which doubles as an antiseptic aftershave and moisturizer. It can be purchased` here on Amazon for about $3 (but it is not in the \\"pre shaving oils\\" department). ...... I started wet-shaving after my curly beard became too coarse for my electric foil razor. After years of wet shaving with the modern multi-blade razors, I hated shaving. Less than 1 day between shaves resulted in razor rash that would not go away for about 3 days. More than 1 day between shaves resulted in snagging and cutting. I always had razor burn and some degree of razor rash. Since switching to DE Shaving: I no longer have razor rash. I can shave twice every day with no skin irritation if I want to. My alcohol based aftershave does not burn (unless I let the blade get too dull). I no longer have ingrown hairs constantly. I can work and sweat in the summer heat without my neck and face stinging. ...... All DE blades are not equal, and your mileage may vary. Get a variety pack and try out a few different blades.

  218. Edit 9/9/2014 ... It's been a year and I still love this product! I can go a week without shaving and this thing will shave like it's the next day. The wiskers just flow behing the razor and out without clogging up. And the thing still looks beautiful after a year, like the day I received it. I still like the shorter handle. I've found that the trick is to use as soft a pressure as possible. Get a good blade, the sharpest you can find, and let it do the work. A short handle gives very nice control. There are so many good things about this razor and the quality of the manufacturer. What a refreshing thing to find these days! One thing that I've learned is that the lotion is critically important. Any razor can only be as good as the lotion. So choose a good one.<br /><br />----<br /><br />It's beautiful and I'm glad that I bought it.<br /><br />I've been shaving with electric razors for 20 years.<br />I have a tough beard.<br /><br />WITH ELECTRIC<br />It took me 5 minutes to shave electric.<br />Frustrating due to missed hairs. Many passes needed.<br />Sometimes one little hair would have to be passed over 10 times.<br />My face would look red and blotchy for an hour.<br />If I went a couple days without shaving it was worse.<br />Sometimes I'd go many days because I hated shaving.<br />I tried many electric razors.<br />They started out mediocre and went to worse as they wore out.<br />Get a ok close shave to start, a month later it is not close.<br />Hairs get pulled out, ouch. Ingrown later, ouch.<br /><br />MY STORY<br />Started looking to buy a new electric razor for another $200.<br />Happened upon the Merkur #34C<br />It was intruiguing.<br />Bought it cause wanted something different. $50 instead of $200. No brainer.<br /><br />THE RESULT<br />I LOVE shaving with this thing.<br />Got some Personna and Feather blades and some good gel shaving cream.<br />The Feathers tug a little bit less, maybe. Hard to tell a difference.<br />Have nicked myself twice, little, like poked with a pencil. No big deal. I pressed way too hard cause habit shaving with electric.<br />Secret to not getting nicked is don't press hard.<br />Also use a sharp blade.<br />Better blades keep blade from tugging.<br />The blade is positioned perfectly to not nick, no worries.<br />Let the blade do the work.<br />Secret is use a medium pressure or light pressure.<br />Number of passes hardly matters.<br />Just use light pressure. Good blade takes hair off like it's just wiping off a layer of dust!<br /><br />COMPARISON TO ELECTRIC<br />Time to shave is still only 5 minutes.<br />No blotchy red face, can visit client imediately.<br />No pain.<br />Much closer shave.<br />No pulled hairs.<br />No ingrown hairs.<br />Every new blade is like a new razor.<br />Extremely inexpensive, unless you are destitute (but you probably don't shave anyway).<br />No frustration.<br />Takes up very little space and looks nice sitting on counter.<br /><br />CONCLUSION<br />Love it.<br />Very happy.t to not getting nicked is don't press hard. Also use a sharp blade. Better blades keep blade from tugging. The blade is positioned perfectly to not nick, no worries. Let the blade do the work. Secret is use a medium pressure or light pressure. Number of passes hardly matters. Just use light pressure. Good blade takes hair off like it's just wiping off a layer of dust! COMPARISON TO ELECTRIC Time to shave is still only 5 minutes. No blotchy red face, can visit client imediately. No pain. Much closer shave. No pulled hairs. No ingrown hairs. Every new blade is like a new razor. Extremely inexpensive, unless you are destitute (but you probably don't shave anyway). No frustration. Takes up very little space and looks nice sitting on counter. CONCLUSION Love it. Very happy.

  227. I've always heard about the benefits of shaving with a double edge razor; so i decided to buy this one as soon as my $30 batch of Gillette blades ran out. From a cost perspective, I stand to save money because the blade refills are bout $5 for 10; far less than what I was using before. The razor and shaving experience is quite different than what I had been accustomed to. Not that it was a bad thing. But there was a short learning curve I had to get over (and a week or so of cutting my face up). The razor itself is shorter than the standard stuff you see at your local CVS pharmacy. You get used to that too. As soon as you master the shaving method, you will be quite pleased with the results. I suggest coupling it with a higher quality shave cream.
  228. This is the 2nd double edge safety razor I've purchased. My first was a Weishi razor purchased on eBay. I loved how protective it was but the butterfly-style blade mechanism started to seize up. When I got tired of using a pliers to open my razor, I decided to switch to a trusted brand. This 2-piece Merkur is much more dependable. It did, of course, take a few days to adjust to the new razor. The weight, blade angle, and aggressiveness were different than my previous razor, but I'm very happy with the product. There is a slightly larger gap between the blade and safety rail, which allows the user to get a little closer but requires more precision. For the record, I have eczema (not on my face, but the sensitivity of my face is clearly apparent), and I don't have a water softener. I currently filter the hard water before use, which is a less than stellar substitute for soft water. Because of this, I notice a few more nicks than the average user (or than I did with the Weishi), but when I get a chance to shave in soft water, the improvement is significant. For that reason, I think this product deserves the 5-star rating. The blade you choose is also important, but it is unique to each user. Take recommendations with a grain of salt and shop around until you're happy. I, personally, did not enjoy the Merkur blade included, and I have not yet tried the Feather blades that came with it. I'll wait until we move to a soft water home to judge what is supposedly the sharpest blade on the market. I prefer Derby Extra, mostly for the price in comparison to the others. The Dorco that came with my first razor also seemed rather forgiving, but I haven't tried another one since. Best of luck to those of you searching for your perfect combination!
  229. Thanks to everyone who had already posted reviews on this. I received mine this week and thanks to the videos on YouTube, have shaved twice with not one nick. It is a great beginner's razor. Look no further, it is great. I will update later on if the chrome peeling others have experienced happens to me
  230. EXCELLENT RAZOR AND VERY EFFECTIVE! NOT MILD BUT NOT AGGRESSIVE, JUST IN THE MIDDLE. HANDLE IS SMALL BUT IT IS STILL VERY EFFECTIVE AND EASY TO USE WITH MY VERY LARGE HANDS. VERY HAPPY AND HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS RAZOR FOR BEGINNERS AND PRO'S ALIKE!
  231. I had been using a Gillette Fusion razor for about 4 years before switching to this safety razor, and I am extremely happy with the choice. It is my first safety razor, and I can't imagine switching back anytime soon. Razor I love the design of this razor. It is very classic, looks great in my bathroom, and feels great in my hand when I shave. The bottom of the razor unscrews so that the blade can be changed, and the stainless steel gives it a very solid feel that makes you think that this razor will be the last one I will every need to buy. BTW, it is a pretty small razor--can fit easily in the palm of my hand--which I see as a benefit for travelling, but that might make some want to get the long handled version. Blade There were actually 10 blades included in my order, even though it said 5 free blades. I am not sure how often to change the blades, but I remembered reading somewhere that if the blade feels like it is skipping over your skin or getting caught on hairs, it is probably time to put a new blade in. Since I don't need to have a clean shaven face for work, I've been shaving about 4-5 times per month, and changing the blade at the end of each month. The razor case is great because you can just slide the used blade into the underside of the small case that the blades came in and then you toss them out when you're done. In terms of blade quality, the standard ones that came with the razor work fine for me. I'm sure there are other types of blades, and look forward to trying those out in the future. Shave The shave was great. It was much easier than I thought it would be. As long as you let the weight of the razor do the shaving, then you should have any issues. I did purchase a badger brush to lather my face, and I make sure to shave after I shower so the hair is as soft as possible. Much like getting a straight edge shave, the shave did not seem as close as I thought it should be, however, it seems to take longer for my facial hair to grow back. Furthermore, ingrown hairs and razor burn is non-existant. Not that it was a huge problem before, but I would always get one or two when using the Fusion. Overall I'm really happy with this purchase. Considering blades are something like 10 cents, I don't think it will take that long to realize the savings of ditching cartridges. The shave is great, and is more of an enjoyable experience than it was with the Fusion. Getting the razor has changed shaving all together for me, and I think of it as more of a relaxing and enjoyable experience than before. I don't think I'll try to move onto straight edge razors as this is as good as a shave as I could ask for. Regardless of whether or not you choose this safety razor, definitely make the switch. You won't regret it.
  232. I didn't buy my 34c from Amazon, rather a local store that sells razors and the sort. I just have to review it for those that are thinking about picking this little razor up. I have the Merkur 38c and love it! It has a longer handle and a bit more heft to it. Which makes it a little more aggressive than the 34c. This razor is great for beginners and pros alike! It shaves great, feels good in the hand and works great whether your clean shaving, maintaining neat lines of your goatee or mustache or keeping the neckline neat on your beard..this razor does it all! Great grip, decent heft, nice feel! 5 stars for sure! The only thing you should be doing right now is ask yourself why you haven't bought this yet!!

  234. Okay, it's been awhile now. Almost a year. I have learned a few things and don't plan on ever going back to a modern razor. I am a safety razor guy, now. And I like it. I bought the long handle, which I enjoy. I like that it feels substantial. It came with a Merkur blade. I then tried Feathers. Then Derby. I came back to using the Merkur. Maybe not a super sharp as Feathers, but I like how smooth they are. I never feel like I have ripped up my face. I wouldn't recommend the Derby's. Too harsh for my taste. The number one thing that seems to help is the shaving soap, cream. Make sure you have a good one and almost any shave will be luxurious. Sadly, even a normal blade feels better and closer with the right soap. I have tried a few. Proraso, Tom's of Maine, Regular. Tom's of Maine was natural and the best for me, but was discontinued. Proraso stings. Too chemically for me. So now I am looking for the right soap again. But at least I found my razor. This one.

It takes about the same amount of time and I very rarely nick myself. My skin feels healthier and I get less pimples. No looking back now!

  244. I was becoming increasingly dissatisfied with the quality of shave I was getting from the multi-blade shavers. And electrics never quite cut it (pardon the pun), although they could be convenient in a pinch. I find I get a closer shave with this razor, and I've yet to nick myself.<br /><br />What I didn't expect is that shaving somehow seems &#34;cool&#34; now. The process of opening a jar of shaving cream (mine is sandalwood, which is quite pleasant), brushing it on and creating a lather, then letting the blade do all the work cutting my beard is just a nice way to start the day.<br /><br />By the way, I chose this particular model because a lot of people have mentioned that it's a good way to start with a &#34;safety&#34; (or double-edge, DE) razor. I wouldn't disagree with them. Although someday I might get a model that provides a more aggressive shave (after I develop more skill using it), this razor is fine for me right now - and likely for the foreseeable future.

  256. This is my first double edge razor. I've been using various cartridge razors my whole adult life. My current cartridge razor was the Gillette Fusion. I always had a hard time buying new blades for the Fusion. I mean, sometime like $30 for 8 blades is simply ridiculous. So, I wouldn't shave very often to try to save money.<br /><br /> So, I searched for a cheaper solution and discovered the world of safety razors (also known as double edge razors). I bought this Merkur razor based on my research and now I can buy 100 double edge blades for as little as $10. Whereas 100 Fusion blades would be something like $375! What a difference!<br /><br />I was a bit worried about switching to a safety razor as I wasn't sure if I'd end up with all kinds of nicks. But, I've been using this for a month or so now and I must say, I love it! It's a tad bit slower going as I'm being more careful than I would be with a cartridge razor, but the results are much better and I've only caused two tiny nicks. I probably actually nicked myself worse with the Fusion blades as I'd use the blades probably longer than I should because they were so expensive. With the cheap double edge blades, I don't feel bad switching to new blades after 2 or 3 shaves with each edge of the blade.<br /><br />Overall, I'm very happy with this razor and I think more men need to reconsider using cartridge razors and try a safety razor!

  258. It's short and heavy and that's what I love about it. It looks like a tool you would keep in your tool kit. Just rinse it well when your done with and let it air dry. I will occasionally put put a little oil on the threads over the weekend (I don't shave but during the work week) just to keep them healthy. It does take some getting used to using one of these safety razors but once you get the hang of it and find a blade you like you will wonder why you didn't switch sooner. As far as a shaving soap or cream, some folks will say you need to buy fancy brushes and soap. Save you some cash and just stick with your favorite canned cream. You get a good shave from these safety razors by learning how to use one, not the soap you put on your face.

  262. Like most of you, I've grown tired of constantly purchasing Gillette safety razors year after year. I thought each update of their razor would bring a better shaving experience. Perhaps. But still the razor blades would dull faster than you can afford to replace. I've been a Proglide user for years. Last year I was given a free Proglide Flexball. It didn't offer a revolutionary shaving experience. And the next catch of course is to continuously purchase the cartridges.<br /><br />So when my cartridges ran out I refused to purchase another set. Then I came across users of old-school razors.<br /><br />Then I thought to myself, if I were to make the switch and since the cheap blades will pay for the actual razor over time I might as well purchase a more expensive Merkur. So I looked at the Merkur Vision and Futur line. Especially the gold ones. I read the reviews and they all liked it because it was a Merkur not to mention the modern styling. But the complaints looked valid. The fatigue on the metal. The ability to change blades. The question it will last long.<br /><br />And that's how I ended up with the Merkur Heavy Duty Double Edge Razor 34C.<br /><br />PROS:<br />1. Perfect weight. As the others have stated, you let the weight of the razor work for you rather than use it to press against your skin.<br />2. Great size. The short handle for beginners like myself allow greater control over the razor.<br />3. Awesome construction. All metal. I want to pass this on to my son not for being a cheapskate, but for sentimental value. I will teach him to shave with this razor.<br />4. Easy blade handling. It's not as easy as the butterfly opening of other razors, but the two piece construction allows the blade to be grasped and changed safely. No balancing of the blades or mis-alignment as the blade will sit securely on the top part and you can just drop the whole handle on it with the centre guide. After which you screw it back on.<br />5. Simple. No complicated adjustments to allow any metal to stress and break.<br /><br />CONS:<br />1. The included Merkur blade to get you started isn't something to sing about. I find it a bit dull and I will be looking for something sharper, but still for beginners like myself. Possibly the Astra blades before I move up to the Feather blades.<br />2. No protective cap. I wish Merkur provides a plastic protective cap to allow me to transport while on the road. A simple one similar to toothbrush caps will be best.<br /><br />OVERALL:<br />I'm very satisfied with this razor blade. I'm glad I didn't go splurging like I normally do for a more expensive model. I was even thinking of this 34C in gold plating, but I also read reviews of the gold plate chipping and fading away which will make it look cheap. I want something that will look old school and last just like those without the tacky upgrades.s to allow any metal to stress and break.<br /><br />CONS:<br />1. The included Merkur blade to get you started isn't something to sing about. I find it a bit dull and I will be looking for something sharper, but still for beginners like myself. Possibly the Astra blades before I move up to the Feather blades.<br />2. No protective cap. I wish Merkur provides a plastic protective cap to allow me to transport while on the road. A simple one similar to toothbrush caps will be best.<br /><br />OVERALL:<br />I'm very satisfied with this razor blade. I'm glad I didn't go splurging like I normally do for a more expensive model. I was even thinking of this 34C in gold plating, but I also read reviews of the gold plate chipping and fading away which will make it look cheap. I want something that will look old school and last just like those without the tacky upgrades.

  265. I was a little disappointed in the overall quality. The razor is stamped and chrome plated rather than machined. It's really more cosmetic than anything else as the razor works fine -- I just expected more for the price. The second gripe is the handle length. It just feels too short, and there isn't the reassuring feeling you'd get if the end rested on the heel of your hand. As it is, you pinch the barrel between your fingers and that's the only contact with the razor. It's a very simple design, sturdily built and it will probably last forever. It has a nice heft to it too. But if I'd seen it first hand I wouldn't have bought it.

  274. If you are new to wet shaving (as opposed to cartridge shaving), then you have to decide if you are willing to learn a new skill. Shaving with a traditional safety razor requires more time and practice than the latest Gillette cartridge gimmick design, but you get more control over the process. The cartridge design is meant to be dummy proof - one-size-fits-all for the masses. If you're willing to pay Gillette $$$ for their proprietary cartridges, many people can get a quick, good enough shaves from them. But, if you don't want to pay $$$ for a few measly cartridges, or if your face and beard don't jive well with their design, then the safety razor is worth a look.<br /><br />Here's the catch. You have to be willing to slow down, learn, and experiment to get the best results. Wet shavers continually cite the expression of &#34;YMMV,&#34; your mileage may vary. Myriad elements like skin sensitivity and beard pattern combine to make your face unique, so, while one user may have a fantastic first shave with a safety razor, another may need to reach for a styptic pencil. However, unlike the cartridge razor, the wet shaver can try a different brand of razor blade (you might be surprised to see how many are out there!) that can produce dramatically improved results.<br /><br />I could go on, but here's the TL:DR - Don't buy a safety razor like this Merkur, shave like you do with your Fusion, and expect a good shave.<br /><br />Instead, go on YouTube, watch introductory videos by users like Mantic59 and Geofatboy. Once you've seen the process, then you can make a more informed decision about whether wet shaving is for you. If you are still interested, then why should you buy this particular razor?<br /><br />Well, if the $40 is not a concern, then it is a fantastic first safety razor. While the Edwin Jagger DE89 falls more decidedly in the mild category, the Merkur 34C is more balanced in terms of aggressiveness. The construction is solid and I find the 2-piece design to be efficient. Unlike twist-to-open designs, razors like this Merkur have a top cap which allows for easy navigation around the nose. The knurling on the handle is good for keeping a solid grip on the razor. Some dislike the short handle, but I found that, once I got used to it, I much preferred the shorter handle and the control it gave me over the shave.<br /><br />Over the course of the past year, I have tried a number of safety razors, ranging from classic Gillette Super Speeds to designs like the RazoRock Stealth Slant. I still consider the 34C my go-to razor, and it is the basis from which I compare other models.<br /><br />If you want to try wet shaving on the cheap, the Lord L6 is a mild but acceptable $10 alternative available on Amazon. However, if you find that you like wet shaving, you may very well end up buying this razor (and others) anyway.
  275. this is a great razor. have had some that the blade can get a little off center, with bloody consequences. This one is so good, i bought 4 more for my boys.
  276. Bought as gift for father in law. Did research and this always popped up near the top.
  277. This razor is amazing! As a first time \\"wet shaver\\" I read everything I could from every source I could find, and finally decided on the Merkur 34C, all I can say is WOW! You simply won't believe how great it will make your face look and feel. BUT the razor is only half of the battle, if you combine this razor with a good brush and shaving soap you will notice a difference. Believe everything you read about this razor and wet shaving in general, shaving will become something you look forward to rather than dread.

I leave mine in the shower and it doesn't have a spot of rust or anything. I was going to upgrade if I liked but I never did b/c there was no reason to. This one is great!!

I started out with the Merkur blades that came with the razor and I have just switched to a Derby. The Derby gave me the best shave yet. I have a sampler pack coming in the mail.
  286. One of the true classics. Heavy in the hand, good shave.
  287. I use this as a backup to my Merkur 180 long handle. It works well and is solid.
  288. First off let’s not kid ourselves. A modern shaver like a Gillette Fusion shaves just as close as a safety razor with less risk of nicks and cuts. That being said, why do I use a safety? In the winter there’s just something comforting about the feel of warm heavy metal on your face (in the summer I switch to a Fusion). Also, I volunteer at a local food pantry and they were trying to get rid of a box of 20 year old Personna blades. So I have enough double edge blades to last a lifetime.<br />As to the Merkur #34C – it’s a great shaver! I used to use a “butterfly” type of safety, but they don’t hold the blade firmly and you get some vibration. Be sure to get one like the Merkur where the entire head clamps down on the blade. I was a little concerned that some reviews said the handle was too short, but I find I hold it with my thumb and first 2 fingers rather than gripping it in my palm. So for me the length is perfect. Finally, treat yourself to a good shaving brush and soap. I find a safety shaves better that way than with canned cream – plus you get the full old time experience!
  289. Highly recommend fits the hand just right, weight just right. Just be careful with the Merkur blade that comes with the razor. It's very sharp and I nicked myself pretty good. It was my first time to shave with a DE razor but I enjoy it now that I am trying different blades.
  290. Good razor, heavy and good quality.
  291. Great razor. Single edge razors are really cheap. I use one side to go with the grain, the other to go against the grain. You can buy 100 blades for around $13 on Amazon. Don't have to stretch out each razor - as it is 13 cents per. Just shave until it is a little uncomfortable. For me it is about a week before needing a change - but it is significantly cheaper than any of the other disposable or multi-blade options. In the end the shave is closer as I go with and against the grain, and there is no irritation as the blades are always sharp - because I am willing to replace them more often.
  292. Works great, done with disposables and razor bumps
  293. The weight feels great in my hand and I always recommend this razor when my friends ask which one to buy.
  294. Went to shaving101.com and read about what is a good starter razor and decided to go with the 34c because of the shorter handle and many justified outstanding reviews. So, if you have nothing else to do, please read on and I will attempt to summarize my experience for anyone currently on the fence about going \\"against the grain\\" and leaving cartridges behind.<br /><br />Reasons for switching:<br />1) Environmentally friendly. The blades are recycleable and cartridges are not.<br />2) Economically friendly. $0.30/DE blade is nicer than $2.50+/cartridge.<br />3) Much closer shave.<br />4) A lot more enjoyable with soap and a badger brush than canned cream and your fingers. Pampering is nice.<br />5) This thing feels like a piece of machined goodness in your hand (weight, balance, finish). Get it and you will understand.<br /><br />Things I have learned:<br />1) Shaving is an art. You will need to slow down, slow down, slow down. Your face/neck will pay if you do not.<br />2) Do not press at all when shaving. Hold the razor at the very tip of the handle (opposite the head)and let its own weight do the work.<br />3) Warm up the razor in hot water before using. It makes for a better cut.<br />4) Pick a nice shaving soap that suits your needs. Proraso green is what I went for and was pleased with the ease of shave and coolness the menthol and eucalyptus left. I tried it once with regular canned cream but it did not provide the same results.<br />5) Buy a styptic pencil and keep it handy at first. You will nick sporadically and the titanium dioxide will tidy things up (but man does it burn).<br />6) Rinse with COLD water when done.<br />7) As for blades, I went with the Amazon top reviewed and bought the Feathers. They are extremely sharp and perform beautifully on thick hair (reviews matched my experience). I tried the Merkur blade that comes with the razor, Wilkinson Sword and another store brand and you can tell immediately by the \\"tugging\\" that the sharpness is not there on those. I recommend the Feather blades.......<br />8) The shorter handle is a little strange at first but when you get used to it, you will love it because you can swing the razor in all positions easily.<br />9) This razor clears cut hair easily as there is an unimpeeded chamber beneath the blade which is large and diverts everything (soap/hair)away. I usually clog cartridges (between the blades) and have to run them under pressure (faucet/shower head) to get them cleared. This clears easily by dunking into the sink with little effort. Makes a difference if you have gone a few days sans manscaping.
  295. I purchased this after many days of research. I'm glad I did. It's heavy weight (balanced, doesn't feel cheap) and fits great in my hand. I'm glad I got this one and not the longer version.
  296. I feel mislead by all the great reviews. Either I've got a super wimpy face, or somebody stuffed the ballot box, or the emperor has new clothes, or lemmings are jumping of a cliff. I used it this Merkur twice and it nearly ripped my face off.
  297. great razor it will take a few times to get use to it but i will not use any other razor and i used the merkur de and it was a good shave and the free ones ihad received look cheap but i will try them out and let you know what i think
  298. This is a really great razor! I made the switch to 'real' razors ;-) and could not be happier. I definitely made the right choice in razor selection! My daily shave has become an enjoyable meditation time, instead of a chore!<br />This razor fits and works perfectly. Once you learn how to use it, you will never wish to go back to the cartridge face / wallet killers! Google searches will provide plenty of sites for teaching how to use this and other safety razors.
  299. I've tried top-end electric razors and the multiple bladed wet razors. Before this Merkur, I had to wait at least two days before I could shave again due to razor burn. This razor is awesome; I have been shaving every day with no problems. However, do some research before you go to town on your face. Look at the videos online of how to shave with a safety razor and save yourself some skin. Although sturdy with a great grip, the razor felt really small in my hand at first. However, I am used to it now and have no problems with the length - it's all about how you use it...yeah, I went there. The set came with 1 Merkur blade and 4 Big Ben blades. At first, I used the Merkur blade and cut my face a lot. However, when I used the Big Ben blades, I was fine. Now I use Sharks and rarely get cut at all. This has to do with practice, too. If you have sensitive skin, I recommend the use of Proraso Ultra Sensitive Saving Soap with a badger brush, an alum block, and witch haze after shave (I use the type that is mixed with aloe). A routine that works for me: shower first or apply a hot, wet towel to face for a few minutes, lather up, shave, rinse with hot water, rinse with cold water, use the alum block, splash again with cold water, dry off, and use a cotton pad to pat on / apply the witch hazel after shave. This sounds time consuming, but after a little practice, it isn't.
  300. I got tired of paying outrageous prices for cartridges. They were simply way to high. I could shave my face to baby smooth, going with and then against the grain and have a good shave. But the multi cartridge razor would leave my face so sensitive I would have to skip a day or two. My beard grows fast enough that I have to shave every day(a habit from the military). But I just couldn't with multi cartridge razors. I saw the commercial for the double edge razor on tv and it peaked my curiosity so I went to you tube and did a little research. I am really glad I did! I bought the Merkur 34c and a tub of Taylor of old bond street sandalwood scent and now I shave every morning with no issues whatsoever. Best of all, I paid 6.50$ for 50 blades! With multi blade cartridges 6.50$ wouldn't even get the package for a multi cartridge. I don't know why they even started making multi cartridge razors! I can remember my dad shaving with an old Gillette double edge razor and always cut himself so maybe that is why I was cautious about using the Merkur. But I figured out that my dad used the cheap store bought foam instead of a quality product like TOBS shave cream. They can keep their multi cartridge razor blades. I am sticking with a double edge. It is best to shave with a double edge right after stepping out of the shower. I will never go back to the disposable crap! Wet shaving is the way to go, plus I get a better shave!
  301. I recently ordered the Feather, E. Jagger, and Merkur 34C razors from Amazon. Due to Amazon's commendable return policy, one can try several razors and return those which don't perform the best. I rotated these 3 razors, with Feather, Astra, and Derby blades, for about the last 2 months, shaving once per day. For me, the Merkur with Feather blades was the clear winner. On the star scale I would rate the Merkur a 5, Feather a 3, and Jagger a 2. The Feather blades were noticeably better than the Astra and Derby blades, in all 3 razors. These are my results, yours will almost certainly differ, and be equally valid. The Jagger never failed to cut me to pieces. Shave was never on par with the other two. The Feather was a mild shave, but didn't cut the hair very well. The Feather's issue was that it was not aggressive enough. It would take 4 passes of relathering and shaving to get the job done. After that, my face was usually burned pretty bad. $200 is utterly outrageous for a razor. No way the Feather razor is worth even half that price. The Merkur was just right. It gives an amazingly close shave, with just 2 passes and a neck touch up. Never a burn, very rarely a minor cut. Outstanding value for the price too. What's the best combination for you? Order up, lather up and find out! You may be surprised at what you find.

  310. I'm African American and a military officer. Clean shaves are a must daily and I've tried it all...magic shave, mach 3, Fusion (or as I call it mach 5), Norelco Nivea for men shavers and clippers. All had their positives but mixing chemicals daily became tiring and in-grown hairs were unsightly. So, after much research I decided to try wet-shaving. This has made a world of difference.<br /><br />The Merkur HD is my first razor. Using Art of Shaving products and Merkur blades, I'm able to get a close shave with no razor burn/bumps. Occasionally I'll get an in-grown but I blame my technique (I still cut myself every now and then...usually when I'm in a rush). This razor definitely has some weight to it and I find the blade loading/unloading simple although not as cool as the \\"butterfly\\" razors.<br /><br />I highly recommend this product for a beginner. Blades are equally as important. I have found Merkur blades to be the happy medium between quality and sharpness although Feather's clearly are samurai sword sharp. Make sure you get a good quality badger brush and shaving cream/soap. Good luck!

  313. I was worried about getting into safety razor shaving but it all turned out ok! This is a great starter item that will last you forever if you take care of it (which is really easy, just make sure its dry at the end of each use). It fits my hand perfectly, I don't see a need for the longer version although I have smallish hands for a guy. Get yourself some shaving soap, extra blades and a brush and you're good to go! Cheaper to shave this way over time compared to cartridge razors.<br /><br />One important note is that the razor blade you choose makes a huge difference. Not all blades work with everyone. Some people need something like a Merkur or Derby blade (they are on the medium to low sharpness scale) while others might go for a Feather Blade. I would suggest getting a mixed kit to start so you can find the on that works for you. Save the Feather Blade till you know what you're doing though!

I've been shaving with this razor for almost 5 yrs and now I understand why grandad shaved with this type of razor.. I've put no less than 20 dudes onto this system for shaving. You won't regret it! UPDATE: I have dropped this one in the bathtub too, and now one side of the razor has damage to it. When I use it on the damaged side, I can feel it and it sometimes scrapes my cheek. If you have a porcelain, steel, or tile tub, this razor can get damaged very easily. I recommend you don't place the razor anywhere it could fall after your done shaving.

  361. I've never use s double edged razor before but after research and reviews, I found this to be a great razor to buy and use so far. Now I'm looking for the best razor blades for me.
  362. First, let me put this in context: I had never used a double-edged (DE) razor before. This was a highly-rated DE razor, so I decided to try it because there seem to be many people who claim that DE razors are superior to the more common safety razors (e.g., Sensor Excel, Mach 3, etc.). So, this review is not comparing this DE razor to other DE razors, but rather comparing the experience I had using this DE razor as opposed to safety razors. Note that I tried both the Merkur blade that came with the razor, and some Feather blades I purchased separately.<br /><br />People who favor DE razors claim everything from them providing a better shave, to being faster, to being much cheaper (in the long run). There are also those who just like the experience of using a DE razor (I can't say much about that, to each his own).<br /><br />DE razors are cheaper in the long run, that's a fact given the relative blade costs (less than a dollar for a DE blade compared to $2-$3+ for most good safety razors). But faster or a better shave? Or safer (not cutting yourself during shaving)? That was not my experience.<br /><br />Even with the Feather blades (which are insanely sharp - so sharp that I actually don't like them because you don't get any feedback - they just slice through the hair and you don't even feel it) the end result is no better than a good safety razor. Granted, not having used DE razors before, I'm sure my technique isn't perfect. But, my technique for a safety razor is just fine. The shave I get with a safety razor is just fine. There is no question that I can shave faster with a safety razor, since I don't have to worry about cutting myself.<br /><br />In the end, I felt like, unless you are actually using a DE razor due to their inexpensive blade costs, the supposed advantages of DE razors were hype (which is ironic, since DE fans say that safety razors are just hype to get people to buy more expensive blades), and to me they just aren't worth the trouble.
  363. Gives a great shave! Like all modern razors except stainless steel ones, it is made of nickel plated pot metal. Vintage Gillette razors for $10 are made of higher quality materials, but it does give a great shave.
  364. I bought the Merkur 34C to learn how to shave with a double-edged razor and it has been an excellent performer for fit, finish and function. It is heavy and well-made, with a simple two-piece design that makes changing razor blades quick and easy. I have relatively small hands and feel that the shorter handle on this razor is comfortable and controllable. People with large hands may want to consider a longer-handled model by Merkur. In any case, the handle and knob knurling is effective against slippage and the gentle bend the head imposes on blades seems just right. It will almost certainly last my lifetime and is nice enough to be worthy of passing on to a child or grandchild. Recommended.

  376. I dove into the wetshaving world eyes open and this was the most recommended razor for wetshaving virgins. I have had trouble shaving my whole adult life. My facial hair grows slow (very slow) and my skin is dry and sensitive. So the in-grown hairs under my neck aren't coarse enough to break the skin surface properly.This razor and Merkur blades has made shaving enjoyable for the first time in my life and I am 50 yrs old.

  382. I purchased this as I was tired of paying the ridiculous prices for Gillette blades etc. I remember this type of razors as the first I learned to shave with as my father used them. This will give a much closer shave then new conventional razors. Be warned though they do take some getting used to as the blades are sharper then on your Gillette etc. It is not a razor for the impatient. I found the weight of this razor to be excellent and it is well balanced. The short handle allows me to get closer to my face and almost feels as if you are running your hand over your face as you shave.<br /><br />Blades are much cheaper and available at your local CVS, Walgreens etc. It is a snap to clean and you just twist off the handle and run warm water over it. No issue at all. Enjoy your shave.

  387. I'm relatively new to classic shaving, but I have to say, I'm absolutely impressed with this razor. Having purchased it on a whim as an alternative to the Gillette Super speed I've been using before now, I have gotten the chance to finally try it.<br /><br />As for the results... they're very impressive. It's quite easily the best shave I've enjoyed. I even having swapped my Astra blades I usually go for with the Merkur sample blade, but didn't notice it detracting from this razor's effectiveness. With the right technique, this razor provides a consistently excellent, close shave, with almost no irritation.<br /><br />A few considerations. First, this razor is relatively short, so large-handed users or those who prefer a longer razor should consider the 38C instead. Second, this razor is heavy, which admittedly provides a more aggressive shave than the super speed I used to use, but newer users should be cautious of applying pressure to this effectively weighted razor.<br /><br />All in all, I love this razor and strongly recommend it either as a first safety razor or for users who want something a bit different to try.

There is definitely a learning curve in order to get a clean shave, especially coming from regular cartridge razors and electric razors which require no effort at all.<br /><br />The main thing when starting to use a double edge razor, or any older/traditional shaving methods, is the process and overall experience. The experience of prepping, shaving, and post-shave rituals creates satisfaction that is absent from today's more contemporary methods.

I'm still working on some patchy areas, some irritation after the first use. The idea of lathering, shaving, lathering again, shaving, takes a bit to get used to.   405. I have used this razor for 2 years and still using same 100 ct. Personna box of blades. I usually get 4-5 shaves per blade. That's about 4 cents a shave. TIP --- Do Not Press down on the razor. You will not get as good a shave and will dull the blade much faster. Just let the razor slide across your face. Let the razor do the work. Go over a few times to get the closet shave. Take your time. You will be very pleased. By the way, I clean and dry my razor and blade after each use; it looks like the day I bought it.
  406. My husband requested this as a gift & I confess I was concerned - especially once I received the package. This is a very small (short handled) razor. He LOVES it. The weight and balance are perfect, and it looks great on his chrome shaving stand with the chrome handled brush.

  412. Love it! Done being ripped off by Gillette and spending $20 for each pack of 4 blades. First of all, let me disclose that I'm a woman and that I use this razor for body shaving. This type of razor actually gives me a cleaner shave once I got used to how to hold it. Plus, it doesn't irritate my skin like a multi-blade razor. Although I will say that it's easier to get an occasional nick, mostly on the front part of my shin if I put pressure on the blade. That's another thing: unlike multi-blade razors, you really don't need to use pressure for a closer shave. Just drag it along at the right angle. I also really like the fact that this razor looks and feels really weighty and high quality, and will never have the gross residue that builds up in a conventional razor that has rubber inserts. My only complaint is that I didn't realize that it came in a long handled version; I think for use on the body, the longer handle might be a bit easier to use - so check both out before you order.
  413. I was tired of cartridge razors that were too expensive and still didn't feel good. After looking and looking, I decided to bite the bullet and try this razor. I was only worried because I bought into the safety of cartridges too much, and had too vivid an imagination of cutting myself to shreds and bleeding everywhere with an seemingly open blade. I'm glad I tried it. This razor is heavy and well-made. It's easy to use with a careful technique. I also found it hard to believe that it would actually make shaving a pleasure. But I was wrong there too. It's great. I do enjoy shaving now, and I haven't cut myself yet a month into it. I'm never going back to the cheap (but expensive) shave of a cartridge.

I actually enjoy the the morning ritual now: lathering up the Sandalwood Shaving Cream and foaming up the face and neck. The time to shave and clean the razor is a bit longer, but using this razor and the Personna Prep Double Edge Razor Blades (100 pack at 35 cents each) gets me a much closer shave at a much better price. This is a two-piece razor but I prefer it to my old butterfly-opening razor because the blade angle at the edge provides a smoother shave. Also, being a two-piece, a little more care needs to be taken when handling/changing blades. Again, not that big of a deal, but anyone who has a problem safely handling double-edge blades needs to just grow a beard. And lastly, the price makes this a great buy.

Blades do matter quite a bit when DE shaving friends. Do yourself a favor order a sample pack and figure out what you like, not what is most popular. I personally love the astra's and hate the feathers, derby's and merkur blades. They just did not work out as well for me. Also I'm not sure how people are ending up bloody messes. Its a razor blade guys, just be careful and you will be fine. You will get nicks, cuts, and little mishaps here and there.   444. Being a multi blade cartridge guys for the first couple years of my shaving &#34;career&#34; I was a little worried about getting cut, shaving causing more break outs and ultimately cost. So I generally just shaved with multi blade cartridge. Often just the cheap disposable ones. Silly I know and I have been wary about going all in with the double edge razors. Weird how cheap and not getting cut was the way, in my mind to a good safe shave using the multi blade cartridge.<br /><br />Now that I have been using the Double Edge razor, I find that a little patients in the beginning goes a long way.<br /><br />Have I been cut? No more so than I would have using a multi blade cartridge. That was a huge relief. Again be patient and it will soon be second nature like using the old, cheap multi blade cartridges.<br /><br />Does it cause more break outs? No, if anything I have notices, especially on my neck, I have seen some improvements.<br /><br />Most importantly, is it more expensive? You do the math.<br /><br />One new, high quality, double edge razor handle cost $50ish dollars. I felt that was high but with the high grade steal, I can't see wearing this out for many years. Blades are about $10ish dollars for a high quality 100 pack. Ok, if you are still with me, so for one year of shaving changing the blade every week and only shaving 6 times a week. I give my face a break on Saturday. That adds up to about $55 dollars in the first year. What does the second year cost? Hmmm, since I will still have blades left over and won't have to get another handle. $0-$5. If you can beat that with a multi blade system and have a fresh blade every week. Be my guest.<br /><br />I did a quick look on Amazon and found a 15 pack of just Mach3 blades for $34 and a handle with handle with 2 blades for $18. That will only get you through the first third of the year. For the full year it will cost you $120ish the first year and then about $100 a year every year after that if you throw the blade away every week. So as far as cost, you at getting something that is more than 2X as cheap the first year and something nearly 20X cheaper the next. Plus or minus 10X on the second year for the engineers now checking my math.<br /><br />If you are on the fence and have the time and money, I recommend adding 2 to 5 minutes to your shave time for a better, cheaper and I find it more enjoyable shave experience. You be the judge.

I was torn between them but now having owned both the EJ89 for me wins hands down. My merkur actually had a spot beside where the post goes into the handle, where the plating chipped. I tried to contact merkur and emailed every listed email with no response whatsoever. Its pretty well documented then plating issues and customer service problems with merkur. I returned the razor trough amazon. I've never seen a razor as beautiful as the EJ89. Get the barley handle for extra grip.

  466. So, I've learned there's a reason why the DE Safety razors where the only real choice for shaving for 100 years. It's superior to the cartridge based systems in every way. I've used the cartridge based system all my life and never knew anything else as the adverts lead you to believe this is the only choice. I hated shaving. Absolutely hated it.. I was prone to razor burn even though I only went with the grain, and passed over once which never really gave me a close shave. Yes it felt smooth if I ran my hand along the grain, but go the other way and it felt like sandpaper... and that's the shave I got used to for 15 years. I started to look into different approaches to shaving and came across an article that talked about the merits of shaving the &#34;old fashioned&#34; way like your grandpa. Did some digging which pointed to this razor as the beginner go to. Purchased it and watched some videos on youtube in anticipation of getting the razor. I admit.. I was a bit worried using a new system and feared that I'd knick and cut my self to shreds. I purchased a pack of Astra's Platinum razors to go with it. I loaded it all up, put the shave cream on my face and proceeded to shave. I gained confidence in the first couple of strokes as it was easier on my face than the cartridge's. My first shave I only did the one pass.. and the end result was the same as the cartridge. So I did bit more digging and found out the secret is to do a second pass. Holy cow.. what a difference that made... I've never had a smoother shave and it's smooth to the touch going in both directions and my skin is not sore or burning in any way. I'll never look back to the expensive cartridges ever again. I've had this razor for a week now and I look forward to shaving! My only complaint with this system is I do have a small mole on my face that I used to just shave over with no issues with cartridges, but I struck oil the first time shaving with my new Merkur, so I have to take carearound that area.
  467. Biggest problem with this razor is the fact that it only leaves a .5-1mm blade showing, so if you intend to get an amazingly close shave, you will not get that. However I would highly recommend this to someone who is unsure of how to shave with a DE.
  468. Great razor! I'm done with those costly disposable razors!
  469. After much research i chose this over other models. The handle is shorter but it provides great grip and control. I have a rounder face and was worried the short blade wold make it harder to shave but on the contrary it allows for good control of the blade. The razor is well balanced and easy to clean. I would definitely recommend this to others.
  470. Great razor -just the right weight, glides easily over the face and cleans up easy. I would recommend this razor to anyone.

The blade gap differs between the side by .18 mm when measured with a blade installed or without a blade. I really thought that a Merkur would be better constucted. Unfortunately, I missed the deadline for returns by 4 days. Should have pulled out my feeler guage sooner.

  502. I love well made tools that serve their intended purpose, so this German made beauty is right up my alley. It's beautifully and (from what I can see) flawlessly designed. It's handle is shorter than the cartridge razors I've used all my life but I'm ok with that because of its heavy head; this extra weight let's the razor do all the work without me having to place extra pressure on the handle to press the razor against my face. So I really don't need the leverage of a longer handle the way I needed it with a cartridge razor and I still get the close shave I crave without the irritation.   503. Has an amazing feel in the hand. Blades are easy to change, shave is close and smooth.<br /><br />I've been wetshaving for a year and a half now. Before I joined the military I would only shave maybe once or twice a month. I was used to walking around like a scraggly faced hobo. After I got out of boot camp I was having issues getting my A-school instructors to believe I had shaved in the morning.<br /><br />There had to be a better way.<br />So i bought the cheapest safety razor I could find and a pack of feather hi-stainless blades. There was a bit of a learning curve, but the shaves were the smoothest I had ever had. I was still using regular shaving cream, the gillet gel type.<br /><br />I decided to up my game. I bought psoraso green soap. My eyes were open. I had understood the lies at the heart of the american dream. No. Wait. That was the time I read &#34;fear and loathing in las vegas&#34;.<br /><br />But my eyes were open. Why had men switched from such a sensible, elegant, and ultimately cheaper method of shaving towards ever more gimmicky and increasingly less effective disposable razors? I don't know. The wet shaving method is clearly more effective. With practice it takes only five to ten minutes to get an excellent shave.<br /><br />Never look back, shipmates.

  513. This is the best shaving experience I have ever had. I had peach fuzz all through high school so I did not start shaving until I joined the Navy when I was 18. In boot camp we all had to shave every morning no matter how many whiskers we had on our face, and we all had to use the same type of razor, a Gillette Atra. Since this was my first shaving experience I just kept on using Gillette razors, from the atra to the sensor and eventually the mach 3. 30 years later I discover this razor, and all I can say is I can't understand how our fathers and grandfathers ever let someone convince them that a plastic multi blade razor was an improvement over this type of razor. I just lather up my face, hold the razor against my face and control it as it slides down, allowing the weight of the razor do the work. Then I re-lather and slide the razor against the grain, once again allowing the weight of the razor do the work and I have a nice comfortable shave. I love this razor and it is a definite improvement over my old mach 3, plus replacement blades are a hell of a lot cheaper.

  536. This was the first razor I bought when I switched off cartridge razors. I've tried open comb razors, and TTO razors, and this one is the one I keep coming back to. It's built very solid, it has a good heavy feel in the hand. The knurling is deep and grips very well when wet. I have NEVER dropped this razor, which I can't say for any of the others I own.<br /><br />The two-piece design makes blade changes a snap, and the razor holds the blades evenly and securely, giving you a consistent easily repeatable shave every time. The construction is high-quality, rest assured this razor will likely outlive you under normal use and abuse. And the plating is smooth, even and consistent, lending to a comfortable shave.<br /><br />It's a fairly mild razor, mild enough to shave with it daily without irritation; but open enough and with enough blade exposure and clearance to easily tackle a few days of growth. This is a really good all-rounder. I would recommend it for anyone, whether you're just getting started in DE shaving, adding to your collection, or replacing a broken daily shaver.
