  541. I bought this razor earlier this month and have to say that coming from cartridge razors, this razor blows away every razor I have ever owned and I have probably owned them all from the classic twin razor to the Mach 5 with a lubricating strip and vibrator (oh gods does that sound naughty!). Eventually I settled on the blades from Dollar Shave Club thinking I was getting the best deal and the shaves were alright, and I’d even hazard to say that these blades were some of the best I had used. That is until this simple, beautiful razor landed at my door.<br /><br />Yes, this razor is quite steep investment and at $44 it is one of the more expensive ones in its class, but once you start factoring in long-term maintenance costs -- ie, replacement blades -- this razor quickly pays off. Even compared to the DSC, I can get more shaves -- better shaves -- for half the cost on blades. You will need to purchase a good shave soap, some alum or a styptic pen, some lotion, and aftershave if you want a great shave, but those are really required for any great shave. Just keep in mind you will want to at least upgrade your shave cream to a proper cream if you are using Barbersol or other aerosol based product.<br /><br />The razor itself came in a box with one blade. I was a bit disappointed about this, but the blade itself is decent, however, I am going to upgrade to Feather blades because I have a rather course and thick beard which means I need a sharper blade. The blade itself is quite sharp and effective, but shaving around the neck caused a bit of skipping. What was impressive, even on the first shave there was minimal cutting and bleeding. Less so with the DSC blades and I rarely cut myself on those. With decent technique, even a novice to DE wet shaving, it is hard to cut yourself.<br /><br />The razor itself is very well weighted and balanced. It exposes enough blade for a great cut, but enough guard to make it hard to make any serious cuts. The textured handle is really nice on this product and makes it very stable to hold: it would be difficult to accidentally drop this razor even with wet, soapy hands.<br /><br />My skin is also very sensitive as well, so shaving with cartridge razors would always result in razor bumps and burn. Not so with the Merkur. The first time I shaved, the blade did cut over the tips of some of my previous bumps from the DSC razor, but a few hours after the shave I couldn’t tell. Shaving the next time was like cutting through butter and left me with a baby smooth face, though there is a little bit of stubble around the neck.<br /><br />The razor doesn’t get gummed up during the shave and dipping and shaking in a warm bowl or water or giving it a blast from the faucet will suffice during a shave and the metal absorbs the heat and feels great of the face. After the shave, cleaning the razor is simple as most of the time a good run-through of hot water will suffice. Changing the razor and giving it a full cleaning is simple: just twist the bolt at the bottom of the razor, hold the top piece of the head and the side of the razor and pull apart gently. From there changing is simple: remove blade, wash or replace, put back onto handle, and tighten screw. It takes only a few seconds and the whole thing has a very solid feel and construction once fully assembled.<br /><br />Overall, I would give this a solid four out of five simply because I think that it should ship with a few more courtesy blades given the cost; otherwise I would have given it five stars. I would and have recommended this razor to friends, and if you are looking for a great wet shave look no further. While it might not be as flashy or cool as the butterfly models Parker makes, it makes up for in simplicity and solid design.e is really nice on this product and makes it very stable to hold: it would be difficult to accidentally drop this razor even with wet, soapy hands.<br /><br />My skin is also very sensitive as well, so shaving with cartridge razors would always result in razor bumps and burn. Not so with the Merkur. The first time I shaved, the blade did cut over the tips of some of my previous bumps from the DSC razor, but a few hours after the shave I couldn’t tell. Shaving the next time was like cutting through butter and left me with a baby smooth face, though there is a little bit of stubble around the neck.<br /><br />The razor doesn’t get gummed up during the shave and dipping and shaking in a warm bowl or water or giving it a blast from the faucet will suffice during a shave and the metal absorbs the heat and feels great of the face. After the shave, cleaning the razor is simple as most of the time a good run-through of hot water will suffice. Changing the razor and giving it a full cleaning is simple: just twist the bolt at the bottom of the razor, hold the top piece of the head and the side of the razor and pull apart gently. From there changing is simple: remove blade, wash or replace, put back onto handle, and tighten screw. It takes only a few seconds and the whole thing has a very solid feel and construction once fully assembled.<br /><br />Overall, I would give this a solid four out of five simply because I think that it should ship with a few more courtesy blades given the cost; otherwise I would have given it five stars. I would and have recommended this razor to friends, and if you are looking for a great wet shave look no further. While it might not be as flashy or cool as the butterfly models Parker makes, it makes up for in simplicity and solid design.
  542. I am really glad that I decided to buy the Merkur 34c. I forgot what a good shave the old Double Edge razors give, plus all the money that I save not buying razors every month or so.
  543. I shave my head every day and I have been spending hundreds of dollars on other commercial razors. Then I heard about Merkur and read the reviews and learned about it. Now, I have been using it for couple of months and I can say that I am never going back to commercial razors again!
  544. Blade gap uneven, good quality chrome finish. Every other blade I've tried, Merkur, Bolzano, PolSilver, and Personna Lab Blues, have really left me raw, bloody, and sore. Should've spent a little more on a mergress.

I got one of the closest shaves I've ever gotten with it.<br /><br />Some users seem to dislike the included blade, but try it anyway since blades work differently for different people. It's working very well for me so far
  546. Awsome! should have made this purchase years ago.

  549. I have black thick facial hair which tugs and pulls with most razors leaving me with burn and irritation.   554. I've been shaving with Mach 3 Turbo for many years, but was really interested in trying the old school method.<br /><br />After reading reviews on many razors, I decided to splurge on this one. I used my favorite brush and Jack Black Supreme Cream.<br /><br />Following advice from reviews, I applied no pressure and let the weight of the razor just rest on my skin. The strokes were easy and pain free, and the result was closer than Mach 3.<br /><br />Obviously, there is more potential for nicks with these, but I was surprised how easy and effective it was.<br /><br />If you are wavering and not sure about trying this razor - go for it.
  555. There's not much more I can write about a Classic. A great starter razor, the Merkur blade is also a very forgiving blade and allows you to learn if you are new to wet shaving. I recommend this to everyone
  556. Never owned or used one of these types of razors before [heck, never even heard of one until lately], and I thought it would be a little short to work with by the looks of it on Amazon, but once it comes in, just play around with it without the blade and get a feel for it, position your fingers in various ways. I've been using it for only a couple days and now I like to hold it with my thumb and index/forefinger on the skinny tapered neck part [just under the head] and with the bottom end of it resting on the edge of my palm between my pinky and ring fingers wrapped around it. It sits nicely there and I feel a bit more confident with it [also because of the grippy rough diamond texture on the handle]. it should work fine with big hands. you might not need the slightly bigger Edwin Jagger DE89Lbl [in case you were looking at that one too].<br /><br />I have some aloe plants in my yard so I cut a section off a leaf, scratch up the inside with a small knife, and rub the gooey gel all over my face. It's pure plain and simple and healthy. I could also use unrefined coconut oil. i don't use shaving creams or soaps of any kind, which no matter how 'natural' they may be, aren't truly natural [always gotta be some darn chemical or refined ingredient in there or just unnecessary stuff].<br /><br />I hold [tilt] the razor about 30 degrees out and I make short light strokes without applying too much pressure, as it really is nice and heavy duty with good weight to it. It smoothly slices off the hairs on its own, no tugging or pulling, and it feels like a nice shave after. no irritation, no nicks or cuts or ingrown hairs [of course, as long as you only go with the grain and do it slow and steady]. it is waayyy much better than all them regular multiblade cartridge razors. totally worth it. if you've never had one before, don't fear it.
  557. I'm new into DE razors, so this is my first and only DE razor but it's hard to imagine what can be improved on.<br /><br />It's got a great weight to it, a simple but elegant look and a perfectly knurled handle that's nice and grippy. Okay, one gripe is it doesn't do that cool butterfly open on top like I've seen some other razors do, instead the whole top just unscrews by twisting the bottom of the handle. Not as cool, but I don't feel like it's enough to dock it because now it doesn't have an ugly split down the center.<br /><br />For me however this works great. I used to shave with cartridge razors every other day or every third day depending on how I felt. I like using this razor so much I shave every day now. Hell, if I have to take a second shower in a day before going out I'll use it twice in one day! Something about it is just fun, and the shave feels a million times better.<br /><br />I do use this razor for my neck and head (no face, the beard will always be there), and while it takes a little getting used to in just a few weeks I've got the pattern down and can shave my neck in seconds and my head in a couple of minutes while getting a closer shave than cartridge ever allowed and without nicking myself (okay, well, the occasional nick, still).<br /><br />Sadly, at least for me, the Merkur blades don't seem to be as well engineered as the handle itself. Sure, they work, but I have been using Personna blades to great satisfaction and am looking to try others as well when these run out.<br /><br />All in all very pleased. I have always had a liking for things a bit more old school because, well, many older tools seem to provide with better results, albeit with more associated risk or effort involved. That is certainly true of DE razors, but your grooming ritual won't feel like you're playing with a toy, either. There are of course cost benefits that for me show up rather quickly: cartridge razors are expensive-- a pack of 15 costs around as much as this razor itself does. For a fellow that shaves his head I went through cartridge razors fairly quickly, and while I replace these razors with the same regularity, they're tons cheaper.<br /><br />Unfortunately now I will have to check my luggage everywhere I go. Damned if I will switch back to those expensive cartridge razors for the convenience of being able to do carry-on.or itself does. For a fellow that shaves his head I went through cartridge razors fairly quickly, and while I replace these razors with the same regularity, they're tons cheaper.<br /><br />Unfortunately now I will have to check my luggage everywhere I go. Damned if I will switch back to those expensive cartridge razors for the convenience of being able to do carry-on.
  558. I decided to try shaving with a DE safety razor after being repulsed by the cost and styling of the Gillette cartridge razors (what kind of man wants to shave with something that looks like a character from a Transformers movie?) and finding that the more elegant and economical Harry's cartridge razor, while excellent for what it is, didn't shave any better than the Gillette razors. It still tugs and rips at the hairs, inviting razor burn and ingrown hairs, just like every other cartridge razor.<br /><br />Most of the extremely helpful wet shaving celebrities on YouTube recommend the Merkur 34C HD as the ideal safety razor for novices, and after my first shave, it's easy to see why. Would I be able to find the right angle? Would I be able to use short strokes without any pressure, overcoming my cartridge razor habits? Would it tug? Would I feel like I was always on the verge of cutting myself? Would I actually cut myself? These are some of the unknowns facing the first-time DE shaver.<br /><br />Well, the first stroke with the 34C put my concerns to rest. I just lined up the safety bar with my side burn, held the razor at angle that felt balanced in the hand, and let the razor glide down my cheek under its own weight for an inch. Oh! That's the way shaving is supposed to feel! It doesn't tug or pull at all. You just feel the blade slicing cleanly and effortlessly through the stubble. Finding the angle was a non-issue. If it's at the right angle, it shaves. If it's too parallel or perpendicular, it just doesn't shave.<br /><br />Because your shaving with a robust hunk of metal, you get excellent feedback on what the blade is doing. You can feel it cut and hear it cut. It's a very reassuring sensation. After a few strokes, it very quickly becomes intuitive, and you just know what inputs into the razor will give you that positive feedback. I thought I would only go straight down for my first few shaves to get the hang of it, but by the end of my first pass I felt likeI could go crosswise on the next pass. A couple strokes on my cheek is all it took to find the angle and get just as comfortable shaving in this direction.<br /><br />I did a very conservative cleanup pass after that and wound up with a categorically smoother shave on most of my face than I've ever had with a cartridge razor. I didn't do as well right up under my nose, and I was gentle on my lower neck where I know I'm sensitive, so I did about as well there as I normally do. My skin felt smooth and healthy with no irritation. It definitely seemed like a far less traumatic experience for my face than the cartridge razors.<br /><br />I'm tremendously satisfied with my first DE shave. It easier, smoother, and more enjoyable than I anticipated, and I look forward to my next shave. It can only get better from here!<br /><br />I'm also completely satisfied with the Merkur 34C HD. It lives up to the hype. Besides being easy to use and giving a smooth enjoyable shave, it exudes the quality and refinement of a finely crafted tool. It's a beautiful object, in a manly and minimalist aesthetic, and it's a nice thing to own in that respect. It's also the rare thing these days which is obviously designed to last. There is no part or detail on this razor which feels cheap or disposable.<br /><br />Other details of my shave:<br /><br />Blade: I will use the sample Merkur blade which came with the razor at some point, but for this shave I used a Personna &#34;Comfort Coated&#34; blade which comes in a blue box of 100 blades for $12. These blades come highly recommended on the Internet as an inexpensive middle-of-the-road blade (sharp but not excessively sharp) which is made in the USA. Being the first blade I've tried, all I can say is that I had no problems with it. It cut smoothly and did not cause any irritation.<br /><br />Brush: I used an Omega Professional (model 10049) boar hair brush. This brush is cheap and huge. It's bigger than I expected and does not fit in standard brush stands. It's still breaking in and just a tiny bit scratchy. Boar hair brushes are supposed to be good for face lathering (which seems like better and faster preparation than bowl lathering). I started using this brush with my Harry's cartridge razor a few times before using the 34C. I haven't had any trouble producing good lathers, but in hindsight I think I would be happier with a smaller brush. This beast can get unwieldy.<br /><br />Lather: I used Nivea Men Sensitive Shaving Cream, which comes in a 3.5oz tube. This cream got some great reviews along the lines of &#34;I'm astonished that a cheap cream from a big global brand is my new favorite cream&#34;. I definitely recommend this for new wet shavers. It's very easy to use and produces a very slick lather. It's high in glycerin, so it holds lots of water and leaves the skin feeling soft and hydrated. Maybe someday I'll try the expensive stuff from Taylor of Old Bond Street and the like, but for now I'm happy with this Nivea cream. I also have a puck of Arko soap, which didn't work as well for me.<br /><br />Set and Setting: I did my first DE shave on a lazy Sunday morning after a nice long shower, and I encourage other newbies to do similarly. It didn't take an enormous amount of time, about 20-25 minutes including lathering. But you don't want to be pressured for time. You want to take as much time as you need to pay attention to all the new sensations that guide the shaving process. My plan is to shower and shave at night this week to get more practice. Hopefully by next week I have this down to 15-20 minutes and be comfortable DE shaving in the morning before work. Experienced shavers can do it in 10 minutes.
  559. This is my first DE razor and I must say I am happy with it overall. I was concerned that the handle would be too short, but now that I have used it for month, I like the maneuverability it offers. I previously used an electric, so I didn't have too many bad habits to unlearn like with cartridge razors. It has plenty of weight to provide a comfortable shave too.

I am still learning the ropes involved in shaving close under my nose and on the curves of my chin but I am getting there. The razors that are included are good and last about 3-4 shaves (I have medium stubble).   572. This razor is definitely worth the money! For $44.00, it'll pay for itself in less than 3 Fusion 4-pack cartridge refills. The others that have written reviews on this razor know what they're talking about. It's all in the technique you use. With this razor, there is no need to apply any pressure - let the weight of the razor do the work. It's much heavier than your standard plastic Gillette or Schick. I had m 4th shave with it tonight and each time it's getting better and better. The more you use it, the better you'll become. As far as blades are concerned, I purchased a 5-pack at my local drug store for $1.00 (that's right, $1.00). It's the store brand but I had one of the best shaves of my life. If it's this good with the cheap ones, I can't wait to buy some expensive ones, for like $5.00!<br /><br />You will not be sorry.   573. I am very satisfied both with my decision to change to using a double edge razor and the quality of this razor.<br /><br />The handle is not very long, but I find that it is easy to grip and maneuver. While this did feel out of place initially, I think a longer handle would add to the difficulty of shaving. Blades are easy to change, the styling of the razor is attractive, and so far the feel for the quality is very high (weight, finish, precision of parts fitting together).<br /><br />The biggest advantage I received by switching to this razor from a Gillette MACH3 is that I experience significantly less skin irritation, especially on my neck. I have had no razor bumps at all on my neck since using this razor, and these were always a concern before.<br /><br />Cuts were a concern before I began using the razor. Following advice I read, I began by only shaving down for the first two weeks. After this two-week period, I began shaving up as part of a second pass. I received a few minor nicks the first time I shaved up, not not subsequent times. Shaving is not as easy, and the size of the shaving head makes it more difficult to see when near sideburns or underneath my nose. This relatively minor disadvantage is far outweighed by less irritation for me.

  581. I'm getting back to DE shaving after many years away. For anyone, like me, with less than fond memories of the old gillettes, this razor is a remarkable improvement. Also much much cheaper to use over time that the current better quality cartridge razors. This thing will last more than my life time.<br />Very simple to use. The top unscrews and comes off. You plop the blade on and screw the top back on. The short handle on this bad boy basically prevents you from leveraging the handle and pushing down to hard. No adjustments to the razor are necessary (or possible.)<br /><br />There are cheaper &#34;starter&#34; razors available. Don't fall for those.   591. I got this for my birthday and I really like it.<br /><br />I have been shaving with straight razors off/on for the last year or so. I enjoy it, but it seems I can only occasionally get as good a shave as my disposable razors and it takes a lot longer. I think I'm not getting the blades as sharp as I need to, and it is a long learning curve.<br /><br />I needed something that would be faster and hopefully provide as good as a shave as the disposable, I turned to the double edge.<br /><br />With the provided Merkur blade my first shave was better than that of the disposable razors (with just a hint of burn). I was astounded. I think my time with the straights, and my respect (fear) of the blade lent to such a good shave right out of the box. After 3 weeks of shaving I have had a little razor burn here and there, but nothing as bad as when I was learning to shave at 15, or when I first got the straights. I did really rush it tonight and got a little more irritation than I had been, but it seems to be a more forgiving learning curve than the straights, and a great way to get a better shave than disposables, at a better price point. I have been using a badger brush from frank shaving, and the taylor of old bond st sandalwood cream, what a delight! It's a ritual I look forward to now! My wife has also noticed that my face has been exceptionally smooth on some occasions (still in the learning curve).<br /><br />I ordered a pack of 25 different blade types, so it is highly possible I will find a blade that I get even better shaves with.<br /><br />This is a short razor, and I think it would be easier to follow old angles learned from disposables with a long handled razor, but being that this is a double edge, it may be good to start fresh. The razor has a real nice heft to it, and blade installment is easy (and you only have to do it once every 2-3 weeks).<br /><br />So get a brush and some shave cream, take your time, and enjoy exceptional shaves!
  592. Fantastic razor. I made the change from a cartridge razor to this one about 4 years ago. The Merkur still looks like it is brand new (once I wipe off the soap).   595. As someone who has big hands, I kept going back and forth between this razor and one with a long handle. I'm glad I went with this. Unlike a traditional razor like the Mach 3, a safety razor is designed for more than one pass in different directions. A long handle would have gotten in the way.<br /><br />This razor has a very solid, sturdy feel to it. It's heavy enough to let gravity apply just the right amount of pressure. If I ever buy another razor it would be for looks, not function. This razor is perfect.<br /><br />Keep in mind that this is a closed-blade razor so it's best when used everyday or with stubble. Open-blade razors are best used for shaving long facial hair.<br /><br />All Merkur razors come with a single, double-edged Merkur blade. Its packaging is no different than anyone elses. I would not recommend shaving with it - just throw it out. Unlike Feather, Merkur blades do not come highly recommended. Using it will leave you with a sub-par shave, razor burn, and regret.
  596. What a nice feeling in the hand, smooth threads inside promote easy and safe blade changes.   598. I researched everything I could before buying this. Seeing who recommended what. Seems like 90% of the sites i visited said the same thing, that ultimately you had to decide for yourself. You can read all the reviews on this razor and the one thing you can glean from them is that this is a quality 2 piece razor. Its not too aggressive nor too safe. The razor blade seats pretty consistently,so you don't have to fiddles with the blade to make it square with the razor. All that said,whether beginner or veteran I do not think you can go wrong with this razor.
  599. Combining this with the included blade, a badger brush, and some Proraso shave soap, provided an excellent shave! Well done!
  600. I love it! Bye-bye Infusion!
  601. I cannot say that I shave often lately but when I do... this is a pleasure with this Razor. Please buy some good Japanese razor blades.
  602. I just tried this razor for the first time. I used to use Gilette ProGlide. When I first tried the Merkur, I thought it wasn't working because there was no resistance at all -- but it was working fantastically. For best results, you have to shave against the grain with it -- that's why the shorter-handle version is better than the long handle. I was a little bit afraid of cutting myself with it -- but I have no cuts. This razor shaves so close I'm afraid of ingrown hairs!<br /><br />This is extremely cost-effective compared to Gilette. The ProGlides I used to use are $50 for 12 blades. The best blades for this Merkur (Feather, which I have not yet tried -- I've just used the blade that came with the Merkur) are under $15 for 50 two-edged blades. I'm expecting 50 to last me at least 6 months, if not a year. I have a very thick beard and shave every day.
  603. I prefer my Edwin Jagger DE89 Knurled handle razor. The Merkur 34C is a good razor. I like the weight and grip and it gives a fine shave. The posts that attach the head to the base are just a little loose requiring me to check and adjust alignment whenever I load a blade. I don't have to do that with my Edwin Jagger, vintage Gillettes, or my $15 Feather Popular. The finish on the Edwin Jagger is also much nicer. Don't get me wrong: i like the 34C. If it wasn't for the slack in the blade alignment, i would give it five stars.
  604. This is an excellent safety razor, at least based on my limited experience. Very easy to set up, short heavy handle feels great and makes it easy to control, blades come off easily. Overall great product and definitely worth the price.
  605. I purchased the Merkur Heavy Duty #34C Razor after having used a single blade injector razor for the past 30 years. I read the reviews of this razor used with the Feather blades and since most of the reviews were really good I purchased one. I've used it for about a week now and although it does an excellent job it's only marginally better than the injector razor that I formerly used. I still have to shave &#34;against the grain&#34; to get a really good shave just as I did with the injector razor and by doing that I get about the same results as I did before. I do like the heft and feel of it and it's well made but I'm disappointed that it doesn't shave a bit closer. The Feather blades are excellent with not even a hint of getting cut. I think the cutting &#34;problem&#34; with the Feather blades is really overblown. All in all, it's a good razor but not the shaving panacea that some would have you believe.
  606. I bought this for my boyfriend and he LOVES it!!
  607. First time DE shaver, and this is my first ever DE razor. After two months of shaving with this I haven't nicked or cut myself once, and I love the shave. My first round has been with Merkur blades, and I'm about to experiment with other brands, so I'm sure I'll have a goof here and there, but overall I love the feel of the razor, the quality, the look, etc. The handle is small, and I know that bothers some people due to the 'size' of their hands, but you shouldn't be gripping this thing like a pipe wrench. There's plenty of area for your fingertips on this razor, and the pattern on the handle provides a great slip free hold. I'm sure the longer handled ones are fine too, but I like the appearance of this little gem.
  608. handle too short for big hands
  609. Been using for about 8 months and love it. Great balance and weigh
  610. First time using a DE razor, and it has taken some adjustment, but definitely like the razor. Great price because this razor is offered at The Art of Shaving for double what you pay on Amazon.

Best shaves only require a single sharp blade and proper preparation. All those new-fangled over-marketed modern B.S. razors with their balls and lubricating strips and what-not aren't worth doodly-squat. When it comes to a high-quality shave...less is more.
  614. It can be hard making the transition to wet shaving and to safety razors. It seems a little confusing at first, and the prices seem a little high, especially if you decide you don't like it.<br /><br />Well guess what? You'll like it. In fact, you'll love it. This razor makes the process effortless and amazing. The razor is well balanced and easy to use. It's durable and will last you a lifetime. Compound this with the value of razors (around twenty dollars for 100 blades) and you're set.<br /><br />For around 50 bucks you should be set for over a year of shaving, as one side of each blade can easily last 3-4 shaves, meaning 6-8 shaves per blade, meaning roughly 52 blades per year. Leaving the other 50 for the following year. This means a 2 year cost of shaving is a total of roughly 60 bucks.<br /><br />Solid deal. Do it. And enjoy a better, closer shave while you're at it.
  615. I've been shaving for nearly 20 years. I've used everything from disposable razors to straight razors. I have very thick facial hair and there was pain associated with every product I tried. I tried switching from creams to gels to hot foam, it made no difference. So I grew to accept that shaving would just naturally involve a bit of discomfort. For the past 6 years I have switched to the double edged razors with the same result, still uncomfortable, but the blades are cheaper. Now I don't buy the cheapest blades I can find, I've been using the feather blades which from all the reviews I could find had a pretty good rating. Well, I wanted to upgrade my razor and so again I started searching for reviews. I settled upon the Merkur Heavy Duty Double Edge Razor as it consistantly had some of the highest reviews. When I got it and tested it out I was absolutly blown away. There was no pain. No pulling, no tugging, no burning. I figured they must have some amazing blade in it, so I put one of my feather blades in it to see the difference. There was none, it was still amazing. I tried it with foam, cream, gel, (I even tried with just watter) all with the same results, completly pain free and close shave. So ya, spent almost 20 years suffering through shaving untill I landed on this razor. Now I get a quick close shave, no nicks, no pulling, no burning. I could not be more satasfied with this product. I've even bought a few as gifts and everyone has been equaly as impressed with the product.
  616. I used the Merkur HD for the first time tonight; this was the first time ever using a DE safety razor. I was fully expecting some blood loss...(even bought a stypic pencil). The shave was exceptionally smooth. No nicks, cuts, or irritation!
  617. Best razor! I will never go back to the plastic razors.
  618. I like the feel of this razor. I am trying different blades to find the perfect match. Believe it or not, the blade type does make a difference, so buy a sample pack to go with this.
  619. This was my second of these, purchased strictly for business travel. Outstanding safety razor that would be hard to improve upon.
  620. This razor is not worth the price. The chrome finish on mine began flaking and chipping after about a year, revealing the metal underneath. It seems like once the company was acquired by DOVO the quality has declined. I contacted the company and sent them a photo, and received no response - poor customer service. If you Google on this razor you will see numerous reports of the chrome flaking and chipping. I am now using a Weber and it is much better made and gives smoother shaves. If you want a razor that will last about a year or two then this is for you; otherwise, there are better quality razors out there for a little more money.
  621. I bought this razor for my man for Christmas. He usually shaves with expensive 3 blade razors with replaceable blade heads. He complains of razor burn and skin sensitivity after using these modern razors. After his first shave with the Merkur HD double edged razor he was amazed at how smooth and close his shave was. He seems to look forward to shaving rather than dreading the task. It was a good investment and a great gift to give.
  622. This was the first safety razor i have ever owned.   626. Sometime in the 70's I switched from my trusty old Gillette double edge razor to the Schick Injector Razor and others as they were advertised and released. The price of razor blades for those lightweight pieces of crap is astounding these days. I finally switched back to what I started with, a double edged razor. It arrived today and I had grown a two day beard to see if I could still shave with one without nicking or cutting myself. I used Cremo shave cream and the 34C with a Derby blade and got the best shave I have had in years. No nicks, no cuts, no irritation, just a damn good shave. Highly recommended! Incidentally, I have large hands and long fingers, the 34C was fine as the weight and non-slip knurled grip gave the feel of old world craftsmanship.
  627. Just the best shaving experience I've had in about fifteen years of shaving (I'm almost 29 now).<br />I find myself shaving a bit more often than I did with the multi-blade razors I used to waste my money on, but that's no problem.<br /><br />I used the first blade more than five times (I'm not sure if that's advisable, but it's my first safety razor, so what do I know?).<br />My point is that the blades are very high quality and you don't have to use a new one for each shave, though they're just about cheap enough and easy to find that you probably could. I don't like being wasteful, and this is much cheaper, &#34;greener&#34;, and just a better shave than what I'm used to.<br /><br />The only possible negative thing I can report (which is most likely my fault) is the irritation I got when I shaved against the grain around my mouth. My skin is quite sensitive, so I should've known better. Well, now I do.<br /><br />I'm still looking for a good shaving cream/soap. Thinking of trying ProRaso. It looks a little expensive, but I want to try a few brands and see what I like best.<br /><br />Anyway, I'm hooked.<br /><br />And so can you!
  628. I have been using the Merkur for several months now. Amazing shave and it's less expensive then constantly buying cartridges.
  629. This is my first safety razor and it is virtually fool proof. It is a two piece design with the handle and comb guard as one piece and the top of the head removes to change out blades. The razor itself has a nice weight to it. I find the the handle to be a bit on the short side. when compared to holding most modern cartridge razors it feels like there just isn't enough space available for my average sized hands. After a few weeks of use the handle size is no longer and issue and it feels plenty comfortable to hold, especially since safety razors aren't meant to be pressed against the skin, just glided across with the shaving cream of your choice. The only suggestion I would have for someone new to safety razors is to buy a sample pack of blades and see which brand works for you. The Merkur blade that comes with this razor is not the sharpest or most forgiving blade on the market. That is the beauty of owning a safety razor, though, you can now buy ten different razor blades for less than the cost of one cartridge and each one will give you a unique shave till you find what suits you. Happy Shaving!
  630. I've been using an old Gillette red handle for years and thought I'd try the Merkur. Mistake!! I cut myself on every shave. I use feather blades,so I know it's not the blade. This razor just feels wrong! Think I'll stick with my old reliable Gillette.

  640. This blade is amazing. At first i was a little skeptical even after reading all the good reviews. Some say it's hard not to cut yourself with this blade, so i was a little concerned. To my surprise during my first shave, this cut so smoothly that i wasn't sure if it was cutting at all! I had to look closely in the mirror to see if it indeed get the stubble and it sure did. My shaves are much closer than my old Mach 5 and it does NOT take longer than shaving with the plastic razors. After a few practice shaves, my shaves are just as fast and easy, with NO razor burn at all. These blades are incredibly sharp so you do need to put a little more care into your shaves. Those people getting a lot of cuts must either have a face with lots of curves and bumps or they are just being a little reckless with the blade. My wife used to complain about my stubble when it touched her face, but after using the Merkur, no more complaints. Even after my stubble grows longer, she says that it feels different and less prickly. For my wife's sake i would sometimes shave against the grain, but that would frequently result in small cuts and always bad razor burn, but with the Merkur going against the grain is painless. I also find that i can be much more precise with the Merkur and get those little bits of hair right under my nose or if i have a bump on my face i can easily shave around it. Could never do that with my Mach 5 even with the little \\"grooming\\" blade on the front end of it. I will never go back to those cheap plastic razors. I am a DE guy for life! Do your face a favor and buy this blade!
  641. I just started wet shaving last month. I ordered this razor and two things struck me when I opened the box. 1)it is very heavy 2)It is pretty short and small Both of these factors make shaving a lot easier. The weight allows you to apply very little pressure while shaving and the size makes it easy to maneuver. I also get the impression that if cared for properly this razor could last basically forever. It's easy to take apart and the blade adjustment is very simple. I would recommend this product quite highly. I was skeptical of the high price at first, but upon seeing and feeling the quality of the product I'm sure that it was worth it.
  642. These razors are the just the right weight and hold the blade just right for a close shave with out razor burn.
  643. Two sections of this review - looks / first impressions, and function. I have to say I am not satisfied with the looks for a few reasons. One is that I expected it to be made out of stainless steel because that is what the description says. In reality is looks like the head is cast zinc and then chrome plated. I tested it with a magnet. The handle looks cheaply made to me. If you were expecting an heirloom object that you can pass down to your son as I was, this is not it. Now to the shaving: I used it for the first time today. I have never used any double edge safety razor before, as far as I can remember. I normally use a Norelco rotary and then clean up with a disposable blade or possibly a cartridge like a Mach 3. I put in a Personna blade and shaved and had basically no learning curve - it just worked. This is with proper shaving soap but my brush didn't even arrive yet, so I used my hands and didn't have any lather to speak of. I was surprised as I watched some videos and was told to expect it to take months to learn this kind of shaving. So while I have close to no experience, this must be an easy to use razor. I just wish it were physically nicer. That being said, probably most people would be ok with it, as the other reviews tend to indicate.
  644. Had the handle for my replaceable cartridge blade break on my just after buying a new one, so I finally made the plunge into double edge razors. It's pretty much the finest shave I've ever had. I've been using it for over a month now, and I am only on my third blade! I have pretty thick stubble, and this makes shaving a breeze.   656. I've been using Norelco 5601X for most of my adult life. It's been amazingly reliable and gets the job done with minimal irritation. But the electric shaver just can't handle stubble older than 2 to 3 days so I started looking into buying a cartridge razor, but found the price of replacement cartridges rather high. That's when I came across the old school double-edge razor and the whole wet-shaving enthusiasts. I purchased Merkur 34C and have been using it for a few months now and I find that it has its pros and cons. I enjoy the &#34;feel&#34; of the razor in my hand. I especially like how I can better maneuver shaving under my nose and above lips better than typical cartridge razors. As for skin irritation, I find that I haven't noticed a significant difference between both types. I tried shaving with both types of razors over 2-week period and my skin is irritated either way. What I do appreciate is that I haven't nicked myself that much using the DE razor. A huge plus. And of course, it does feel &#34;cooler.&#34; The whole ritual involved with the shaving is a bit more pleasant and well, different.<br /><br />Downside is that I can't quite seem to get that close shave just yet. I realize that I shouldn't go for complete removal, but compared to the cartridge razor, I have to do at least 3 passes or more to achieve a real close shave. I also find that I can't just rake across my face like I can with an electric shaver or cartridge razor. So again, if time is an issue, I'll opt for the electric shaver<br /><br />In the end, when compared to shaving with Norelco, I hate to admit it, but my electric razor outperforms in terms of time, convenience and performance (again, only for short stubble). Nevertheless, I'll continue using the DE razor and hope to improve over time and find it a much better solution for wet shaving.

  679. The heft of this almost does the work of shaving for you. It feels like a TOOL, not some cheap plastic &#34;beauty product&#34;. The blades are hilariously inexpensive compared to disposable or cartridge razors, even the ones made of German-made medical grade steel, meaning you can change them out as often as you like, even every shave, and still be economical. It has practically eliminated the razor bumps I've had on my neck for my entire adult life (and to be honest, I expect it will -- I'm still healing from the damage I didn't know the other razors had been doing).<br /><br />Guys, think back to the razor your grandfather used, and you may remember one like this, even long after those pitiful disposables and cartridge razors from Bic, Gillette, and the like were in fashion. And twenty one years ago I paid 60.00 for this razor, the prices on Amazon are more than fair.
  683. I have been using this razor for a month and love it. I was concerned the handle would be too short but it's naturally balances between the thumb and index finger and the butt rests comfortably on my little finger. Very heavy for it's looks, it gives the feel of a very well built and well engineered product. Solid like a Mercedes. I have yet to nick myself and I get a much smoother shave than disposables or cartridges.
  684. I ordered this razor because I was tired of paying $20 for Mach 3 refills every few months. I calculated that this razor would pay for itself in about a year (factoring in shave soap, scrub, etc.). I ordered this at the same time that I ordered [[ASIN:B002JKR0HA Col. Conk Amber Glycerine Shave Soap]] and the [[ASIN:B000G647Y8 Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush]]. I also picked up some Neutrogena pre-shave scrub and post-shave lotion from a local store. Due to the vagaries of shipping times, I actually received all my shave accessories before the razor arrived, so I had a chance to experience wet shaving with a Gillette Mach 3, good shave soap, and adequate face preparation before my Merkur razor arrived, and then compare the two.<br />First off, I was surprised how much of a difference the pre-shave scrub and post shave lotion made. It took me awhile to figure out the shave soap and brush lather, but after about 4 or 5 shaves I had it down. The shave was the smoothest I'd ever experienced, and I was worried the Merkur razor would not live up to the hype, just because the shave soap and scrub made such a difference.<br />After the Merkur arrived, I used it with the included blade for about a week, and was impressed, but not blown away. I wasn't getting a shave any closer than the Mach 3 had with all the preparation. Then I switched to one of the [[ASIN:B004SGKMA0 Derby Double Edge Razor Blades]] I had ordered, and immediately experienced what all the hype is about.<br />This is the best razor I've ever used. I've been frequently bothered by ingrown hairs with the multi-blades razors, and haven't yet (fingers crossed) had one with this. It is smoother than the best I was able to get with a Mach 3, and my girlfriend agrees. Once I got the hang of it, it is not slow either.<br />Caveats:<br />1) It is a bit slower than a disposable. Certainly the fastest I'm able to shave with this is about 3-4 minutes, as opposed to 30 seconds or so with a Mach 3 right out of the shower with my trusty [[ASIN:B005FNVINA Barbasol]] alone.<br />2) This thing is tiny. I don't know that I have huge hands, but the razor is only half the length of my Mach 3 and it is small enough to be awkward to hold. It takes some getting used to, and I'm thinking about going with the longer model and using this for travel purposes.<br />3) it is possible to nick yourself with this blade. But I haven't noted it is any worse than I occasionally got with the Mach 3.<br /><br />Overall, I recommend this, along with the Derby blades and some good face preparation.
  685. It is tough to go wrong with this razor. High quality metal, easy to open, easy to replace the blade, easy to clean, etc. It is mild and forgiving, great for my sensitive skin. The heft of the razor makes shaving easier as it is easy to avoid applying pressure. Once you find a blade that works well for you, you'll never want to go back to multi-blade razors.
  686. The handle is perfect. Easy to use and maneuver. I have sensitive skin, and the merkur blades left my skin very irritated.<br /><br />Still, hard to knock off a star for this razor because the couple of sample blades didn't satisfy my needs.

It glides effortlessly through stubble and beard, leaving a smooth, clean path in its wake. Should you need to go &#34;against the grain&#34;, you can do so with the confidence that this razor will not carve your face into a work of modern art.<br /><br />If you're switching from disposable razors, please understand that you will need to adjust your technique. The blades are super sharp and there is no pivot in the head to get around the sharp contours of my bony shins and ankles. I constantly have a few nicks along my shin bone and trying to navigate this around my ankle bones was a nightmare. Maybe I'm just careless or unskilled at shaving, but I can't handle this baby! It's too much razor for me! I'm happily reunited with my razor that has a pivoting head and handles my jagged bones better.

But those are becoming harder and harder to find and buy. Then I came across an online discussion regarding shaving and after a few minutes of search here and there, I was surprised to see that the old school shaving method that I used to use back when, has become the trend and is probably better for my skin (explained why I never had razor bumps before but now I get them a lot more.) This razor was listed in many forums as a good overall razor, so I decided to order it and tried it.<br /><br />Good workmanship, definitely a high end product. Works well and I am kind of excited to be back to the old ways. I get a very clean shave (closer than Excel) without any irritation.
  705. This is my first DE razor after using disposable blade razors my entire life. I bought the new gillette swivel fusion last year and generally liked it except that I would still get razor burn and the cost of the blades is annoying. My wife bought me an art of shaving starter kit last summer and I began using a shaving brush and before and after shave creams. This was a big improvement over the gels I was using. This also generated some interest in looking at other shaving options and after looking at all of the reviews about this razor I decided to give it a try and also buy feather blades based on reviews on Amazon.<br /><br />It definitely takes some adjustment to your shaving technique.   707. So I originally started shaving with a safety razor using the flawed Edwin Jagger DE89 because I heard good things about it as well and it was $10 less. Safe to say though it was all hype. The is the razor to buy. The weight and size is phenomenal. As perfect a shave as I expected. The highlight is the stainless steel design. The DE89 has a brass handle and plastic head that were chrome plated. Though it's listed only as brass. This is ALL stainless. That means the head as well. Also the thread for the head goes almost the length of the handle, as opposed to 1/2in long chrome plated plastic. This truly is a durable razor that will last a lifetime of flawless shaves if you maintain it.
  708. Great all around DE razor. The Merkur 34c is my goto double edge razor.
  709. First off, as I would tell anyone, a quality shave is the product of a lot of factors. I'm assuming that anyone who is interested in this type of product has already taken the time to pursue a good prep (i.e. soak,brush, lather, quality after-shave treatment etc.) If you're switching over from the radioactive-colored gel/plastic face-grater routine, it's a good idea to take a gradual approach. Try using plain old shaving soap & a brush, & get a good lather. Keep it Simple. Get all that chemical crap off your face. Despite what the ads say, women don't want it, and it just provides more things for your body chemistry to reject. That by itself will give you a MUCH better shave.<br /><br />I am an African American male who, like many others, has had to deal with razor bump issues. I went from gel and multi-blade, to brush/soap & multi-blade, to brush/soap and a DE razor (Merkur #34C). Just as applying with a brush is superior to using your fingers, Having a single blade, which you can control, is much better than scraping multiple blades across your skin. You will FEEL the difference.<br /><br />The 34C has been a great first DE razor for me. It does take time to adjust. Don't pick up a DE razor for the first time when you have to catch a train in 15 minutes. It takes time to re-learn your beard. You're not using an axe anymore, it's more like a trusty knife. Unlike multi-blades, a DE won't get clogged. If you pick up a bit of scuff, rinse, switch sides, fresh blade. You MAY have to pay a bit more attention to what you're doing, but if you're a guy like me who has had to deal with bumps/irritation for years, you already were. Keep it light,don't try to get it all in one pass. Unlike a cartridge razor, you need NO PRESSURE. You won't get cut if you let the weight of the razor do the work. If anything, go by resistance/sound rather than feel. You can do the with/against/cross method and lather every time, but even if you don't you'll get just as good as a cartridge, that's the beauty. The shave is as good and long lasting as the time you're willing to put in. I've also found that getting a clean edge is much easier with the broader DE blade. And the blades are cheap. Very cheap (relatively).<br /><br />Construction of the Merkur 34C is top notch. The handle is shorter than the plastic face-shredders but the added weight gives counter-balance & a sense of touch. Like any other tool, you can judge the quality by holding it in your hand. Buy one and you will probably pass it on to your son one day, seriously. STOP WASTING YOUR MONEY ON PLASTIC.
  710. Works exactly as advertised,well built and nice weight
  711. Well made very nice I would highly recommend theis razor to any one I love the quality and craftsmanship of this razor
  712. I was a little concerned about trying something new on my face but WOW, talk about a smooth shave. I just love how if I dont shave a few days this razor still is super easy to clean. My Fusion always gets clogged with my hair and half the time shaving is spent trying to get the hair free.<br /><br />Love it!
  713. I've been happily using an Edwin Jagger DE razor for several months now. I decided to buy another razor and chose the Merkur 34C due to its strong reputation--basically being the state of the art in DE razors. After using it, I can understand why. While the Merkur may not be quite as pretty as the EJ, I find it to be functionally superior in a couple of ways. Blade changes are easier--less pieces to fiddle with. Ergonomics are better due to the knurling and the increase in diameter at the end of the handle--both facilitate a better grip and thus control during the shave. Both razors give excellent shaves and I have no problem endorsing the purchase of either, but I believe the Merkur to be a bit more user-friendly.

  717. I did an enormous amount of research before purchasing this razor (which I do before buying anything of any importance). It arrived on time, in perfect condition, and exactly as advertised. The razor, a Merkur HD 34C is an absolutely amazing piece of hardware and I couldn't be happier with it. Some buyers have complained about either its weight or its short length, but I believe this buyers failed to appropriately check the item out before purchasing it. It is solid and heavy (as expected from the name) and is definitely shorter than a standard modern razor. Both the weight and length, in my opinion, provide a better sense of control when shaving, allowing for a closer shave and tighter lines if you're wearing a beard or side burns of any kind. So far, I couldn't be happier with the selection. I will update this posting in a few months and rate the longevity of the razor.

  732. Excellent. Hold is good. I switched from cartridges as they were not giving a close shave any more. I contemplated between going for electric shaver and this. I am so glad I tried this. It took some learning. Had cuts and bleeds few times. I was doing it all wrong. I was not keeping the skin taught etc. I was not soaping enough and create hydroplaning. May be I was holding the stroke angles wrong and irritated the stubs. Takes a good a month or two so you shave with optimal 3 or 4 passes. WTG, XTG, ATG and your final couple so you get BBSM shave. Once I got the skills right and with combination of this cute small well built DE razor and blades ( I use both Personna and Feather) - shaving is not a chore. I enjoy giving myself a good shave. I do listen to music while shaving (got a Abco Tech water resistant wireless bluetooth) so I can listen in bath. I do sometime listen to audiobooks as well. I can't do this, if I had gone with electric shaver. Besides it would never have given me a close smooth shave. After a month and half, this Merkur blade is as good as new. No rusting or loosing shine or anything. Easy to load blade and clean. I do use mineral oil at the end of the shave to apply to blade edges and also to parts of the blade. This prevents bladges from getting rusted. Razor also repel water and becomes easy to clean.

  734. I've just decided to take the plunge into DE shaving, and gave this Merkur 34C a try. Like many others, I browsed the numerous forums and reviews online before deciding which razor to get. Most debate seemed to come down to this product and another from Edwin Jagger.<br /><br />I ultimately decided to try this from Merkur, and have enjoyed using it very much thus far. It feels very well-made, with a good weight to it in your hand and an easy glide. It seems expensive initially, but with the amount you save on razors (including the very tangible benefit of changing your blades more regularly because they're so cheap), I'd say the outlay is well worth it. There is also some discussion out there about how it might fit into your hands if you're a large person with bigger hands and all of that. For those of you wondering, I'm 5&#34;7 with with normal-sized palms, and like how this feels in my hands.<br /><br />It gives a wonderful, close shave that I certainly prefer to any of my previous cartridge razors (I used shavemob before, which I liked). The only downside to this (unavoidably) is that it really does take time to learn how to use this properly and quickly. You cannot be impatient about it and just have to put the effort into it. Otherwise, I've thoroughly enjoyed - and frankly look forward to - shaving with this product. I've recommended this to many of my other friends, some of whom are considering trying it too. I would absolutely love to try any of their other products, because I've been so impressed with this.

  747. This is the third DE razor I've owned and consequently the third stab I've taken at DE shaving. I'm in the military and have to shave every weekday. I'm used to suffering through mild but painful razor burn from the middle to end of the week when using old cartridge standbys.<br /><br />My first DE razor was a decent Edwin Jagger. It had some weight to it but I felt it wasn't helping me enough. Several months later I picked up a 1940's Gillette on Ebay. It's much lighter and built of a better quality but I still wasn't getting the shave I desired. Fast forward three years and I've decided to pick up DE shaving once again. After reading reviews on several other razors, it was hard to pass this one up.<br /><br />This thing has some weight to it. That's a good thing, because it lessons the chance that you'll be tempted to push rather than let the razor do the work. It's sturdy and the crosshatch pattern on the handle provides good grip, even when wet with water and lather.<br /><br />Since switching to this razor, I've had great shaves. Little to no razor burn--still a bit of a learning curve, but I'm getting there. I use this combined with Feather blades, The Art of Shaving Lavender cream, a Parker silver tip badger brush, and finish with Nivea sensitive skin aftershave.<br /><br />If you're new to DE shaving, this is a great razor to get you into the game.   755. I switched to the 34C after about 3 months use of the 25C open comb, which I found a bit too aggressive for my skin/hair type. My skin always felt a bit inflamed and sensitive to the touch after using it, even with just 2 passes. Using the 34C with Personna reds and Nivea Sensitive Skin After Shave Balm I can now do a 3-pass shave without any irritation. It feels good in the hand, on my face and just performs well. I am relatively new to DE safety razor shaving, and happy to have found the right combination of razor, blade, soap, brush and after shave that works for me.
  756. Very nice razor, stubby and built like a tank. Price is fair.
  757. Works great and a lot cheaper than buying the replaceable cartridges all the time. Price of blades for this is a dollar a dozen. Smaller handle than the average razor blade but easier to maneuver after a couple swipes. I have and will keep telling people to switch.
  758. Easy to use and heavy-duty. Only down-side is that I wish the handle were a little bit longer. But other than that, I like it and don't miss shaving with the name-brand disposable cartridge razors.
  759. Nice heavy double edge handle. Works great for me, some people may prefer a longer handle, but I'm very happy with this purchase.
  760. This is my first double edge razor. I did a lot of research and everything pointed me to this one. I love it and haven't looked back!
  761. Top notch. Still can't get over it
  762. This is my first de razor. Just got into wet shaving and have been in enjoying it from the beginning. You won't go wrong with this razor.
  763. I was sick of buying overpriced junk razors. The idea of spending over $20 for around 3 cartridge razors made me nauseous. So I decided to go old school and never looked back. This was the best idea I have had lately and the cost savings is tremendous. The quality of this razor is great and made of solid metal. Finish is great and I have never gotten a better shave.   764. I don't think that I can add anything new here that hasn't already been said, but I will say that between switching to this type of razor and watching You Tube videos on shaving, I feel like I am learning how to shave correctly after shaving for many years the wrong way. I really enjoy this razor. As stated, I am new to this type of shaving, and I very seldom get cut. I used to shave everyday with my old razor and gunk in a can. Now, I shave every other day (sometimes less) and people don't even notice. My skin is thanking me. In shaving math, that means that this razor is shaving twice as close. I use a combination of Arko shaving soap and Kiss my Face shaving soap (both sold here at Amazon). Both are terrific products on their own, but together, they are fantastic! I use both Astra and Personna Blue razor blades. Both are great products and are very forgiving on my face. Try this type of shaving--you'll never go back!
  765. I've been shaving with cartridges as long as I can remember, until now. Recently purchased the Merkur 34C DE safety razor. Invest! Comfortable shave with no irritation. A few nicks, but I believe that was operator error. The weight of this razor does the work for you so there's no need to push down like with others. Leave the latest cartridge razor fad on the grocery store shelves and buy this razor!
  766. Very easy to use. I was a bit hesitant to use a different technology at first but after a few go's, I've gotten comfortable with it. It is super safe and I get an excellent close shave from it. It is easy to clean and to use. I use double edge blades from the local CVS store. I've used three blades in the span of a month or two now. I think it's like less than a dollar per. It may sound like you're spending more money on razors, but you definitely save in the long run... and when I say long run, I mean a month or two you probably get it back. What are you waiting for?   767. Excellent piece of hardware, though I found the handle to be too short and uncomfortable to shave with, especially compared to the Gillette Fusion I had been using.   768. I am new to this kind of shaving and the recommendations regarding this product are spot on. I like the handle's feel and action. It's not adjustable like some of the pricier models but does it's job well. If you don't need the adjustability this thing works fantastic.
  769. Prior to using this DE razor, I was using the Mach 3 blades. My beard comes in pretty coarse and I would get ingrown hairs here and there. In fact, I knew that if I ran the blades across my face, at a certain angle, I would definitely end up with ingrown hairs.<br /><br />Now that I have been shaving with this DE razor for about a month, I have to say, I will never go back. Once you find a brand of blade that works best for your facial hair/skin, you will notice the difference. My face has never been so baby smooth. After learning the proper technique for using this blade, I have not had any ingrown hairs for weeks. And since these blades don't pull on your hairs, like the multi-blade cartridges, I can run this razor at angles that would have given me razor burns before.<br /><br />The razor has a good weight to it and the shorter handle makes it easier (at least for me) to shave. I tried a longer handle model, but found the handle would get in the way during my shaves. That could be due to my technique, but after getting this one, I never went back to the longer handle.
  770. This is a sturdy and well-made (and frankly, beautiful) razor. It takes a little getting used to a single blade after using Gillette's perverse multi-bladed abominations, bur it's very well worth the effort.
  771. Have had this razor for 3 weeks now, having switched from a Mach 3. It has taken me this long to start to feel confident with the Merkur. Now that I'm getting used to it, I really like it. But I didn't like it at all for the first week, mainly because I was overly worried about getting cut. Now, I do feel like I get a closer shave than with the old mach 3, but it comes at the expense of adding a couple of minutes to my shave. While everyone seems to say that you should always shave with the grain, there are some areas where I (still) have to shave against the grain to get a close shave.<br /><br />The razor is well built, heavy and sturdy. But it's short, and I wish I had opted for the long handled version. Where it really becomes an issue is shaving around your jawbone close to your ears. It's hard to keep a good grip on this short handle for that area. The shortness is kind of a plus, however, when getting the area right under your nostrils.<br /><br />As a tip, when you're rinsing the razor between strokes, twist the bottom to loosen the blade, and then run it under the water. This allows everything to rinse out - otherwise it tends to stick in there.
  772. Built like a tank, a beautifully polished chromed one at that. It lives up to its reputation as an excellent DE safety razor. It is not difficult to get a BBS (baby bottom smooth&#34; shave from this razor. I even like the Merkur razor blade included with the purchase, but razor blades are very subjective to the specific user.<br /><br />This is one of 4 DE safety razors that I have in my rotation (Merkur 34C, Lord L5, Lord L6, Weishi 9306-H). I like them all and they all have been good razors to learn with. The Merkur 34C is the heftiest of all, it is the best manufactured of the 4, however also costs 5X more than the other 3 razors.<br /><br />The Merkur 34C must be a more aggressive blade angle and blade tolerance than the other 3 because it gave a smoother shave with less passes. However, that being said, I find it pleasurable to shave with. My styptic pencil is used rarely. This razor has been reviewed with very positive user experiences and my experience confirm the public reviews are correct.

One thing I really like is that the head is really flat so you get the under the nose/upper moustache area better without having to contort your poor nose.   785. This is my first DE razor, so I can't compare it to other shavers out there.<br /><br />I CAN say that as a beginner, I felt comfortable using this from the get-go. I was worried I'd slice myself up - hasn't happened. So that's good. Not sure I like the Dorco blades it came with, though. They take quite a few passes and leave me with some irritation. I tried a Derby blade recently and that seems to have lessened the problem dramatically.<br /><br />For other beginners - be aware! If you're like me, switching to wet shaving will mean your shaves will require more concentration and preparation. They will take longer. And they may not be as close and smooth as you're used to. But I view this as investing in a skill that helps me know myself better, take better care of my skin, and feel more manly and confident. It has helped me turn a chore into a ritual, and psyches me up for the day. It helps me feel proud and in control of myself. It lends me some desire to look nicer - and my lady loves that. Just know what you're doing - the benefits here aren't short-term. When you get a DE razor, you're committing to some work - research, practice, and experimentation.<br /><br />Overall, very happy with my purchase. Good item, as described, no troubles yet, good shipping and customer service. Unfair to deduct a star because the blades didn't suit me personally? Maybe, but it has definitely affected my enjoyment of the product, so there you have it.

  824. The Merkur HD 34C safety razor feels solidly made and substantial in your hand. Its weight feels nicely balanced to me. One of the reasons I chose this razor was that it was not flimsy and that it had only two separating parts:the top blade holder section and the bottom holder section with attached handle that screws into the top section.<br /><br /> The handle is shorter than most of todays modern multiblade-headed razors which unlike DE (double edge) razors usually also have a floating head. This DE razor's handle is about 3 inches long. I like it though. It kind of forces you to use your fingers to lightly hold the handle so that the non floating head can gently follow the contours of your face. I have a feeling that if it had a long handle new users like myself just switching to a DE razor would tend to grip it in their plams and nick the heck out of their faces.<br /><br /> Everyone is slightly different when it come to shaving and some of the choices should be made by user's trial comparisons. This thought applies to shaving creams/soaps, brush (if used) and the blade brand used. Each individual varies in skin type, beard type, and preferred beard preparation method. So shaving choices which include which shaving soap or cream, soap brush or can cream, and personal choice of a DE blade brand that works best are items each user needs to decide on for themselves based on their personal conditions. Choosing the right blade for yourself is pretty important. I can tell you that some blades that got very good reviews did not turn out to be my favorites, at least not with this razor and my own conditions. You should try some sample packs until you find a blade that works well with all of your personal variables.<br /><br /> I think most users will like this razor as it works well and gives very nice results once you get used to DE shaving techniques. Maybe people with very large hands would prefer the longer handle version, but for me this has been working quitewell for the last 6 weeks or so that I've had it and I'm quite pleased with this purchase.

  835. Sturdy and simple, works quite well. It motors through a week's worth of stubble without slowing down. The cost of this razor was about the same as a large package of blades for my former razor at Sams, but will last for the foreseeable future. It takes a bit of practice, but after you figure out how to angle the handle, it works great. I use this razor, with Feather blades, to shave both face and head, with little difficulty. Rather than use the mug soap & shaving brush most shaving websites recommend, I use HeadBlade's HeadSlick shaving lotion, touch up with a styptic pencil when needed (not very often, unless I rush or apply too much pressure) and finish up with Gilette Aftershave Gel. After shaving, I disassemble it, pat everything dry, reassemble it and dip the head in alcohol before putting it into a case I cobbled together from a travel soap case, a kitchen sponge and a couple of desiccant capsules out of pill bottles (total cost: about 2 bucks). I am a truck driver, and don't always have an opportunity to shave every day. In fact, there are weeks I only shave once or twice, and this razor effortlessly mows right through a weeks stubble without slowing down. My only regret is that I didn't buy this razor, or one like it, years ago.

It works well. It's smooth, easy to work with. I'm in between with the handle size. I would like a little more handle but not as much as the other one. I prefer this over the long handle. There are a ton of options out there, you gotta start somewhere and learn what you like. This was a good beginning point, I don't regret it. This was't a very expensive product, aside from the packaging, it's doesn't seem very cheap as well. It's a in the pocket kind of purchase for someone like me wanting to start out with a quality razor, getting to learn the art, and not blowing the bank.

  859. If you spend over 3 dollars a week on razor blade cartridges. IE Gillette Fusion. Or if your the guy that makes his cartridge last a month.... This razor is for you. There is a learning curve. It's a fact. You will have to soften your beard in the shower with conditioner. Or use a preshave product such as Paraso. ANY form of shaving cream will result in a good shave. Don't let the die hards peer pressure you into the fancy shaving soaps... Unless you want to use them. I like them. But unnecessary. Look into an After Shave Balm. They can.be helpful starting out. Otherwise the same Paraso will work great. You will find yourself looking forward to shaving. To spending less time in the shower and more time in front of the mirror. By choice. The most you could possibly spend on blades a week is $1. The least $.10. Get a blade sampler pack. Try them all once. Keep a journal of pros and cons for each blade. Then try them all again. You will find the perfect blade. Good luck and have fun! Your life will forever be different.

  900. I have had this razor for about a year. Use it with Feather blades, Vanderhagen shave soap from Walmart, an Escali badger brush and Nivea post shave balm also bought at the Walmart. This German razor cost $15 more but is so much nicer. The affordability of wet shaving is such a great saving. 50 Feather blades cost about $11 and can give 3 shaves apiece. 100 Astra or Derby blades cost around $11 and can also give around 3 shaves but not near as close. After one year the razor looks great if I clean it up and has no rust. Simply awesome piece of tech that every man should be using. $60 today will last you till the middle of next year when you will have to spend $11 to order enough razors to bring in 2016.

I tried 3 passes before but I don't get better results and it seems as though the first pass going with the grain really doesn't do anything for me.<br /><br />You can tell that this is a precision product made with quality materials. I feel like this is going to out last my lifetime. The Germans are great at what they do. I am shave daily because I work in a professional environment, and it's important how comfortable the shaves are because I certainly feel it, and razor burn and nicks affect the following day.<br /><br />After I shave I wipe everything down including the blade with a wet towel and dry / polish everything with a dry towel and re-assemble so it will be ready for shaving again the following morning.<br /><br />Pros: Quality, looks great, works great<br /><br />Cons: I can't think of any

  907. I started wet shaving with very little investment and was using an old Gillette adjustable double edge razor. That worked fine but the razor really needed to be professionally re-plated and I wasn't going to deal with that. After reading reviews, I went with the Merkur 34C and have been nothing but pleased. I always grip the razor near the head so the shorter handle is fine for me. The weight of the 34C, along with a really good blade, does all of the work and gives a great shave. I also just like putting a new blade in and going, no adjustments like I used to do. Highly recommend.
  908. I was DE curious but scared, turns out my fears were over nothing. It's shaving, way nicer shaving, but no more difficult than that. Get good cream, I like Taylors Old Bond, get a mid price badger brush and a stand and a blade sample pack. Soak your brush in warm water while you shower. Dry off, leave your face wet, if it dries shake out your brush and wet your face. Swirl your brush on the cream and get just a bit and swirl it around on your face. Dip the ends in a bit of water if you need more. Shave using motions 90 degrees to the razor head. If you miss spots lather up again, wash the brush, rinse your face in cold water.

  921. I began using an old butterfly type Gillett Double Edge Razor some 40 years ago. Soon after the newer double, triple, and five bladed razors were introduced I stopped using my double edge razor. Now the expense of these along with their short life span, I decided to go back to the &#34;old school - tried & true&#34; method. I ordered the Merkur 34C along with some additional Merkur blades, some Taylor of Old Bond Street St. James Luxury Shaving Cream, a Parker 100% Pure Badger Bristle Black Handle Shaving Brush, and an Escali Deluxe Chrome Razor and Brush Stand.<br />Now this is shaving! The Merkur 34C is a well balanced, well made, and attractive shaving device. Blades fit perfectly securely without any guess work. Simply unscrew the razor head using the knurled knob on the end of the razor. I invert the razor head and place the blade in the head. Invert the handle and place the bolt of the razor head back in the handle and retighten the head. Simple and quick.<br />The Parker Badger Bristle Brush is amazingly soft and the Taylor Luxury Shaving Cream is superb...a magnificent combination to prepare your beard after showering. The Escali Chrome stand holds the Brush and Razor perfectly and the combo is incredibly attractive.<br />Merkur Double edge razors set the bar for close shaving luxury and whichever razor you choose to use will be highly dependent on your personal preference(s). The 34C will hardly wear out and is easy to care for. On a cost/benefit ratio it is a no-brainer. If you have a tough beard and are on the fence of whether to give up your Gillett multi-blade razor...this is probably the one to consider. It is easy to learn the art of wet shaving with this razor due to it's inherent weight. No real exertion on the users part is required. Just a steady guiding of the razor across the face with an accurate touch. Highly recommended.
  922. Freakin awesome!!! No more gimmiky overpriced cartridge Mach III BS for me. These razors may be a little high to start with but in the end hey are even cheaper than shave clubs.
  923. I've been using the Merkur Heavy Duty for a couple months now and I really like the weight and balance, it is well crafted. I haven't used a double edge razor in about 35 years, and I can't remember why I got I started using the crappy/expensive safety razors. I will admit you need to be more cautious and not rush when using a double edge razor, but that's not a problem. Razor blades are rated 1 - 5, where 1 is least sharp and 5 is most sharp. I chose Derby blades (rated a 1) because my whiskers are fine, and because blades rated 1 are more forgiving (less likely to cut yourself). Having said that, I think I'll try a 2 or maybe a 3 next time, but considering I only spent $5 for 25 blades, it might be awhile. I can't believe how much money I've wasted on the safety razors over the years - no more. Conclusion, the Merkur is well built, easy to clean, nice quality - I'm very glad I purchased it.
  924. I really enjoy shaving with my new Merkur Heavy Duty. It provides a close save and, after you get used to the new technique required to shave with a double edge razor, you will not want to go back to the &#34;normal&#34; razors. Shaving becomes a new thing for you - much better.
