It is rounded enough to prevent that, but is a bit more pointy. So, at times that point gets me in the nose or neck. Other than that I really like it. I tried an Edwin Jagger DE89Lbl this morning. I liked that razor, but even though it is lined it is still too slippery compared to the Merkur's knurling.

If you take the time to get used to it, and use good shaving lather you will love this razor.<br /><br />It also cleans very easily and the blade is a breeze to change out.
  928. Have not used a safety razor in 40 years but missed the quality of the shave. My last safety razor was the Durham. I read 'The Ultimate Guide to Safety Razors'. Then I took my time, followed these recommendations and got a perfect shave the first time with no nicks. Amazing! I did one minor deviation from the suggestions. I continued to use liquid hand soap on my face. It has always worked for me and continues to do so with this razor and blade. The plastic handle disposable shavers were no longer working well for me.   930. The Merkur #34C (aka Heavy Duty DE Razor) has a short, BUT VERY THICK handle that is ideal if you have some pretty heavy hands that otherwise would make the #180 Long Handle impractical to use (something that I personally use because my fingers ARE long). This was a gift but I still played around it after presenting this to him when he asked for one. I'd have no complaints traveling with this, it's a nice little companion that offer's a lot.   931. After researching on-line the 34C was recommended for a beginner to wet shaving. After several shaves I highly recommend Merkur and their 34C. Initially I was concerned about the handle length (which was a lot shorter than my cartridge razors), after my first shave I found that the length of handle actually helped in the balance and control. The quality of design, materials & build are incredible -certainly worth the cost. If you're new to WS, you won't go wrong with the 34C, just remember to keep the pressure off and let the weight of the razor do the work. Coming from years of cartridge scraping, added pressure was necessary to drag the multiple blades through one's beard. Something you will not need do with a DE/safety razor; in fact, too much pressure will cause nicks, razor burn and other issues which will make your face unhappy. I did use the included blade for the first three (3) shaves and am now trying out blades from a sample set. Something highly recommended for a newbie, as well as the book &#34;Gourmet Shaving. A lot of useful info, insight and recommendations that has helped a lot.
  932. My sensitive skin needs all the help it can get . And this device on my face helps drastically to reduce razor bumps . I'm a dark skin black male and guys in my shoes notoriously get razor bumps from a lot of different shavers . This one blade action on my skin gives me a close shave without having to deal with 3 or 4 blades pulling my facial hair causing them to curl back in causing severe razor bumps . I've been using this style razor for a few years now and I love it . Just one thing. Be careful because the double edge blade that goes in it is sharp as hell!!!

The irritation of the cartridge razors is a thing of the past and to top it all off I can now pickup 100 blades for about 11 bucks! I used a Gillet Mach 3 and it was probably the best cartridge I have used and was smooth if I rubbed my face after shaving in one direction, but after shaving with this my face is literally \\"baby bottom smooth\\" in all directions, even my wife is surprised at how smooth my face is. The picture is my actual set-up.<br /><br />Adding a two week follow-up: I am still very impressed with this razor and I mentioned above about some slight irritation and as I thought it was just the change in shaving, or possibly the blade, but after a couple days of this new shaving I had no irritation. My technique is gradually getting better and there is a difference in blades used. I have so far tried Derby, Personna (Red), Crystal, Merkur and Astra. I still have a pack of Feather blades to try but wanted to make sure my technique was down before trying those. Astra is my favorite blade with this razor, very close shave, no pulling or tugging, and no irritation. I can see sticking with this razor for a long time and I also very much better understand the comments about better control with the short handle. I would highly recommend this razor for beginners or advanced users as I don't see how you can get a closer shave. I will even recommend this to my Barber for neck shaves.y recommend this razor for beginners or advanced users as I don't see how you can get a closer shave. The razor itself holds the blade such that it's not very aggressive, so that allows you to use sharper blades without getting all sliced up by them (I'm experimenting with feathers, wilkinsons, and personas right now, after having used astras for a few months and finding them not as aggressively sharp as I'd like).

  994. This is one product that lives up to the sales hype. It's been decades since I used a DE Safety razor and the Merkur brought me back to basic shaving with no (cut) anxiety. Initially I was interested because of the rising cost of easier shaves. I've been getting the new model of Norelco (fantastic electric razor) each year for hundreds of dollars. This Merkur seems kind of pricey but it will last forever and the cost of blades is negligible. Just don't go crazy on expensive shaving creams or soaps.<br /><br />I'm subject to severe ingrown hairs due to my wire-like curly beard. In the past I attributed it to the razor but it was my shaving method. Over the years I &#34;discovered&#34; the way to shave as to minimize ingrown hairs and razor burns. It applies to both bladed and electric razors. Allow me to pass the word:<br /><br />1) DO NOT shave against the direction your beard grows. Notice the neck hairs grow side to side.<br />2) DO NOT stretch the skin. The hairs will bend back into place beneath the surface of the face and start growing inwards.<br />3) DO NOT press the razor into your face. Just let the weight of the razor do the work or barely touch your face.<br /><br />The most important part is #3. There will ALWAY be times when you need to shave against the direction of the beard or when you have to stretch the skin, but you should NEVER press too hard. That cuts hair below the skin line.
  995. The Merkur Heavy Duty is a high precision beauty of classic technology. Feels like it will last forever, just the opposite of most things in our disposable society. I have small hands, and the standard handle length on this razor surprised me with how short it is. I don't really have a problem shaving with it, but it actually looks funny its so short. Men with larger hands will definitely want one of the long handled models, and all sizes may want to consider the long handle. One factor that should benefit longevity is that this razor is solid stainless steel (from Solingen, Germany no less!), so it should resist nicks, dents, and mechanical wear better than the more common brass razors with chrome plate. I am very pleased with this razor and would recommend it to anyone who does not need a long handle.

  1006. I grew up using an electric razor and one day I decided I finally had enough of it. Having never had a wet shave before, I youtubed a couple of helpful videos, and after a rough shave or two, I quickly learned how to work the razor. I still get an ingrown hair now and then, but not nearly as many as I did beforehand.   1007. I have been trying to get out of paying Gillette a king's ransom for replacement razors, but hadn't found a solution. I tried Dollar Shave Club, Henry's, a straight razor (for the high maintenance shaver), and then on a whim decided to try a safety razor. This Merkur razor is awesome.<br /><br />Shaving with this took some getting used to (customers who bought this item also bought a styptic pencil), but it has been great. I shave with the grain first pass, against the grain second pass and I get a super clean shave. And &#34;high-end&#34; replacement blades for the Merkur run about .50 per blade. My problem area is under the nose, and although the Merkur doesn't shave that spot as economically as the Fusion precision blade, it works far better than any other solution I've found.<br /><br />I wish I would have bought this razor sooner. I love it for its utility, for the replacement blade cost, and its durability. I would buy this again.... if it weren't such a tank of a razor. I can't imagine ever needing to buy it again.
  1008. This is based on my very first shave with a safety razor. Had been a Mach III/Fusion guy till now, but I found I was going through the cartridges rather quickly (around 2 months, on average). So I did some online research and found many people recommending safety razors, if for nothing than for their affordability. I went for the Merkur 34C after reading about the strong grip it offers because of its weight (it does) and, well, because its Merkur. The razor came with a Merkur blade.<br />A common observation shared by newbie safety razor users is that getting nicks is unavoidable, specially during the first few shaves. Imagine my delight when I didn't get a single nick during my first shave! Plus, I don't know how to explain it, but my face feels a lot naturally lighter after the shave, when compared how it would after a shave with a Fusion. The irritation is also virtually non-existent, again not something that cartridge razors could do. However, I was initially afraid about going against the grain with a safety razor, but realised it was a must if I wanted to get anywhere near a close shave. Going with the grain was basically pointless, which made me wonder if it has to do with the blade (the Merkur blade) than with safety razors in general. But going against the grain did the trick. So, overall, fairly happy with my first shaving experience with safety razors!
  1009. I'm returning to wet shaving after years with an electric. Did my homework and felt the Merkur 34C would work well for me. I was right. The heft is perfect and the short handle is just right for shaving down across the jaw bone as a longer handle could require me to bend my neck back to less comfortable angles to give clearance. Like it so much, I ordered the Merkur travel shaver for when I'm on the road.
  1010. It's not a butterfly hinged style, but rather a screw plate which makes it tricky to load. But the plate flexes the blade to just the right angle for a really close shave. First time I used it, I applied too much pressure (what I normally use with my multi-blade) and nicked myself a a lot. After, the second shave, I got the feel of it and am now getting the best shave I've ever had from any razor. I get generic blades from a local pharmacy for now, and still get a great shave. Blades last about 5 to 6 shaves and I have a coarse beard. At 24 cents a blade, that translates to huge long term savings. Plus it's environmentally a good it. Far less waste. Looking forward to buying bulk premium blades online and saving even more. This razor is built simply and will last forever.
  1011. Absolutely fantastic razor. I've turned 4 people onto this razor, and I use it myself. I love it.

It has good sturdy weight to it and therefore has a very solid feel in the hand.<br /><br />Overall a very nice razor and we are very pleased with it.

  1019. I absolutely love this razor. I already have a Merkur 23c 180 long handle but didn't like the weight of it. Too light. I also thought that I &#34;needed&#34; a longer handle because that's what I was used too in cartridge land. I found out that the shorter handles make it easier to maneuver. I then bought an Edwin Jagger DE89L based on reviews. Yes the razor is beautiful, chrome, etc... I used it for about 5 months everyday, head and face, to get used to it. Tried all kinds of blades and angles... My razor is either defective or it's just not good for me. The blades never felt smooth over my face and left me raw no matter what angle or how lightly it touched my face (never hade problems with it on my head though). I could live with it but decided to try another Merkur as the 34c was it's main competitor.<br /><br />People on forums said the 34c is more aggressive than the DE89... I just don't see how. I shaved my head and face today with it... no nicks, no cuts, no irritation. The alum bar didn't sting at all which was a (somewhat missed) change. My aftershave didn't burn, my neck wasn't red. So... either my DE89 sucks and EJ should send me a new one or people haven't actually used a 34c. Currently I am using Astra SP blades. I have 50 Feathers on the way...<br /><br />If you're on the fence, this is a great option.

Shave soap will leave a residue on the razor and make it appear dull and not shiny without a little cleaning.<br /><br />I'm sure there are better razors out there that can give you a closer shave on your final BBS pass.   1072. My first safety razor was the Edwin Jagger chrome plated razor. It worked great for about a year. Though there was a short adjustment period where I had nicks and cuts, I appreciated the greater control (and the cost savings) compared to cartridge razors. After a year of shaving with the Jagger, however, screw which seated into the stem became corroded and did was difficult to thread and screw on- in my effort to get it screwed on I stripped the threads. I liked the Jagger, but thought I would try a different model and selected this one (Merkur) based largely on the positive ratings, and have been pretty happy with it.<br /><br />What I like about it: First and foremost- this is definitely a safety razor. I can't explain why- don't understand it myself- but this razor is decidedly safer (harder to cut yourself with) than the Jagger. I've been using it now for a few months, and don't think it is any less close of a shave. In order to get the desired level of closeness I shave twice with these razors- and am very pleased with how close a shave doing so achieves. Having the screw at the bottom makes changing blades easier and faster than the top screw of the Jagger.<br /><br />What I don't like: I wish it had a bit more heft. This 'heavy duty' was supposed to be pretty heavy, and though it is substantial I believe it is lighter than the Jagger (which was longer). Probably a very individual preference- but I'd like it to be heavier. I'm not sure it would make it more stable, but the lighter weight is noted and not preferred. This is largely me being very critical- but knowing there is one with a longer handle- I'd probably go with it in hopes of getting a greater heft.<br /><br />All in all, I'm satisfied, pleased with it, and glad that I got it. It's a good razor. If you're looking to get a safety razor, I think you'll be pleased with it.
  1073. I got tired of spending $20.00 for 4 razor blades. So I bought this highly crafted razor like my Father used. I am 61 now and the first time that I used it I was amazed, it was the best shave I ever had. I highly recommend this razor, it is high quality!!!
  1074. Better than the long handle for my face. Also it loads easier, as it unscrews from the handle, not the blade.

  1080. This razor is my first attempt/return to wet shaving. My father always used shaving soap and a brush when I was growing up but I never really used it full time. I started with an electric razor almost twenty years ago and used a cartridge razor when I wanted a closer shave. I finally got fed up with the poor shave that I received from the electric razor (despite the high price tag) and the discomfort of the cartridge. I wanted to return to a wet shave. After nearly a month of it I cannot believe I waited this long to return to the traditional shaving practice. It takes only a little more time than I used to spend gnawing at my face with my electric razor and is much more enjoyable. I use shaving soap and was very pleasantly surprised about how easy the transition was. The quality of this razor really assists in the transition. Its weight and size encourages you to be gentle with the blade and produces a very close shave at the same time. I have had very few cuts or nicks at all (I was expecting a lot). A lot of people/reviews say this is the double edge razor that all others are measured by, I can see why.
  1081. Well I'm 61 and just started shaving with a DE razor about three weeks ago and I wish I had started 30 years ago. My curousity was triggered by the commercial Rick Harrison does on TV for DE razors. I started to do a little research online and to my amazement discovered DE shaving is making a big come back. Disposable razors came out just about the time I started shaving so I didn't use a DE when I was younger but I remember there always being a bunch of butterfly type DE razors laying around in the bathroom that my mom and dad used. Wish I had them now.<br /><br />I have used disposables all my life and started using a Braun electric a few years ago. My beard is about medium-heavy I would guess and to be honest I can get a pretty good shave with disposables. The only good thing about the electric is it is so fast and easy, but it comes nowhere close to even a disposable blade shave and within a few hours I have a pretty serious stubble going on.<br /><br />I decided to try DE shaving and I am so glad I did! I bought 3 razors, the Murkur 34C HD, the Murkur Futur and the Edwin Jagger DE89L because they are so highly rated for beginners and the least aggressive. Also bought a blade sampler pack, various other small packs of blades, a brush, soap, alum bar, razor/brush stand, brush bowl and countless other accessories, etc. I have not cut or nicked myself one time :). There is a learning curve, but I did my research and watched some youtube videos so I avoided the mistakes that a newby could make that would cause them to possibly give up on DE shaving.<br /><br />I started off with the Murkur 34C HD with a Murkur blade in it. The first week, I had a slight amount of irritation during the day but I was not using any aftershave or skin conditioner. I bought several different kinds of aftershave, including an aftershave sampler from MR. Fine online and some skin conditioners. I have been having fun using a different aftershave everyday and I really enjoy the little whiffs of scent throughout the day. Some of the old timers like Old Spice, Aqua Velva blue ice and Clubman are still great aftershaves and I love them. The aftershave was the icing on the cake and my face now feels great all day and I am still amazed at how smooth my face is and for how long.<br /><br />Although there was a little trial and error in the beginning, my routine is now pretty quick and simple. I shave before I shower and although I use hot water to warm up my brush, I now use cold water to shave because I felt hot water was opening my pores too much which increased irritation. I warm my badger bristle brush while brushing my teeth, then wet my face with cold water, whip up a nice thick, wet lather and cover my beard. I make a pass with the grain, re-lather and make a pass across the grain, re-lather, and the third pass is against the grain. Learning the correct amount of pressure (almost none) is key, DE blades are so sharp minimal pressure is needed. I rinse my face, run the alum block over the shaved area (there is a little stinging) and jump in the shower. After drying off, I splash on some aftershave (little more stinging) and by the time the aftershave dries, all irritation is gone, I smell great, my face is incredibly smooth and I am good until the following morning.<br /><br />After the initial investment, DE shaving is quite inexpensive. I change my blade every monday morning although I think I could run them much longer. I used the Murkur blade I got with the razor for 10 days and I was just starting to notice a little dullness. I am now using an Astra blade and it is giving me an excellent shave. My plan is to use each razor for one month to get a feel for how each one shaves. It is important for someone just starting to do some serious research on the various razors that are available because they have different levels of aggressiveness. If someone just starting out bought a razor that was too aggressive they might hack their face up and throw it in the garbage.<br /><br />So, thats my story an I'm sticking with it :) I HIGHLY recommend anyone thinking about doing this to spend some serious time on some of the larger DE shaving forums because there is really a lot to learn about all of the various razors, blades, soaps, brushes, techniques, accessories, etc. I'm really glad I did, and now shaving has become almost a hobby and something I look forward to doing instead of it being a morning drudgery. I also think it is ironic that Gillette which invented the DE razor and sold tens of millions of them does not make one now, at least as far as I can determine.<br /><br />So check it out and enjoy your morning BBS (Baby Butt Smooth) shave!
  1082. I have had this razor one month - since mid-July 2015. I bought it to replace a Parker 92R which I used for 4 months. Problem with the Parker is that the knob used to open the butterfly kept getting loose while shaving which occasionally led to nicks or cuts. The Merkue #34C is far superior. Although it's a 2 piece the shaves are much better. No nicks yet. The safety bar is perfectly positioned. The handle is shorter than the Parker but very easy to control. The grip is superior even with some lather on it. I shave every day and there is hardly any irritation whether I use Cremo Cream or Taylor of Old Bond Street. I plan to switch to Feather bladed based on the reviews after I finish using the Personnas I received with the Parker. The Personnas are fine but the Feathers might be even better. That switch won't happen until sometime in 2016 as I get 5 shaves from each Personna.
  1083. I'm new to DE shaving so I don't have any other razors to compare it to. I can tell you this razor is a quality piece. I found no blemishes in the finish and it seems like it's built to far outlive it's owner. Much research led me to this as my first DE razor and I'm very happy with it.
  1084. not a better shaver on the market - perfectly weighted, for great control and balance. Partnered with Feather blades and its a perfect match.
  1085. Great DE razor to introduce oneself to wet shaving. Well constructed and feels solid. Would anticipate this can last for decades!
  1086. Really good razor! I guess this is the razor I would recommend to a friend who was interested in taking up wet shaving. It is not my favorite but it is about half as expensive as my Weber. The results are pretty close to it though! It is probably about a medium aggressiveness, and so it gives a smooth shave with little to no discomfort.<br /><br />The blade included in the pack however is another story! I have never liked Merkur blades they just don't do a good job for me, and they don't seem to have improved since last time I tried them YMMV. Try other blades if you order this razor and take the time to learn the techniques required to use this tool properly and you will be rewarded with a better shave than with one of those multi-bladed jobs. Though I admit it is a little more work and I do have to pay attention which I never did when I shaved with a new Gillette, but i get fewer ingrown hairs, and almost never get any razor burn like I did with that thing either.<br /><br />I haven't had this long enough to address the plating issues that some have had but as I shave with distiller water and wipe my razor after every shave I doubt I will have any.
  1087. Works very well (Although I would have prefered one a bit longer).<br />Very well made, should last a lifetime.
  1088. I have both this Merkur Heavy Duty #34 and the Edwin Jagger DE89Lbl. They are both great safety razors. The Merkur is a two piece design. The Jagger is a three piece design. I personally prefer the German two piece design over the English three piece design. I think the Jagger manufacturing quality is slightly better than the Merkur.
  1089. Anyone who uses this razor will probably never go back to conventional razors. This is easy to use and only requires double-edge razors as replacements (which are much much cheaper than conventional 4 or 5 blade replacements). A must for any guy!
  1090. I purchased this razor after reading multiple reviews that this was a good all-around double-edge razor. This was my first foray into the use of a double-edge razor and I have found it is not as scary and death defying as I thought it would be. Using an Astra razor blade (for now) from an Amazon-sold variety pack, I found that the Merkur and the blade itself are surprisingly forgiving. The blade drops into the Merkur easily and tightens without issue. The Merkur feels solid and has a good weight. The razor glides over the face and I have yet to cut myself. I found that with this razor and blade, I can be a lot less careful than I thought I needed to be, and I have not had to dramatically change my shaving method from when I used a Gillette Fusion. With, across and against the grain, I have had no problem with cuts. So far I have not had as close a shave as promised, but it is closer than the Gillette I previously used, and I have to continue to work on my method and I will likely purchase a badger hair brush, good shaving cream and change to a sharper blade from my variety pack (probably Feather) in the near future to assist the process. For those entering the double-edge razor arena, the Merkur is a solid piece of equipment and is good for a beginning and advanced shaver (according to those who are advanced double-edge shavers on the forums), and not nearly as brutal as I thought.
  1091. The best and most used double edge razor in the market.
  1092. The razor itself looks nice and had a good weight to it. Very comfortable in the hand. HOWEVER... The head wasn't machined perfectly symmetrical. One side of the blade (the included blade) stuck out slightly more than the other, which made that side shave more aggressively than the other side, which shaved too mild to get a good cut. If it had been too mild or too aggressive on both sides, it would be OK and you could deal with it. But with each side having different shaving characteristics, it was too much to deal with. Especially since this is a \\"beginner\\" safety razor, I have a hard time recommending a product that isnt consistent. A completely new person to double edge shaving might not realize why they keep burning their face some strokes and hardly getting off hair with the next. As in most cases, you get what you pay for. This is a pretty cheap razor that has a great reputation for the most part. I got one bad one, there are lots of good ones out there. Hopefully someone reads this who is having problems and can check for alignment before their 30 day return period is up!
  1093. This razor is straight old school cool
  1094. where have you been all my life?!?! my favorite, hands down
  1095. This is actually the second double-edge razor that I have purchased. My first was a Merkur Futur, which I felt was a little unforgiving and aggressive to my skin. Based on the Futur, I wasn't sure that DE shaving was for me. The first shave with a 34C, however, proved to me that I made a good move switching to a DE razor. I've used this razor for about a week now and my skin has never been happier. I have some pretty sensitive areas on my neck, but using this razor has been a blessing. I was initially concerned about the length of the handle, but those worries went away quickly. At this point, my shaves are just about smooth as glass with no nicks or irritation. Trust me, it will take a while to get the hang of a DE razor. Don't give up, though. This razor is the best thing that has happened to my shaves ever. I actually shave every day now (when I used to shave about twice a week) because I like the experience. I wouldn't have thought that buying a razor would be a life-changing event, but I really am happy with this purchase.
  1096. I was very surprised on how much better this 'old style' razor performed compared to modern razors in terms of shave comfort and closeness. For a number of years I have increasingly been unhappy with the multi-blade shaving razors by Gillette, Bic, etc. I was contemplating making the switch out of desperation. Now that I have been using the Merkur for a little over a week, I wish I pulled the trigger sooner. It is not a slight improvement but a remarkably improved shaving experience. It took me no time to learn how to use it. Whereas today's modern disposable razors are nimble like a sports car, this is more like a truck but the comfort and smoothness cannot be beat. An incredibly close shave. I can see that if you have larger hands, this razor may seem a bit small, but for my average sized hands it is fine. It comes with one Merkur blade which was perfectly okay to me and now I am trying the Wilkinson German blades (which I find no difference).
  1097. Husband loves this razor
  1098. This is a nice tool to hold in your hand - nice and heavy, well made, etc. But I did not find it gave me a close shave like the Fusion. And it ave me worse razor burn. But if you like old school razors, this is a good one, which is why I gave it three stars
  1099. Don't be scared of the safety feature. This razor will give you the closest shave you can experience. I wish I would have converted years ago
  1100. The Merkur 34C is a great product. This is my first double edge safety razor, and I doubt I'll need to ever buy a second. This is precision made with a beautiful chrome finish and knurled handle. Nice weight to it. I use this with Shark blades from Japan. I will never go back to modern day multi blade cartridge systems.
  1101. I have 4 Merkur razors counting this one I just purchased and out of all 4 this Merkur #34 is my favorite and its a great razor well worth the money spent.<br />I like the way that it is a 2 piece over most others are a 3 piece.<br />Shaves great and a real nice razor with a great feel and weight.
  1102. I'm new to wet shaving and I'm so glad I decided to pay extra for this razor. It has a very solid construction and I have no doubt that I'll be able to pass this down to my son when he gets old enough. The shave is very nice, I have thick beard hair and this razor cuts through it with no problem. The heft of the razor allows for a nice glide down your face without applying to much force. If you want a solid razor with quality construction at a reasonable price look no further. German engineering at its finest.
  1103. This razor is rated very high and for good reason, it's always a risk purchasing something that you have never tried and that's why I rely heavily on my fellow reviewers, I was just telling my wife about the difference in this razor and the Edwin Jagger DE89Lbl it's almost like you can get a feel for where they were made, the merkur being made in Germany and the Edwin Jagger made in England. The merkur is solid and well made, very hefty and feels like a well built tank in your hand. The Edwin Jagger on the other hand feels elegant and flawless, I know I'm a bit partial towards the Edwin Jagger but if you try it out you will be as well. Okay moving on, this razor is great you really can't go wrong with it, the handle is a bit short for me but I'm thinking I have to get used to it, I also ordered the long handle as well due to Amazon having the wrong description but heck I kept it,
  1104. Really heavy duty shaving razor. I like it so much I bought a 2nd one as a christmas present for my brother. It comes with a free razor, but throw that away (or recycle it rather) and buy yourself a supply of Feather razors to get a close shave that doesn't cut your face.
  1105. Nice, heavy feel razor. Well made and works like it's supposed to.
  1106. I gave wet shaving a try after not being able to stomach the disposable cartridge price at Costco. This razor works perfect for me. As I had used disposable razors (as opposed to an electric) there was not much adjustment. I watched a couple of youtube videos that helped with the process. I started slow with short strokes with the grain and really had no problems. For a close shave, I will do two passes, the first with the grain and second against. For a super close shave, I have used a shaving oil first and then applied the shaving cream. Normal shave really takes no longer than the old disposable, is closer and way cheaper once you have the set-up. Will never go back to modern technology or advertising. Looking forward to my order for upgraded blades and soaps.
  1107. My first safety razor. Very well constructed - heavy and balanced well. I bought Astra replacement blades because the Merkur blades that were included weren't quite sharp enough for my heavy-ish beard.
  1108. This razor is my new go to razor, great feel and plenty of control with when wet. I have a couple of razors that have thinner smooth handles and they are difficult to control when wet and easily results in nicking my neck. This handle actually is thicker in than any razor I own and has perfect control. Loading the blade is easy and the razor seems to rinse well with very little loading under the blade with heavy creams.
  1109. Bought this for my husband for Christmas, and he loves it! Gives him a super close shave without all irritation. You do have to use a good quality shaving cream - not just one from the drug store.
  1110. Just now started using a DE razor and its awesome. Such a smooth shave when you use a good cream and brush. The weight feels really well in my hand. I have nothing but great things to say about the Merkur 34C. I will say that the Merkur blades are not very good. I used it once and then swapped it for a personna coated blade(American made) very sharp but not like a feather. Great for a coarse beard.
  1111. good weight, works as advertised, recommend!<br /><br />Update 2/12/15: I think I personally prefer the Butterfly style of blade removal, but no big deal. Also wanted to add, in an attempt to \\"sling\\" off excess water to enhance drying out the interior of handle, the screw-piston close/open device went flying out, bounced off the wall and hit the floor....so for those of you who want to make sure the inner works of this thing get dried out, it does come apart into 3 (actually 4) parts...the 4th part is a cylinder-ring type device wrapped around the piston, to hold it inside the handle. Apparently you can dislodge it if so inclined, as I did.<br />It's dry now, by gad....and no broken parts!
  1112. Fits my hand just right. If you don't have nimble fingers, than go with this one
  1113. I have no complaints about this razor. It works great as expected. I have not used any other DE razor but I have no reason to try any other after using this.
  1114. I had been considering a safety razor for about a year and settled on a Merkur based on favorable reviews online. I keep a short beard so I primarily use this razor to keep my neck and upper cheeks trim and smooth. I was concerned about the shorter handle initially (being used to disposable razors), but decided the original design involved a short handle for a reason. I find that the shorter handle is a nice advantage, providing enough balance and weight while also allowing me to shave around my neck without being cumbersome. Feels solid in the hand and shaves very well once you develop some technique. Even as I'm learning to use it properly, I find that razor burn and ingrown hairs have become less common.
  1115. Great Razor the weight is perfect and the shorter handle makes it easy to control and get a great shave.
  1116. Settled on this safety razor after much searching. I've found you can go as cheap or expensive as you would want to and still be able to find a good quality razor that meets your needs. This one works great for me!
  1117. I moved from multiple blades to double edged to be kinder to my skin and reduce shaving bumps, etc. So far, the Merkur has proved very easy to get started with and the blades that came with it are excellent and last at least 1 week. There is generally less irritation, particularly if I start with a pre-shave oil and work the lather with a brush. Taking your time to get a smooth shave is essential to getting a shave as close as the multi-blade razors.
  1118. FINALLY no more money wasted on overpriced disposable cartridges. I wish I would have tried this years ago. I was nervous about using this razor at first, but it's very easy to use and works great.
  1119. I purchased this Razor 2 years ago ( March 2013 ) along with the Feather blades. It is absolutely better than the cartridge razors. You shave with this razor as if it were sharp...unlike the safety razors that you can just whip across your face. The difference is this will last for 30 years or more. The razor is robust and sturdy, it has a little heft to it ....though I don't notice it anymore. I disassemble mine after each use and clean it off to prevent build up. The finish has not dulled at all. It could still pass for brand new. The screw bottom ( which tightens and loosens the blade housing ) secures tightly and firmly. The blades drop onto the pegs with alacrity and when the head is screwed down it lines up precisely and consistently every time. I look forward to continued use.
  1120. Gillette and other foolishness never again. Merkur is the best razor I was shaving with in my entire life. Highly recommended for people with​ sensitive skin.
  1121. The Merkur 34C is a great operating razor for a good price. Most of my life I used Gillette razors, butterfly, adjustable and ball-end. I still have the ball-end so I compared it with my new Merkur using Derby blades. I can't say exactly why, but the Merkur cuts more smoothly. The heft difference is noticeable but I think the blade gap must be slightly different as well. Whatever the reasons, I retired the ball-end razor and now use only the Merkur. My aged sun-damaged skin is in better shape than it has been in years.
  1122. little small for my hand. But very nice shave, very proffesional looking. Moving to the single edge blade really reduced the amount of ingrown hairs too.
  1123. Well crafted and works nicely. Probably a good reason for the reputation!

  1127. It doesn't shave as smooth as the 38C , though the 34C's blade gap should be bigger than my earlier 38C's. Simply,it doesn't have as much blade exposure as the 38C,and this problem had a great negative impact on my shaves with it.
